Osama took it and handed it to Buraidah, and they encamped at the Jurf, and among those who volunteered with Osama (427) were the elders of the Emigrants (Muhajiroon) (428) and the Helpers (Ansaar), including: Abu Bakr, Umar, Abu Ubaydah, Sa'd, Sa'id, Qatadah ibn al-Numan, and Salamah ibn Aslam… Some spoke about this, including Uyayesh ibn Rabiah al-Makhzumi, and Umar replied to him, and the Prophet, peace be upon him [and his holy progeny], was informed, and he addressed them as mentioned in this narration; then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him [and his holy progeny], became more severely ill, and he said: "Send out Osama's army," and Abu Bakr prepared him after appointing a successor in the area he was commanded. He traveled for twenty nights, killed his father's murderer, and returned with the troop safe, having gained spoils.

footnote.p: 3- لا یوجد فی المصدر : ( سامیاً ) .
(426) Not present in the source: (high).
4- در [ الف ] اشتباهاً اینجا : ( کان ) اضافه شده است .
(427) The addition of (was) here in [A] is an error.
5- در [ الف ] اشتباهاً اینجا : ( من المهاجرین ) اضافه شده است .
(428) The addition of (of the Emigrants) here in [A] is an error.

para.p: وقد قصّ أصحاب المغازی قصته مطولة فلّخصتها ، وکانت آخر سریة جهّزها النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم وأول شیء جهّزه أبو بکر .

The companions of the campaigns narrated his story at length, so I summarized it, and it was the last expedition the Prophet (peace be upon him [and his holy progeny]) prepared was the one he arranged for Osama, and the first person to prepare it was Abu Bakr.
وقد أنکر ابن تیمیة فی کتاب الردّ علی ابن المطهر أن یکون أبو بکر وعمر کانا فی بعث أُسامة .
Ibn Taymiyyah denied in his book "Al-Radd 'ala Ibn al-Mutahir" that Abu Bakr and Umar were present in Osama's mission.
ومستند من (429) ذکره ما أخرجه الواقدی بإسناده فی المغازی ، وذکره ابن سعد فی أواخر الترجمة النبویة به غیر اسناد ، وذکره ابن اسحاق فی السیرة الصغری المشهورة ، ولفظه :

The basis for (429) his statement is what al-Waqidi reported in his "Al-Maghazis" with his chain of narration, and Ibn Sa'd mentioned it at the end of the Prophetic biography without a chain. Ibn Ishaq also noted it in the famous "Sirah al-Sughra," and its wording is:

footnote.p: 1- فی المصدر : ( ما ) ، وهو الصواب .
(429) In the source: (ما), and this is the correct version.

para.p: بدئ برسول [ الله ] صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم وجعه یوم الأربعاء فأصبح یوم الخمیس ، فعقد لأُسامة وقال : « اغز فی سبیل الله و سر إلی موضع مقتل أبیک فقد ولّیتک علی هذا الجیش » . فذکر القصة وفیها : فلم یبق أحد من المهاجرین الأولین إلاّ انتدب فی تلک الغزوة ، منهم : أبو بکر وعمر ; ولمّا جهّزه أبو بکر بعد أن استخلف ، سأله أبو بکر أن یأذن له بإقامته ، فأذن . ذکر ذلک کلّه ابن الجوزی فی المنتظم جازماً به . (2) انتهی .

The Messenger of [Allah] (peace be upon him [and his holy progeny]) began to experience his illness on Wednesday and woke up on Thursday. He then appointed Osama and said: "March in the way of Allah and set out to the place of your father's murder, for I have appointed you over this army." The story continues: Therefore, there was no one among the early emigrants (Muhajirin) except that they volunteered for that expedition, including: Abu Bakr and Umar; and when Abu Bakr prepared him after he had appointed a successor, Abu Bakr asked him for permission to stay behind. He consented. Ibn al-Jawzi mentioned all this in "Al-Muntazam," asserting it. (430) End.

footnote.p: 2- [ الف ] کتاب الغزوات . ( 12 ) . [ ب ] فتح الباری 8 / 107 ( طبع مصر سنه 1325 ) . [ فتح الباری 8 / 115 - 116 ] .
(430) [A] Kitab al-Ghazawat (12). [B] Fath al-Bari 8/107 (Printed in Egypt, year 1325). [Fath al-Bari 8/115-116].

para.p: و در “ مدارج النبوة “ شیخ عبدالحق دهلوی مذکور است :
And it is mentioned in "Madarij al-Nubuwwah" by Shaikh Abdul Haqq Dehlawi:

حکم عالی چنان صادر شد که اعیان مهاجر و انصار ، مثل ابوبکر صدیق و عمر فاروق و عثمان ذی النورین و سعد بن ابیوقاص و ابوعبیدة بن الجراح و غیرهم - الا علی مرتضی [ ( علیه السلام ) ] که همراه نگردد - در آن لشکر همراه اسامه باشند ، [ و این معنا بر خاطر بعضی مردم گران آمد که غلامی را بر اکابر مهاجرین و انصار امیر گردانید ] (1) و در مجالس سخنان از این جماعت در این باب به ظهور میآمد و ورود مییافت ، این اخبار چون به سمع شریف رسید ، خاطر مبارکش رنجیده شد و به غضب در آمد ، با وجود تب و دردِ سر ، از خانه - سر مبارک به عصابه بربسته - بیرون آمد و بر سر منبر رفت ، و خطبه خواند و گفت : « ای معشر الناس ! این چه سخن است که در باب امیر ساختن من اسامه را ، از شما سر بر میزند ؟ ! و در باب امارت پدرش در غزوه موته نیز سخن میکردید ! به خدا سوگند که [ وی ] (2) سزاوار امارت است ، و پدرش نیز سزاوار امارت بود ، و زید از دوست ترین مردم است [ و پسرش اسامه نیز از دوست ترین مردم است ] (3) نزد من بعد از وی ، و هر دو مظنّه خیرند ، اکنون وصیت من [ را ] در شأن وی به نیکی قبول کنید که وی از جمله اخیار شماست » . پس از منبر فرود آمد و به خانه درون رفت (4) .

A Divine Decree was issued that was so high that the notable figures of the Emigrants (Muhajirin) and the Helpers (Ansar), such as Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, Umar al-Faruq, Uthman Dhul-Nurayn, Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, and Abu Ubaydah ibn al-Jarrah, and others – except for Ali al-Murtadha (peace be upon him) who would not be accompanied – would be in that army with Osama, [and this matter weighed heavily on the minds of some people, that a slave was made an Amir over the senior members (Akabir) of the Muhajirin and Ansar] (431), and in gatherings, speeches from this group regarding this issue would emerge and be mentioned. When these reports reached his noble ears, his blessed heart was troubled and he became angry. Despite having a fever and a headache, he came out of the house – his holy head bound with a cloth – and went to the pulpit, delivered a sermon, and said: "O people! What is this speech that arises among you regarding me making Osama an Amir? And were you also not speaking about his father's leadership in the Battle of Mu'tah? By God, I swear that [he] (432) is worthy of leadership, and his father was also worthy of leadership. Zayd is one of the dearest people, [and his son Osama is also one of the dearest people] (433) to me after him, and both are likely to be good. Now, accept my will [regarding him] with kindness, for he is one of your best." Then he descended from the pulpit and entered the house (434).

footnote.p: 1- زیاده از مصدر .
(431) The addition is from the source.
2- زیاده از مصدر .
(432) The addition is from the source.
3- زیاده از مصدر و [ ب ] .
(433) The addition is from the source and [B].
4- [ ب ] مدارج النبوة 2 / 530 ( طبع نول کشور هند سنه 1323 ) . [ مدارج النبوة 2 / 530 ] .
(434) [B] Madarij al-Nubuwwah 2 / 530 (Nawl printing, India, 1323 AH). [Madarij al-Nubuwwah 2 / 530].

para.p: و نیز در “ مدارج النبوة “ آورده :
And it is also mentioned in "Madarij al-Nubuwwah":

اسامه بنابر فرموده آن حضرت صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم به لشکرگاه ‹ 57 › معاودت نمود ، و فرمان داد تا لشکر کوچ کنند ، و چون خواست که خود سوار شود ، مادرش اُمّ أیمن پیغام فرستاده که رسول خدا ( صلی الله علیه وآله ) در نزع است ، اسامه بازگشت و اشراف صحابه نیز مراجعه نمودند ، و ابوبکر صدیق و عمر فاروق و امثال ایشان ، خود در مدینه بودند ! (1) و نیز ابن حجر در “ فتح الباری “ در حدیث امارت اسامه در باب مناقب زید بن حارثه گفته :

Osama, according to the command of that Prophet, peace be upon him and [his holy progeny], returned to the army <57>, and commanded the army to move. And when he wanted to mount himself, his mother, Umm Ayman, sent a message that the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was in his final moments. Osama turned back, and the dignitaries of the Companions also came to see him, and Abu Bakr as-Siddiq and Umar al-Faruq, and others like them, were in Medina! (435)

footnote.p: 1- مدارج النبوة 2 / 531 .
(435) Madarij al-Nubuwwah 2 / 531.

para.p: و نیز ابن حجر در “ فتح الباری “ در حدیث امارت اسامه در باب مناقب زید بن حارثه گفته :
Ibn Hajar also mentioned in “Fath al-Bari” regarding the hadith of Osama's leadership in the chapter on the virtues of Zayd ibn Harithah:
وفیه جواز إمارة المولی ، وتولیة الصغار علی الکبار والمفضول علی الفاضل ; لأنه کان فی الجیش الذی کان علیهم أُسامة ، أبو بکر وعمر (436) .

And this indicates the permissibility of appointing a freed slave as a leader, and the appointment of those younger over the older, and those lesser over the greater; because in the army that was under their command was Osama, Abu Bakr, and Umar (436).

footnote.p: 2- [ الف ] باب مناقب زید بن حارثة ، من أبواب المناقب ، نسخة سید باقر صاحب . ( 12 ) . [ ب ] فتح الباری 8 / 70 ( طبع القاهرة الطبعة المنیریة سنة 1325 ) . [ فتح الباری 7 / 69 ] .
(436) [A] Chapter on the Virtues of Zayd ibn Harithah, from the Chapters on Virtues, copy of Sayyid Baqir Sahib. (12). [B] Fath al-Bari 8 / 70 (Cairo edition, Muniriyah, 1325). [Fath al-Bari 7 / 69].

para.p: و قسطلانی در “ شرح بخاری “ - در شرح قول : « إن رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم بعث بعثاً أمّر علیهم أُسامة بن زید » - گفته :

Qastalani in “Sharh Bukhari” – while explaining the statement: “Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) sent an expedition and appointed Osama ibn Zayd as their commander” – said:
وفیه وجوه المهاجرین والأنصار ، منهم أبو بکر وعمر (437) .
And it included the prominent members of the Emigrants and the Helpers, among them were Abu Bakr and Umar (437).

footnote.p: 3- ارشاد الساری 6 / 126 .
(437) Irshad al-Sari 6 / 126.

para.p: و ذهبی - که نزد مخاطب امام اهل حدیث است - در “ تهذیب التهذیب “ در ترجمه اسامه گفته :
And Zahabi – who is regarded by the Addressee as the Imam of Ahl al-Hadith – in “Tahdhib al-Tahdhib” in the biography of Osama, said:
أمّره النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم علی جیش فیه أبو بکر وعمر ، فلم ینفذ حتّی مات رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم . (438) انتهی .

The Prophet (peace be upon him [and his holy progeny]) appointed him as commander over an army that included Abu Bakr. and Umar, it was not carried out until the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him [and his holy progeny]) died. (438) End.

footnote.p: 1- تهذیب التهذیب 1 / 182 .
(438) Tahdhib al-Tahdhib 1 / 182.

para.p: کمال عجب است که با آنکه مأموریِ ابوبکر به خروج همراه جیش اسامه ، به روایات و اقوال ثقات متقدمین و متأخرین اهل سنت ثابت است ، کالواقدی ، وابن سعد ، وابن إسحاق ، وابن الجوزی ، والذهبی ، وابن حجر العسقلانی ، والقسطلانی ، وجمال الدین المحدّث ، وعبد الحق الدهلوی . . وغیرهم ممّن لا یخفی (2) ، باز متعصبین قوم از ثبوت آن انکار نمایند ، و در ابطال آن کوشند !

It is a complete wonder that although the appointment of Abu Bakr to leave with the expedition of Osama is established through the narratives and statements of the trustworthy early and later scholars of the Ahle Tasannun, such as al-Waqidi, Ibn Sa'd, Ibn Ishaq, Ibn al-Jawzi, al-Zahabi, Ibn Hajar al-Asqalani, al-Qastalani, Jamal al-Din al-Muhaddith, and Abdul Haqq al-Dihlawi… and others whose numbers are not hidden (439), yet the fanatics of the group still deny the establishment of this and strive to nullify it!

footnote.p: 2- انظر : شرح ابن ابی الحدید 1 / 159 - 160 و 6 / 52 ، 9 / 196 - 197 ، 12 / 83 ، 17 / 183 ( عن کثیر من المحدّثین ) ; البدایة والنهایة 6 / 335 ; تهذیب الکمال 2 / 340 ; الکامل لابن الأثیر 2 / 317 ; تاریخ الخمیس 2 / 154 ; وفیات الأعیان 8 / 374 ; جامع الأحادیث الکبیر 13 / 211 ; فتح الباری 8 / 115 ( أواخر کتاب المغازی ) ; تاریخ الیعقوبی 2 / 76 - 77 و 113 ; السیرة الحلبیة 3 / 228 ; عیون الأثر 2 / 352 ; نهایة الإرب 17 / 370 و 19 / 46 ; تاریخ مدینة دمشق 8 / 46 ; ( ترجمة أُسامة ) تاریخ الإسلام للذهبی ( المغازی ) 714 ; أنساب الأشراف 2 / 115 . و من طُرف الأخبار ما ذکره الیعقوبی فی المقام من أنّ أبا بکر بعد أن استولی علی الخلافة ، وأراد تنفیذ جیش أُسامة ، سأل أُسامة أن یترک له عمر یستعین به علی أمره ، فقال : ما تقول فی نفسک ؟ ! فقال : یابن أخی ! فعل الناس ما تری ، فدع لی عمر وأنفذ لوجهک ! انظر : تاریخ الیعقوبی 2 / 127 .

(439) See: Sharh Ibn Abi al-Hadid 1 / 159-160 and 6 / 52, 9 / 196-197, 12 / 83, 17 / 183 (from many of the muhaddithin); al-Bidaya wa'l-Nihaya 6 / 335; Tahdhib al-Kamal 2 / 340; al-Kamil ibn al-Athir 2 / 317; Tarikh al-Khamis 2 / 154; Wafiyat al-A'yans 8 / 374; Jami' al-Ahadith al-Kabir 13 / 211; Fath al-Bari 8 / 115 (late chapters of the Book of Ghazis); Tarikh al-Ya'qubi 2 / 76-77 and 113; Sirat al-Halabiya 3 / 228; Uyun al-Athar 2 / 352; Nihayat al-Irb 17 / 370 and 19 / 46; Tarikh Madinat Dimashq 8 / 46; (Biography of Usama) Tarikh al-Islam al-Zahabi (Ghazis) 714; Ansab al-Ashraf 2 / 115. Among the interesting reports is what Ya'qubi mentioned in this context, that after Abu Bakr seized power, and wanted to carry out Usama's expedition, he asked Usama to leave him Umar to assist him in his affairs, to which he replied: "What do you think of yourself?!" Usama said: "O son of my brother! The people have done what you see, so leave me Umar and carry out your mission!" See: Tarikh al-Ya'qubi 2 / 127.

para.p: ابن روزبهان میگوید که : صحیح شده که ابوبکر در جیش اسامه نبود ، و از شیخ جزری میآرد که : هر که دعوی میکند که ابوبکر در جیش اسامه بود پس خطا کرده (1) .

Ibn Ruzbihan says that: it has been firmly established that Abu Bakr was not in the army of Osama, and he quotes Shaikh Jazari as saying: whoever claims that Abu Bakr was in the army of Osama has made an error (440).

footnote.p: 1- احقاق الحق : 218 .
(440) Ihaqaq al-Haqq: 218.

para.p: و نصرالله کابلی هم نقاب حیا از رخ برگرفته ، به تقلید ابن روزبهان مأموریِ ابوبکر را انکار کرده ، چنانچه در جواب این طعن گفته :
And Nasrullah Kabuli also uncovers the veil of modesty from his face, denying the appointment of Abu Bakr in imitation of Ibn Ruzbihan, as he said in response to this reproach:
وهو باطل ; لأنه ما أنفذه و ما أمره بالرواح فی الجیش . . إلی آخره (441) .
And this is false; because he did not enact it and did not command it to be done in the army… till the end (441).

footnote.p: 2- الصواقع ، ورق : 253 - 254 .

para.p: و مخاطب با آنکه سرقت اقوال او ، و نسج بر منوال او پیشه گرفته ، لیکن از سرقت این انکار و دروغ فضیح استحیا کرده ، بلکه به اِلجای قادر علی الإطلاق ، خود نقل کرده که : ابوبکر و عمر و عثمان ساختگی کرده ، دیره و خیمه بیرون فرستاده بودند ، و میخواستند که از آنجا کوچ نمایند (3) .

And although he is engaged with one who has taken to stealing his sayings and weaving in his manner, he has felt shame in stealing this denial and lying, rather, by the will of the All-Powerful without restriction, he himself has narrated that: Abu Bakr, Umar, and Uthman had fabricated and sent a monastery (dayr) and tents outside, and they intended to move from there (442).

footnote.p: 3- مراجعه کنید به : تحفة اثناعشریه : 264 - 265 .
(442) Refer to: Tohfah Ithna'ashiriyah: 264-265.

para.p: و این را به کتب معتبره خود نسبت داده ، و به زبان خود کذب و وقاحت علمای خود [ را ] ظاهر ساخته .
And he attributes this to his own reliable books, manifesting falsehood and audacity of his scholars in his own words.
و ابن تیمیه وقاحت و بی حیایی را به پایان رسانیده که تکذیب آن به کمال تشدّد و مبالغه نموده ، و از نهایت جسارت ، ادعای اجماع علما بر کذب آن نموده ! چنانچه در جواب “ منهاج الکرامه “ گفته :

And Ibn Taymiyyah has brought audacity and shamelessness (bi haya) to an end, denying it with complete severity (takdhib) and exaggeration, and from the utmost insolence, claiming the consensus of scholars on its falsehood! As he said in response to "Minhaj al-Karamah":
أما قوله : إنه أمّر أُسامة علی الجیش الذین فیهم أبو بکر وعمر . . فمن الکذب الذی یعرفه من له أدنی معرفة بالحدیث ، فإن أبا بکر لم یکن فی ذلک الجیش (443) .

As for his statement: "Indeed, he appointed Osama over the troop (jaysh) in which were Abu Bakr and Umar..." this is one of the lies known to anyone with the slightest understanding of hadith, for Abu Bakr was not in that army (443).

footnote.p: (443) [A and B] In response, a fifth argument for the truth of the Shia belief from the first methodology. (12). [Minhaj al-Sunnah 4/276].

para.p: And in another place, when Allameh Hilli mentions the three who deviated from Osama's troop, Ibn Taymiyyah responded:
الجواب من وجوه :
"The answer is from several perspectives:

أحدها : المطالبة بصحة النقل ، فإن هذا لا یروی بإسناد معروف ، ولا صحّحه أحد من علماء النقل ، و معلوم : إن الاحتجاج بالمنقولات لا یسوغ إلا بعد قیام الحجة ‹ 58 › بثبوتها وإلا فیمکن أن یقول کل أحد ما شاء !

The first of them is the demand for the authenticity of the report, for this is not narrated with a known chain of transmission (isnad), nor did any of the scholars of transmission validate it, and it is well-known: that using transmitted reports as evidence is only permissible after establishing proof of their validity; otherwise, anyone could say whatever they wanted!

الثانی : إن هذا کذب بإجماع علماء النقل ، فلم یکن أبو بکر فی جیش أُسامة ، وإنّما قد قیل : إنه کان فیه عمر ، وقد تواتر عن النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم انه استخلف أبا بکر علی الصلاة حتّی مات ، وصلّی بهم أبو بکر الصبح یوم موته ; ویوم کشف الحجرة فرآهم صفوفاً خلف أبی بکر فسرّ بذلک ; فکیف یکون مع هذا قد أمره أن یخرج فی جیش أُسامة . (444) انتهی .

The second is that this is a lie by the consensus of the scholars of transmission, so Abu Bakr was not in Osama's troop, but it has been said that Umar was in it. It has been reliably reported (mutawatir) from the Prophet (peace be upon him [and his holy progeny]) that he appointed Abu Bakr as his successor for prayer until he died, and Abu Bakr led them in the Fajr prayer on the day of his death. On the day the room was uncovered, he saw them lined up in rows behind Abu Bakr and was pleased with that. How, then, could it be that he had, with all this, commanded him to go out in Osama's troop?" (444) End.

footnote.p: (444) [A and B] Ma'ateb (Critiques) of Abu Bakr, the last book of Minhaj al-Rabi. [B] Minhaj al-Sunnah 4/220 (Cairo edition 1322). [Minhaj al-Sunnah 8/292-293].

para.p: أقول : انظر إلی هذا الجهل المفرط ، وقلّة الحیاء ، وشدة الوقاحة ، وصفاقة الوجه ، ومجانبة الدیانة ، و ترک الأمانة ! کیف کذّب أمراً واضحاً ، وأنکر نهاراً ساطعاً ؟ !

I say: Look at this excessive ignorance, lack of shame, and extreme impudence, and blatant face, and divergence from piety, and abandonment of trust! How could he deny something so clear and reject it in broad daylight?!

لیت شعری کیف یخرج الواقدی ، وابن اسحاق ، وابن سعد ، وابن الجوزی . . وغیرهم من الجمّ الغفیر والجمع الکثیر من العلماء ویدخلهم فی السفهاء والجهلاء ، حتّی یصح دعواه الکاذبة الفاجرة من إجماع العلماء علی کذب هذه القصة المشهورة المتواترة الظاهرة .

I wish I knew how al-Waqidi, Ibn Ishaq, Ibn Sa'd, Ibn al-Jawzi... and others from the vast multitude and large gathering of scholars could emerge and be counted among the foolish and ignorant, while he claims, unjustly, that they are in consensus, so that his false, scandalous claim of an agreement among scholars on the falsehood of this well-known, widely reported, and apparent story might be validated.
ثم العجب من استدلاله علی کذبها بادعاء استخلاف الرسول – علیه [ وآله ] الصلاة – أبا بکر علی الصلاة ، فإن الشیعة تنکر ذلک الاستخلاف وتستنکف من إثباته أشدّ الاستنکاف .

Then the wonder is at his use of evidence for its falsehood by claiming that the Messenger – peace be upon him and his purified progeny – appointed Abu Bakr as his successor in prayer, for the Shia deny this appointment and recoil from confirming it with the utmost reluctance.

ولمّا ثبت بروایات ثقاتهم وتنصیصات أثباتهم : أن أبا بکر کان مأموراً بالرواح مع جیش أُسامة ، بطلت قضیة الاستخلاف والإمامة ; لأن ابن تیمیة مصرّح بالتنافی بین الأمرین ، فإذا ثبت أحدهما امتنع الآخر لاستحالة اجتماع المتنافیین .

And when it has been established through the narrations of their trustworthy sources and the explicit statements of their reliable ones that Abu Bakr was commanded to proceed with the burial of Osama's mother, the case of succession and imamate is rendered invalid; because Ibn Taymiyyah clearly states the incompatibility between the two matters. Thus, if one is established, the other is impossible due to the impossibility of two contradictions existing simultaneously.

As for what he said: "On the night of Thursday, the illness of that Noble one, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, intensified, and for this reason, he faced imminent demise. At the time of the evening prayer on that Thursday night, the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) appointed Abu Bakr as the leader of the prayer and assigned him this duty."
Thus, it is rejected for two reasons:

First: That the observer may think from his words that those narrating the story of Osama mentioned the incident of the Prophet Muhammad's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) appointing Abu Bakr as the leader of prayer (Imam) within that narrative; whereas this is contrary to reality, as was clarified by the statement in "Rawdat al-Ahbab" (445). Rather, the narrators of Osama's story narrated it separately, and the hadith of Abu Bakr's leadership of prayer separately.

footnote.p: (445) Refer to Rawdat al-Ahbab, pages: 165 - 166.

para.p: Second: That from this statement, it is understood that from the night of Thursday, which he believed was when the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) appointed Abu Bakr as the caliph for prayer, the date was the twenty-ninth of Safar, and that he remained alive until the day of Monday, the twelfth of Rabi al-Awwal. From the twenty-ninth of Safar to the twelfth of Rabi al-Awwal is thirteen days, whereas it is mentioned in "Rawdat al-Ahbab":

"And when the time for prayer came, Bilal announced it to that Presence (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), until he (the Prophet) came out and prayed with the people, and in the last three days of illness, he was unable to come, and there is a narration that he could not be present for seventeen prayers in congregation outside" (446).

footnote.p: (446) Rawdat al-Ahbab, pages: 170 - 171.

para.p: Also, in "Rawdat al-Ahbab," the hadith of prayer does not specify the mentioned day (447).

footnote.p: (447) In [A], it mistakenly states (is) instead of (is not).

para.p: And according to the scholars of the Shia, this strong emphasis and threat of warning against those who hesitate, the designated ones of Osama's army <59>, was related to their departure after the incident of the prayer (448), as mentioned in a lengthy hadith in "Jila' al-Oyoon":

footnote.p: (448) [A and B] The author, the scholar, alluded to this to indicate that what the opponents claim, namely, that the Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) command to Abu Bakr to lead the prayer was abrogating his command (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) for him to proceed with Osama's army, is refuted; for even if one were to concede that the command issued from him (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) concerning leading the prayer took place, it would still be of no benefit; because the emphasis on proceeding had been issued by him (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) after the incident of the prayer. How then could the earlier one be abrogating the later?! (12). To its writer.

para.p: When he went to Aisha's house, the illness of that Imam (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) worsened considerably. Then Bilal came at the time of the morning prayer, and at that moment, the Imam was focused on the World of Sanctity. When Bilal called out for the prayer and the Imam did not become aware, Aisha said: "Tell Abu Bakr to pray with the people," and Hafsa said: "Tell Umar to pray with the people"; [the Imam] (449), when he heard their voices and understood their [malicious] intent (450), said: "Refrain from such statements, for you are acting like women who wanted to lead Joseph astray." And since the Imam had ordered that Abu Bakr and Umar go out with Osama's army, at that moment, upon hearing the words of Aisha and Hafsa, he realized that they had returned to Medina for the sake of instigation and corruption, and he became very saddened. With that severity of illness, he stood up, fearing that Abu Bakr and Umar would pray with the people, and this could lead to a doubt will be cast over the people, he placed his hand on the shoulder of the Commander of the Faithful (Amir al-Momineen) (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and Fazl ibn Abbas, with utmost weakness and inability, dragging his feet on the ground until he came to the mosque. When he reached near the mihrab, he saw that Abu Bakr had taken the lead, standing in the mihrab in place of that Blessed One, and had begun the prayer. Then he gestured with his holy hand and said, "Then stand firm!" and he himself entered the mihrab, sat down, and performed the prayer in congregation with the people. He resumed the prayer and disregarded what Abu Bakr had done. And when he completed the salutation of the prayer, he returned home and summoned Abu Bakr, Umar, and a group of Muslims, and said: "Did I not tell you to go out with the army of Osama?!" They replied, "Yes, O Messenger of Allah!" (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) You said so.

footnote.p: (449) The addition is from the source.
(450) The addition is from the source.

para.p: He said, "Then why did you not obey my command?!" Abu Bakr said, "I went out and returned to renew your covenant."
And Umar said, "O Messenger of Allah!" (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) "I went out and returned because I did not want to inquire about your illness from others."

Then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) said, "Send out the army of Osama and go out with the army of Osama. May God curse anyone who disobeys the army of Osama." He said this three times and fainted from the exhaustion of going to the mosque and from the sadness and grief that afflicted that Noble One (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) due to what he observed of the unbecoming behaviors of the hypocrites and understood from their corrupt intentions; and the Muslims wept abundantly, and the sound of lamentation and crying rose up from [the women and] (451) the children of that Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny). (452) It concluded.

footnote.p: (451) The addition is from the source.
(452) [A] Chapter four of the first book regarding the Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) bequest. [Jala' al-Uyoon: 61]

para.p: However, what is stated: This is what is found in "Rawdat al-Safa," "Rawdat al-Ahbab," "Habib al-Siyar," and other reliable histories of both Shia and the Ahle Tasannun.

Thus, it is pure falsehood and absolute slander, and it is never mentioned in any book of Shia historical texts that the noble Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) appointed Abu Bakr for the leadership of prayer, as the one addressed in this story is mentioned.

It is quite astonishing that the one addressed, with all this boasting and exaggeration, mentions such clear fabrications and disgraceful lies, showing no shame at the affront and taking no account of being held to account, and still, with utmost audacity, attributes to the esteemed scholars – according to the saying: a person measures others by themselves – slander and falsehood in rightful claims!

However, what is said: But (453) he requested that Osama <60> give protection to Umar ibn al-Khattab so that he could stay with him and share in the protection of Medina, investigation, and consultation.

footnote.p: (453) In [A], it mistakenly states: (Famma).

para.p: It is therefore implied that: Osama was not commanded and authorized to grant permission for every person to return or withdraw as he pleased, but his leadership was confined to those who had been designated for the battle against the Romans by the command of the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), to be under his approval and judgment in the matters of travel and warfare, and to neither preference nor elevate their own understanding of what was right and proper over his discernment of what was correct (454), not that it would be permissible for anyone he permitted to withdraw to oppose the command of the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and deviate from the companionship of Osama.

footnote.p: (454) 1- The part: (what was right and proper) has been noted in the margin [a] as a correction.

para.p: However, what is said: if it is in the second manner, namely, to deviate from the companionship of Osama, then this point of criticism against Abu Bakr in this matter is explicitly stated and clarified in the words of the scholars of Shia.

As for what is mentioned: that the leader of the time, whenever he designates a person in an army, can still assign that person to a duty among his own duties, it clearly indicates that this person was regarded as one of the designated individuals whose situation is suspended and excepted, and his command has been abrogated, and here the same principle is applicable.

It is therefore countered by stating that: the second command only supersedes the first command when both matters are equal in the strength and weakness of the narration, and in realization and affirmation, they are incompatible and contradictory; and here, both matters are absent.
However, the first matter – that is, the lack of equality in strength and weakness – is supported in several ways:

First: The narration of the Prophet Muhammad's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) commanding Abu Bakr and Umar to be in the presence of Osama is certain and unanimously agreed upon between the two groups; and the narration of the incident where that Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) commanded Abu Bakr to lead the prayer is disputed. It is not hidden from a wise, discerning person that a matter which is unanimously agreed upon between the two groups has a clear advantage over a matter that is disputed.
Second: The first narration is consistent, while the second narration is in a state of utmost confusion and difference.
As for proving the differences and confusion in the narration of Abu Bakr's leadership in prayer, know that al-Bukhari narrated this hadith in his "Sahih" from Aisha with the following words:

لمّا مرض النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم مرضه الذی مات فیه ، فحضرت الصلاة فأذّن ، قال : مروا أبا بکر فلیصلّ بالناس . فقیل : إن أبا بکر رجل أسیف ، إذا قام فی مقامک لم یستطع أن یصلی بالناس . . وأعاد ، فأعادوا له ، فأعاد الثالثة ، فقال : إنکن صواحب یوسف ، مروا أبا بکر فلیصل بالناس . . فخرج أبو بکر مفصلّی ، فوجد النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم من نفسه خفّة ، فخرج یهادی بین رجلین ، کأنّی أنظر إلی رجلیه یخطّان الأرض من الوجع ، فأراد أبو بکر أن یتأخر ، فأومئ الیه النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم : أن مکانک ، ثم أُتی به حتّی جلس إلی جنبه .

"When the Prophet (peace be upon him [and his holy progeny]) fell ill with the illness in which he died, and the time for prayer came, he said: 'Tell Abu Bakr to lead the people in prayer.' It was said: 'But Abu Bakr is a gentle man; when he stands in your place, he will not be able to lead the people in prayer...' And he repeated, and they repeated to him, and he repeated a third time, saying: 'You are like the companions of Joseph. Tell Abu Bakr to lead the people in prayer...' Then Abu Bakr came out, adjusting his clothing, and the Prophet (peace be upon him [and his holy progeny]) felt a little better in himself, so he came out, guided between two men, and it seemed to me that I could see his feet tracing the ground from the pain. Abu Bakr wanted to step back, but the Prophet (peace be upon him [and his holy progeny]) gestured to him: "Your place is here," then he was brought until he sat beside him.
قیل للأعمش : فکان النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم یصلی ، وأبو بکر یصلی بصلاته ، والناس یصلون بصلاة أبی بکر؟
It was said to al-A'mash: Was the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) praying, and Abu Bakr praying with his prayer, while the people were praying with the prayer of Abu Bakr?
فقال برأسه : نعم . رواه أبو داود .
He nodded his head: Yes. Abu Dawood narrated this.
وعن شعبة ، عن الأعمش بعضه ، وزاد معاویة (455) : جلس عن یسار أبی بکر فکان أبو بکر یصلی قائما (456) .
And from Shu'bah, from al-A'mash, part of it, and Mu'awiyah (455) added: He sat to the left of Abu Bakr, and Abu Bakr was praying while standing. (456)

footnote.p: (455) In the source: (Abu Mu'awiya), which is correct.
(456) [A] in the chapter on the limit of a sick person attending the congregation, from the chapters on congregation. (12). [Sahih Bukhari 1 / 162 and see: 1 / 166 and 4 / 122 and 8 / 145].

para.p: Ibn Hajar said in "Fath al-Bari" regarding the explanation of this hadith:
قوله : ( فوجد النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم من نفسه خفّة ) ، ظاهر انه وجد ذلک فی تلک الصلاة بعینها (457) .
His saying: <61> (Then the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) felt a lightness within himself) clearly indicates that he felt this in that very prayer. (457)

footnote.p: (457) [A] That wording was compared to the original of Fath al-Bari in the chapter on the limit of a sick person witnessing [attending] the congregation from the chapters on congregation in two accurate copies. (12). [Fath al-Bari 2 / 129].

para.p: This means that the apparent meaning of this statement indicates that the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) felt a lightness within himself during this very prayer.
His statement: (between two men), in the second narration of the two hadiths of the chapter: that they are Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib and Ali (peace be upon him) (458).

footnote.p: (458) Fath al-Bari 2/130.

para.p: Ibn Hajar also said:
وروایته هذه وصلها البزاز (459) ، قال : حدّثنا أبو موسی محمد بن المثنی ، حدّثنا أبو داود به ، ولفظه : کان رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم المقدم بین یدی أبی بکر .

And this narration was transmitted by al-Bazzaz (459), who said: Abu Musa Muhammad ibn al-Muthanna narrated to us, Abu Dawud narrated to us about it, and his wording was: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was the one leading between the hands of Abu Bakr.

footnote.p: (459) In the source: (Bazzar).

para.p: کذا رواه مختصراً ، وهو موافق لقصة حدیث الباب ، لکن رواه ابن خزیمة فی صحیحه عن محمد بن بشار ، عن أبی داود – بسنده هذا – ، عن عائشة ، قالت : من الناس من یقول : کان أبو بکر المقدّم بین یدی رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فی الصف ، ومنهم من یقول : کان النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم المقدم .

Thus, he narrated it briefly, and it is consistent with the story in the hadith of the chapter, but Ibn Khuzaymah narrated it in his Sahih from Muhammad ibn Bashar, from Abu Dawud – with this chain – from Aisha, who said: Some people say that Abu Bakr was the one leading between the hands of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) in the row, and others say that the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was the one leading.
ورواه مسلم بن إبراهیم (460) عن شعبة بلفظ : إن النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم صلّی خلف أبی بکر .
Muslim ibn Ibrahim (460) narrated it from Shu'bah with the wording: Indeed, the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) prayed behind Abu Bakr.

footnote.p: (460) [A] Khabir's copy: ibn Tamim.

para.p: أخرجه ابن المنذر ، وهذا عکس روایة أبی موسی ، وهو اختلاف شدید .
Ibn al-Mundhir related this, and this is the opposite of the narration of Abu Musa, and it is a serious discrepancy.
ووقع فی روایة مسروق عنها أیضاً اختلاف ، فأخرجه ابن حبان من روایة عاصم ، عن شقیق ، عنه بلفظ : کان أبو بکر یصلی بصلاة رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم [ والناس یصلّون بصلاة أبی بکر ] (461) .

There was also a difference in the narration of Masruq from her, so Ibn Habban from the narration of Asim, from Shaqiq, narrating from him with the words: Abu Bakr was praying with the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) [while the people were praying with the prayer of Abu Bakr] (461).

footnote.p: (461) The addition is from the source.

para.p: وأخرجه الترمذی ، والنسائی ، وابن خزیمة ، من روایة شعبة ، عن نعیم بن أبی بکر ، عن زید ، عن شقیق بلفظ : إن النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم صلّی خلف أبی بکر .

And al-Tirmidhi, al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Khuzaymah narrated it from the narration of Shu'bah, from Nu'aim ibn Abi Bakr, from Zayd, from Shaqiq, with the words: Indeed, the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) prayed behind Abu Bakr.
و ظاهر روایة محمد بن بشار : إن عائشة لم تشاهد الهیئة المذکورة ، لکن تظافرت الروایات عنها بالجزم ، بما یدل [ علی ] (462) أن النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم کان هو الإمام فی تلک الصلاة :

And it appears from the narration of Muhammad ibn Bashar: that Aisha did not witness the aforementioned situation, but the reports from her have corroborated with certainty, indicating (462) that the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was the imam in that prayer:

footnote.p: (462) The addition is from the source.

para.p: منها : روایة موسی بن أبی عائشة التی أشرنا إلیها ، ففیها : فجعل أبو بکر یصلی بصلاة النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم والناس بصلاة أبی بکر . . وهذه روایة زائدة بن قدامة عن موسی .

Among them is the narration of Musa ibn Abi Aisha that we referred to, which states: So Abu Bakr began to pray with the prayer of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and the people with the prayer of Abu Bakr. . And this is the narration of Zayd ibn Qudamah from Musa.
وخالفه شعبة أیضاً ، فرواه عن موسی بلفظ : إن أبا بکر صلّی بالناس ، ورسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فی الصف خلفه .

And Shu'bah also contradicted him, narrating from Musa with the words: Indeed, Abu Bakr prayed with the people, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was in the row behind him.
فمن العلماء من سلک الترجیح ، فقدّم الروایة التی فیها : إن أبا بکر کان مأموماً للجزم بها ; ولأن أبا معاویة أحفظ فی حدیث الأعمش من غیره .

So some of the scholars took the path of preference, giving precedence to the narration that states: Abu Bakr was being led in prayer, due to its certainty; and because Abu Mu'awiyah was more reliable in the hadith of al-A'mash than others.

ومنهم من [ سلک ] (463) عکس ذلک ، ورجّح أنه کان إماماً ، وتمسک بقول أبی بکر الآتی – فی باب من دخل لیؤمّ الناس – حیث قال : ما کان لابن أبی قحافة أن یتقدم بین یدی رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم (464) .

And among them are those who [followed] (463) the opposite, and they preferred that he was an Imam, clinging to the statement of Abu Bakr to come – in the chapter on those who entered to lead the people in prayer – where he said: It was not appropriate for the son of Abu Qahafa to advance in front of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny. (464)

footnote.p: (463) The addition is from the source.
(464) [B] Fath al-Bari 2/107 (Cairo edition). [Fath al-Bari 2/130-131].

para.p: Nasrullah Kabuli, in “Sawaqe’”, argued for the invalidity of it due to the differences in the Hadith of the (roasted) bird regarding its specification, as he stated in the ways of refuting the argument based on the Hadith of the (roasted) bird:
ولأنه اختلفت الروایات فی الطیر المشوی ، ففی روایة : هو النحام ، وفی روایة : إنه الحباری ، وفی أُخری : إنه الحجل . (465) انتهی .

And because the narrations differ regarding the roasted bird, in one narration, it is said to be the flamingo, in another, it is said to be the bustard, and in yet another, it is said to be the partridge. (465) End.

footnote.p: (465) Sawaqe', page 246-247.

para.p: Thus, according to these Hadiths, the Imamate of Abu Bakr, which Ibn Hajar explicitly stated has a severe disagreement, may also be invalid.
Ibn Hajar also stated in "Fath al-Bari" while explaining Sahih Bukhari:
قوله : ( هو علی بن أبی طالب [ ( علیه السلام ) ] ) ، زاد الإسماعیلی من روایة عبد الرزاق عن معمر : و لکن عائشة لا تطیب نفساً له بخیر (466) ;
His statement: (It is Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him)), Isma'ili added from the narration of Abd al-Razzaq from Ma'mar: But Aisha's heart does not become at ease with good for him. (466)

footnote.p: (466) [A and B] It is mentioned in "Musnad" Ahmad ibn Hanbal: Ghad hadathana Abdullah, hadathani abi, hadathana Abd al-Razzaq, from Ma'mar, from al-Zuhri; and Ubaydullah [ibn] Abdullah ibn Utbah informed me that Aisha told him, saying: The first thing the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny (Salla Allah 'alayh wa Alihi wa Salam), complained of was in the house of Maymunah, and he sought permission from his wives to be cared for in her house, and they allowed him. She said: So he came out, with his hands [supported] by Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him) and the other hand by another man, and he was dragging his feet [with his feet] on the ground. Ubaydullah said: And he mentioned [this] to Ibn Abbas, who said: Do you know who the [other] man Aisha did not name is? It is Ali (peace be upon him), but Aisha's heart does not find ease with him. [Musnad Ahmad 6/228]. It is also mentioned in the "Musnad" of Ahmad ibn Hanbal: Abdullah narrated to us,my father narrated to me, Abd al-Ali narrated to us, from Ma'mar, from al-Zuhri, from Ubaydullah, from Abdullah, from [Aisha], who said: [When] the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny (Salla Allah 'alayh wa Alihi wa Salam), fell ill in the house of Maymunah, he sought permission from his wives to be cared for in my house, and they permitted him. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, came out leaning on Abbas and another man, and his feet were dragging on the ground. Ubaydullah said: Ibn Abbas said to me: Do you know who that man is? It is Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him), but Aisha's heart does not find ease with him. (12). [Musnad Ahmad 6/34].

para.p: وابن اسحاق فی المغازی ، عن الزهری . . ولکنّها لا تقدر علی أن تذکره بخیر .
And Ibn Ishaq in the Maghazi (Expeditions), from al-Zuhri... But she is unable to mention him except in good.
و لم یقف الکرمانی علی هذه الزیادة ، فعبّر عنها بعبارة شنیعة .
And al-Kurmani did not find this <62> addition, so he expressed it with a vile phrase.

وفی هذا ردّ علی من قطع (467) ، فقال : لا یجوز أن یظنّ ذلک بعائشة ، وردّ علی من زعم أنّها إنّما أبهمت الثانی لکونه لم یتعین فی جمیع المسافة ، إذ کان تارة یتکی علی الفضل ، وتارة علی أُسامة ، وتارة علی علی ( علیه السلام ) ، وفی جمیع ذلک الرجل الآخر هو العباس ، واختص بذلک إکراماً له ; وهذا توهم ممّن قاله ، والواقع خلافه ، لأن ابن عباس – فی جمیع الروایات الصحیحة – جازم بأن المبهم علی ( علیه السلام ) ، فهو المعتمد .

And in this is a refutation of those who severed (467), saying: It is not permissible to think that with Aisha, and he responded to those who claim that she only obscured the second because he had not become definite in all the distances, as he would sometimes lean on Fadl, and sometimes on Osama, and sometimes on Ali (peace be upon him), and in all of this, the other man was Abbas, and he was specifically distinguished by this in honor of him; and this is a misconception of those who said it, while the reality is contrary, because Ibn Abbas – in all the authentic narrations – was adamant that the one being referred to was Ali (peace be upon him), and he is the one relied upon.

footnote.p: (467) [B] Fatḥ al-Bari 2 / 107. [Fatḥ al-Bari 2 / 131-132].

para.p: ودعوی وجود العباس فی کل مرة ، والذی یتبدل غیره ، مردودة ، بدلیل روایة عاصم – التی تقدمت الاشارة إلیها – . . وغیرها صریح فی أن العباس لم یکن فی مرة ولا مرتین منها ، والله أعلم (468) .

And the claim of Abbas's presence each time, with the one who changes being someone else, is refuted by the evidence of the narration of Asim – which was previously mentioned – … and others that clearly state that Abbas was not present in one or two of those instances, and Allah knows best (468).

footnote.p: (468) [B] Fatḥ al-Bari 2 / 107. [Fatḥ al-Bari 2 / 131-132].

para.p: It means that Ibn Abbas said: That other man whom Aisha did not name was Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him).

And an Isma'ili added the following phrase to the narration of Abdul Razzaq from Mu'mar: "But Aisha herself is not pleased to mention him favorably in relation to Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him)."
And Ibn Ishaq stated in his book "Maghazi" from Zuhri: "But Aisha is unable to mention him in a good light."
And al-Kermani did not realize the additional detail that exists in these narrations, so he described it with a contemptible expression.

And in this excess, there is a refutation of anyone who claims to have severed ties, stating that it is not permissible for one to assume that this meaning could be attributed to Aisha, namely, displeasure at the mention of the exalted status of the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him and his holy progeny).

And it is a rebuttal to anyone who presumed that Aisha ambiguously mentioned another man because no one particular person was identifiable throughout the entire distance from the house to the mosque; this is because that noble one (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) would sometimes lean on Fadl, sometimes on Osama, and at other times on Ali (peace be upon him and his holy progeny).

However, this interpretation is contrary; because Ibn Abbas is categorical in all authentic narrations, asserting that the ambiguous reference in Aisha's statement is to Ali (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), so this is to be regarded as reliable.

And the claim that Abbas was present at every instance, and that those who were changing were not him, is refuted by the narration of Asim – to which an allusion has been made earlier – and others that are explicit in this meaning, that Abbas was neither in one instance nor in two instances. Thus ends the summary of the translation.

And if Aisha's animosity toward the Commander of the Faithful, Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), was such that she would not bring the blessed name of that noble one to her lips, and her wicked soul could not find satisfaction in the mention of the good of that holy figure (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and she lacked the power to recall that noble one with kindness, then the narrations (469) that the narrators of Ahle Tasannun report from Aisha on this matter are significant, it may have been narrated that the virtue of his father was mentioned, and in those narrations, there is also severe differences and contradictions; how can those narrations be deemed valid for arguments against the Shiites?!

footnote.p: (469) The last two lines appear to be incomplete in the [B].

para.p: Third: That his statement, may peace be upon him and his holy progeny, regarding Abu Bakr following Osama was in a state of correctness, while his command to lead the prayer – assuming submission – was in a time of severe illnesss, as mentioned in the “Rawdat al-Ahbab”:

One narration states that Aisha al-Siddiqah said: When the illness of the Prophet of God, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, became severe, the companions were in the mosque waiting for that master, ready for a prayer of repose. He asked, "Did the people pray?" I replied, "No, O Messenger of God!" They are waiting for you. He said, "Prepare some water for me in a washbasin." We did so, and he poured it over himself and washed his body, then tried to get up but fainted. After some time, he came to himself and said, "Did the people pray?" I said, "No, O Messenger of God! They are waiting for you." He said, "Prepare some water for me in a washbasin." We did so, and he poured the water over himself and washed his body again, then wanted to rise, but fainted once more. This occurred three times, and each time he regained consciousness, he would ask, "Did the people pray?" I would reply, "No, they are waiting for you." In the third instance, he sent someone to Abu Bakr, saying to pray with the people. The messenger of that venerable one went and conveyed the message to Abu Bakr. Abu Bakr was a man of tender heart, and he said, "O Umar! You pray with the people." Umar said to him, "You are more deserving of this matter than I." Then Abu Bakr prayed with the people; and after that, the Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) experienced a faintness from illness. The next day, Abu Bakr was leading the people in the previous prayer while that Master (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) came out between two men, one of whom was Abbas, and he said to them: "Place me on the side of Abu Bakr." They did so. When Abu Bakr realized that the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) had come, he wanted to step back, but the Prophet gestured that he should remain in his place. That Master sat and prayed, with Abu Bakr as his follower, and the people were followers of Abu Bakr, meaning they were aware of the actions and movements of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) through his (Abu Bakr's) Takbirs (Allahu Akbar) over the Prophet's actions and transitions. (470) End.

footnote.p: (470) Rawdat al-Ahbab, pages: 170 - 171.

para.p: And this narration is mentioned in "Mishkat" with slight changes from Bukhari and Muslim. (471)

footnote.p: (471) [A] Third Chapter, Section on the Obligations of the Commanded to Follow and the Ruling of the Latecomer from the Book of Prayer. (12). [B] Mishkat 1 / 361 (Damascus edition, 1380 AH). [Mishkat al-Masabih 1 3 / 1682].

para.p: And Umar’s statement: (Indeed, the pain has overwhelmed the man) and similar remarks indicate a difference in the state of health and the overwhelming illness of the Prophet of God!! As will be discussed in the refutations of Umar.

Fourth: The command of the Noble Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) to obey Osama was in direct confrontation and face-to-face. Furthermore, the command of that Noble Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) to Abu Bakr to lead the prayer – even if one were to assume submission – was through a person of unknown status.

Fifth: That if the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and his holy progeny (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), commanded Abu Bakr to lead the prayer, why did Abu Bakr oppose his command and tell Umar that: "You pray with the people!"

Sixth: That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and his holy progeny (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), had not appointed anyone for leadership in prayer, as mentioned in "Rawdat al-Ahbab":

One narration is that when the muezzin of that Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, announced the time for the afternoon prayer, Abdullah ibn Zam'ah was in the presence of that master. He said to him: "Tell the people to pray." Abdullah ibn Zam'ah came out and met Umar, saying: "Pray with the people." Umar advanced and prayed, reciting aloud. The Master of the Worlds, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, heard Umar’s voice of recitation from his chamber and said: "Is this the voice of Umar?!" They said: "Yes." He replied: "Allah and the believers refuse that." He then emerged from the window of his house and said: "No, no, Abu Bakr must pray with the people." Umar then turned away and said to Abdullah ibn Zam'ah: "Didn’t the Prophet tell you that [Umar] (472) should pray with the people?!" He replied: "He had not appointed anyone, but when I did not see Abu Bakr among the companions, I thought to tell you to pray, as to me, no one among the present was more qualified than you." Umar said: "I did not know it was like this, otherwise I would not have become the imam of the people." (473) End.

footnote.p: (472) The addition is from the source.
(473) Rawdat al-Ahbab, page: 171.

para.p: And in "Isti'ab," the translation of Abu Bakr, this narration is mentioned with the following wording:

و روی الزهری، عن عبد الملک بن أبی بکر بن عبد الرحمن بن امیة ، عن أبیه ، عن عبد الله بن زمعة بن الأسود ، قال : کنت عند رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم وهو علیل ، فدعاه بلال إلی الصلاة ، فقال لنا : مروا من یصلی بالناس ، فقال : فخرجت فإذا عمر فی الناس ، وکان أبو بکر غائباً ، فقلت : قم یا عمر ! فصلّ بالناس . فقام عمر ، فلمّا کبّر ، سمع رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم صوته – وکان مجهراً – فقال رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم : فأین أبو بکر ؟ یأبی الله ذلک والمسلمون ، فبعث إلی أبی بکر ، فجاء بعد أن صلّی عمر تلک الصلاة ، فصلّی بالناس طول علّته حتّی قبض رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم (474) .

And Al-Zuhri narrated, from Abd al-Malik ibn Abi Bakr ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Umayyah, from his father, from Abdullah ibn Zam'ah ibn al-Aswad, who said: I was with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) while he was ailing, and Bilal called him to prayer. He said to us: "Tell someone to pray with the people." Then I went out, and I saw Umar among the people, and Abu Bakr was absent. I said: "Stand up, Umar! Pray with the people." Umar stood up, and when he began to pray, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) heard his voice – and he was raising it clearly – so the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) said: "Where is Abu Bakr? Allah forbids this, as do the Muslims." Then he sent for Abu Bakr, and he came after Umar had prayed that prayer, and he prayed with the people for the remainder of his illness until the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) passed away (474).

The point of using this narration as evidence is that: This narration contradicts and opposes the narrations whose implication is the designation of Abu Bakr from the very first instance; and whenever the designation of Abu Bakr from the very first instance is rendered void by the implication of this hadith, it follows that the narrators of the narrations designating Abu Bakr from the very first instance must have fabricated it themselves, just as Abdullah ibn Zam'ah in this narration designated Umar on his own.

Seventh: The one conveying the command of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) for the leadership (imamate) of Abu Bakr is Aisha, and Aisha is suspected of seeking to benefit her father. Therefore, arguing based on the statement of Aisha to prove the leadership (Imamate) of Abu Bakr, it is sufficient to mention that a fox was asked: "Who is your witness?" It replied, "My tail."

And the Ahle Tasannun do not accept the testimony of Imam Hasan (peace be upon him) and Imam Husain (peace be upon him) – despite the clear testimony of the Glorious Word (Qur'an) regarding their purity – in the matter of Fadak for Lady Fatimah al-Zahra (peace be upon her). They say, "The testimony of branches (furu') is not acceptable for the roots (usul)!" Then how can the testimony of A'isha in the matter of Abu Bakr be accepted?! Especially when A'isha's animosity towards the Commander of the Faithful, Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him), was such that she disliked mentioning his name, as was evident from the words of Ibn Hajar.

However, the non-occurrence of contradiction and conflict between both matters can be explained as follows: The ultimate purpose of the command to obey Osama was to be present and participating during the struggle and battle; and the ultimate purpose of the command regarding the leadership (Imamate) of prayer – after submitting to it – was to perform the prayer while present, not to establish it indefinitely. Thus, the command to lead the prayer (Imamate) is not contradictory or opposed to the command to obey Osama; because after completing the prayer while present, there would be no hindrance to joining Osama in his need to relieve himself and accompanying him, just as Sayyid Murtaza Alam al-Huda said:
ما المانع من أن یولّیه تلک الصلاة – إن کان ولاّه إیّاها – ثم یأمره بالنفوذ من بعد مع الجیش ، فإن الأمر بالصلاة فی تلک الحال لایقتضی أمره بها علی التابید (475) .

"What prevents him from appointing him to that prayer – if he appointed him to it – and then commanding him to proceed afterwards with the need to relieve himself? For the command to pray in that situation does not imply his command to it as a permanent obligation" (475).

footnote.p: (475) [B] Ibn Abi al-Hadid 17/179, quoted from al-Shafi. [al-Shafi 4/149].

para.p: And Ibn Abi al-Hadid, a Mu'tazili, appreciated this response of Sayyid Murtaza (may Allah have mercy on him), as he said:
و اما قوله: یجوز أن یکون أمره بصلاة واحدة أو صلاتین ، ثم أمره بالنفوذ بعد ذلک . . فهذا لعمری جائز (476).
"And as for his statement: 'It is possible that his command was concerning one or two prayers, and then he commanded him to proceed after that...' Then this, by my life, is indeed possible (476)."

footnote.p: (476) [B] Ibn Abi al-Hadid 17 / 184 (Cairo edition 1963).

para.p: And even if we assume that the command to lead prayers (Imamah) was abrogating the command to proceed, it will entail the abrogation of something before its occurrence, and this idea is invalid.

Moreover, this command was not from that Noble One (the Prophet), but rather from the side of 'A'ishah, as the Shi'ah narrate through the tradition of the Ahl al-Bayt (peace be upon them) of that Noble One. And even if it were from that Noble One (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), it would be abrogated by the command to proceed.

However, what Shaykh Abd al-Haqq Dehalwi said: "If this were an abrogating command, as the Shi'ah suppose, it would have been abrogated by a statement," is refuted by the fact that just as the statement of that Noble One can be abrogated, so too can the action of that Noble One (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) be abrogated, without any difference in this, as is explicitly stated in Ibn Hujjab's "Mukhtasar al-Usool" and Mulla Sad al-Din's "Talwih" (477). The distinction between the statement and action of that Noble One is sheer arbitrary insistence (tahakkum), rather, some have said: "Action is more eloquent than speech."

footnote.p: (477) Refer to the explanation in "Sharh Mukhtasar Muntahi al-USul" 3 / 208.

para.p: But what he said: the beginning of jihad is an obligation of sufficiency (fard bil-kifaayah) . . . and so on.

Then the answer is that whenever the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) commanded and appointed Abu Bakr to go to war in obedience to Osama, it became an individual obligation (fard 'ayn) for Abu Bakr to go to war in obedience to Osama.

And it appears from his statement that a jihad for defense is not an obligation of sufficiency (fard bil-kifaayah), rather it is an individual duty (waajib 'ayn); whereas jihad in defense is also an obligation of sufficiency (waajib kafaayii), not an individual duty.
But what he said: repelling the fitnah of the disbelievers and apostates from Medina is an individual obligation (fard 'ayn) … and so on.

Then the answer is that this meaning applies to those for whom it was an individual obligation (fard 'ayn) – in the case of being able and capable – that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not command them to act in obedience to Osama, but rather saw it as beneficial for them to remain in Medina, not for Abu Bakr and Umar who he included in Osama's army and, despite the severity of the illness, repeatedly emphasized the enforcement and sending them out.

And yet, if protecting Medina from the evil of the Arabs was an individual obligation (waajib 'ayn), and for that reason it was permissible for Abu Bakr to not go himself with Osama's army, and to explicitly oppose the command of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), then the failure to enforce Osama's army directly would also be permissible for the same reason, whereas he himself is reported to have said that Abu Bakr – in response to those who said: it is not appropriate to raise this army – said that: If it is due to the sending of Osama's army, I know that I will become prey to wild beasts in Medina, I cannot act contrary to the command of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny). (478) End.

footnote.p: (478) Tohfat al-Ithna-'Ashariyya: 265.

para.p: And it is evident that whenever the people of Medina would become prey to wild beasts afterward, the turn would eventually come to Abu Bakr, at the very least, that after that, it would necessarily happen that the people of Medina and the sanctuary of the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) would become prey to wild beasts. Nevertheless, it was also of utmost importance for Abu Bakr to protect his own life! Especially considering that, by his cause – in the opinion of Ahle Tasannun – the promotion of religion and the establishment of the signs of the clear Sharia in the most complete and best manner would become possible. And if Abu Bakr, despite all these dangers, could not justifiably refrain from joining the army, how could it be permissible for him to deviate from joining the army?!

However, what is said: it is specific, as long as the entire army was engaged in equipping and urging Abu Bakr, the reward for all this would return to Abu Bakr, and that obligation of sufficiency would also be established in his record of deeds.

This is countered by the fact that: in this case, there should be a person who (479) intentionally neglects the prayers and urges others to perform the prayers, contrary to the way of the Sharia. The reward for all these worshippers would return to that neglectful person and be established in his record of deeds, and he would not be held accountable at all! And since that is not the case, it is not so.

footnote.p: (479) In [A], there was mistakenly (that a person) which has been corrected.

para.p: But what has been said is this: Second, the determination of specific individuals for jihad (holy struggle) in a certain capacity and alongside an emir (commander) is a matter of civil policy, which is entrusted to the judgment of the current leader, not an ordinance decreed from God… and so on to the end.

Therefore, it is prohibited, and the claimant is required to provide evidence and reasoning for this claim, and the origin of this doubt lies with Qazi al-Qozat (Ibn Khallikan), the author of "Mughni," and this is his wording:

إن الرسول صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم إنّما یأمر بما یتعلق بمصالح الدنیا من الحروب وغیرها عن اجتهاده ، ولیس بواجب أن یکون ذلک من وحی کما یجب فی الأحکام الشرعیة ، وإن اجتهاده یجوز أن یخالف بعد وفاته وإن لم یجز فی حیاته ; لأن اجتهاده فی الحیاة أولی من اجتهاد غیره (480) .

The Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy family) only commands matters related to worldly interests, such as wars and others, based on his own juridical reasoning (ijtihad). It is not necessary that these matters be based on revelation, as is required in religious rulings. Furthermore, his ijtihad may be opposed after his passing, even though it was not permissible during his lifetime, because his ijtihad in life takes precedence over that of anyone else. (480)

footnote.p: (480) [B] al-Shafi: 246 (first edition, 1301). [In the book al-Mughni 20 / vol. 1 / 346 (Cairo edition), the same point is mentioned with different wording].

para.p: And this statement of Qazi al-Qozat (Ibn Khallikan) is refuted by the fact that: Ijtihad (independent juristic reasoning) was never permissible regarding the Noble Prophet of Allah, Muhammad (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), in any ruling, so it would not be permissible to oppose a ruling from the laws of the Respected Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny).
As Fakhr al-Din Razi stated in his commentary on Surah Yunus:
قوله تعالی : ( إِنْ أَتَّبِعُ إلاّ ما یُوحی إِلَیَّ ) (481) معناه : لا أتبع إلاّ ما یوحی إلی ، فهذا یدلّ علی أنه ما حکم إلاّ بالوحی ، وهذا یدلّ أن (482) لم یحکم قطّ بالاجتهاد (483) .

His statement, the Exalted, said: (I follow not except what is revealed to me) (481) means: I do not follow except what is revealed to me, and this indicates that he judged only by revelation, and this indicates that (482) he never judged by ijtihad. (483)

footnote.p: (481) Surah Yunus (10): 15.
(482) In the source: (that he).
(483) [A] Commentary on the verse: (When Our clear verses are recited to them...) [Yunus (10): 15] in the second issue. [B] al-Tafsir al-Kabir 17/56.

para.p: And in the commentary on Surah al-An'am, he said:

قوله : ( إِنْ أَتَّبِعُ إلاّ ما یُوحی إِلَیَّ ) (484) ظاهره یدلّ علی أنه لا یعمل الاّ بالوحی ، وهو یدل علی حکمین : الحکم الأول : إن هذا النصّ یدلّ علی أنه لم یکن یحکم من تلقاء نفسه فی شیء من الأحکام ، وإنه ما کان یجتهد ; بل جمیع الأحکام صادرة عن الوحی ، ویتأکّد هذا بقوله تعالی : ( وَما یَنْطِقُ عَنِ الْهَوی * إِنْ هُوَ إلاّ وَحْیٌ یُوحی ) (485) .

His statement: (I follow not except what is revealed to me) (484) appears to indicate that he does not act except by revelation, and this indicates two rulings: The first ruling is that this text indicates he would not judge on his own accord in any of the rulings, and that he would not engage in ijtihad; rather, all rulings were issued by revelation, and this is further confirmed by His statement, the Exalted: (And he does not speak from [his own] inclination. It is not but a revelation revealed). (485)

footnote.p: (484) Surah al-An'am (6): 50.
(485) [A] See part seven after half [of Surah an-Najm (53): 3-4]. [B] al-Tafsir al-Kabir 12/231 (Tehran edition).

para.p: And Waliyullah said in "Izaalat al-Khafa":

In the time of that Noble one (may peace be upon him and his holy progeny), there were those who, in all kinds of knowledge, had their eyes on the beauty of that Noble one (may peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and their ears attuned to his voice (may peace be upon him and his holy progeny). Whatever arose regarding the necessities of struggle (jihad), truce (hudna), and the conclusion of tax (jizyah) (486), and jurisprudential rulings (ahkam fiqhiyah) and ascetic sciences (ulum zuhudiyah), all were inquiring from that Noble one (may peace be upon him and his holy progeny), as if they had just emerged from their mother's womb. Such were the formal (rasmiyah) and experimental (tajribiyah) sciences that they knew before the sending of the Chief of Messengers (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) – upon them be the best of prayers and peace – all had been dissolved in the spheres of descending bounties from the presence of the Master (Lord) of the heavens and the earth (may His greatness be glorified). In every matter, apart from awaiting the ruling of the Honest Informant (Mukhabir Sadiq), it was not their duty. (487) End.

footnote.p: (486) In [A], it mistakenly says: (Juz'iyah).
(487) [A] Note that the first point relates to the jurisprudential rulings (ahkam fiqhiyah) of Umar. (12) [Izaalat al-Khafa 2 / 140].

para.p: And if the allowance of ijtihad (independent juristic reasoning) were also presumed for that Noble one (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), then still, opposing that Noble one would not be permissible, due to the fact that the ijtihad of that Noble one (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), just as it is preferable over the ijtihad of others during the lifetime of that Noble one (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), will also be preferable to the ijtihad of others after the passing of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny).
And it is among the wonders that Abu Hashim al-Jubai criticized this issue – namely, the permissibility of ijtihad:

The opposition of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) – <67> Osama's delay in departure, and Abu Bakr's and Umar’s attempt to retract from his army, is presented as evidence.

And this is a clear indication that, regarding the essence of this issue, this action of Abu Bakr and similar ones are taken as proof, and they use this matter to argue for the validity of Abu Bakr's actions.
Allama Hilli (may Allah have mercy on him) said in his book “Kashf al-Haq wa Nahj al-Sidq”:

قد اعترض أبو هاشم الجبائی فقال : أیجوز أن یخالف النبیّ ( صلی الله علیه وآله وسلم ) فیما یأمر به ؟ ثم أجاب فقال : أمّا ما کان من طریق الوحی فلیس یجوز مخالفته علی وجه من الوجوه ، وأمّا ما کان علی طریق الرأی فسبیله فیه سبیل الأئمة ، لا یجوز أن یخالف فی ذلک حال حیاته ، ویجوز بعد وفاته ، والدلیل علی ذلک : انه أمر أُسامة بن زید أن یخرج بأصحابه فی الوجه الذی بعثهم فیه ، فأقام أُسامة علیه وقال : لم أکن لأسأل عنک الرکب ، ولا کان لأبی بکر استرجاع عمر من جیش أُسامة (488) .

Abu Hashim al-Jubai raised an objection and said: Is it permissible for the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) to be opposed in what he commands? Then he answered, saying: As for what was through Divine Revelation, it is not permissible to oppose him in any way, but as for what was through personal judgment, his situation in this regard is like that of the Imams; it is not permissible to oppose him during his life, but it is permissible after his death. The evidence for this is that he commanded Osama ibn Zayd to set out with his companions on the route he had sent them, and Osama remained firm before him and said: I would not ask about you from the caravan, nor could Abu Bakr retract Umar from the army of Osama. (488)

footnote.p: (488) Nahj al-Sidq: 340. Section: (nor could Abu Bakr retract Umar from the army of Usama), was not found in the source.

para.p: And there is also a hadith indicating the impermissibility of opposing the Noble Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) in political matters, which Mulla Muttaqi mentioned in “Kanz al-Ummal” – under the chapter “Jami al-Jawami” by Suyuti – and this is his wording:

سیف بن عمر ، عن أبی حمزة وأبی عمر . . وغیرهما ، عن الحسن ابن الحسن قال : ضرب رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم بعثاً قبل وفاته علی أهل المدینة ومن حولهم ، وفیهم عمر بن الخطاب ، وأمّر علیهم أُسامة بن زید ، فلم یجاوز آخرهم الخندق حتّی قبض رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم ، فوقف أُسامة بالناس ، ثم قال لعمر : ارجع الی خلیفة رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فاستأذنه یأذن لی ، فأرجع بالناس ، فإن معی وجوه الناس ، فلا آمن علی خلیفة رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم وثقل رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم وأثقال المسلمین أن یتخطفهم المشرکون .

Saif ibn Umar, from Abu Hamza and Abu Umar... and others, from al-Hasan ibn al-Hasan, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) sent a military expedition before his passing to the people of Madinah and those around them, including Umar ibn al-Khattab, and appointed Osama ibn Zayd as their commander. None of them advanced beyond the trench until the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was taken. Osama stood with the people and then said to Umar: "Return to the Successor of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and seek his permission to allow me to proceed, then bring the people back. For I have with me the key figures of the community, and I do not feel secure for the Successor of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and the weight of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and the burdens of the Muslims, that they might be seized by the polytheists."

وقالت الأنصار : فإن أبی إلا أن نمضی فأبلغه عنّا ، واطلب إلیه أن یولّی أمرنا رجلا أقدم سناً من أُسامة ; فخرج عمر بأمر أُسامة فأتی أبا بکر ، فأخبره بما قال أُسامة ، فقال أبو بکر : لو اختطفتنی الکلاب والذئاب لم أردّ قضاء قضاه رسول الله [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله وسلم ) ] ، قال : فإن الأنصار أمرونی أن أبلغک : إنهم یطلبون إلیک أن تولّی أمرهم رجلا أقدم سناً من أُسامة ; فوثب أبو بکر – وکان جالساً – فأخذ بلحیة عمر وقال : ثکلتک أُمّک وعدمتک یابن الخطاب ! استعمله رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم وتأمرنی أن أنزعه ؟ !

The Ansar said: "If he refuses, we must proceed, so convey this to him, and ask him to appoint an older man than Osama to oversee our affairs." So, Umar went with Osama's command and came to Abu Bakr and informed him of what Osama had said. Abu Bakr replied: "Even if dogs and wolves were to seize me, I would not reverse a decree made by the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)." Umar said: "The Ansar have instructed me to inform you that they are asking you to appoint an older man than Osama to oversee their affairs." Then Abu Bakr jumped up – he had been sitting – grabbed Umar’s beard and said: "May your mother mourn you and may you be bereft, O son of al-Khattab! The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) assigned him, and you command me to remove him?!"
فخرج عمر إلی الناس ، فقالوا له : ما صنعت ؟ فقال : امضوا ثکلتکم أُمهاتکم ، ما لقیت من سببکم الیوم من خلیفة رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم . (489) انتهی ما أردنا نقله .

Umar returned to the people and they said to him: "What did you do?" He replied: "Go, may your mothers mourn you! I faced nothing from your actions today regarding the Successor of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)." (489). This concludes what we intended to convey.

footnote.p: (489) [A] Al-Kitab al-Ghazawat, Bi'th Usamah (The Book of Expeditions, the Mission of Usamah) (12). [B] Al-Kitab al-Ghazawat, Bi'th Usamah, Kunzal-A'mal (The Treasure of Actions) 5/314. [Kunzal-A'mal 10/578-579 (printed by Mu'assasat al-Risalah, Beirut).

para.p: And in "Tarikh al-Tabari", this narration is also presented with the following chains of transmission:

حدّثنا عبد الله ، قال : أخبرنی سیف ، وحدّثنی السری ، قال : حدّثنا شعیب ، قال : حدّثنا سیف ، عن أبی ضمرة ، وأبی عمر . . وغیرهم ، عن الحسن بن أبی الحسن البصری ، قال : ضرب رسول الله [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله وسلم ) ] . . إلی آخر الحدیث (490) .

Abdullah said: Abdullah narrated to us, saying: Sayf informed me, and al-Suri narrated to me, saying: Shu'ayb narrated to us, saying: Sayf narrated to us, from Abu Dumrah and Abu Umar… and others, from al-Hasan ibn Abi al-Hasan al-Basri, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)… until the end of the narration. (490)

footnote.p: (490) [B] Tarikh al-Tabari 3/212 (printed in Egypt, 1336 AH). [Tarikh al-Tabari 2/462].

para.p: Thus, if it were permissible for the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) to be opposed in matters of governance after his passing, how could it be permissible for Abu Bakr to rebuke and admonish Umar ibn al-Khattab to such an extent?! And to insult him <68> and say: “( ثکلتک أُمّک )” (May your mother mourn you), and Umar’s beard would bristle – rising from its place – and he would say: "If dogs and wolves were to seize me and destroy me, would I negate and alter the command of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)?"

And the term Judgment (Qadaa) which is indefinite and is situated in the context of negation, implies totality. Therefore, it would not be permissible for Abu Bakr to oppose the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) in any ruling of the sacred message (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and this is the truth.

However, despite all this, Abu Bakr, in the sense of “لِمَ تَقُولُونَ ما لا تَفْعَلُونَ” "(Why) do you say what you do not do?" (491), acted in contradiction to the explicit statement of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and had refrained from the command of Osama, and turned away his companion, and did not think of the warning and curse of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)!

footnote.p: (491) Surah As-Saff (61): 2.

para.p: And from this narration, another benefit is derived, which is that: it is explicitly mentioned in this hadith that Umar was commanding Abu Bakr to depose Osama – whom the Noble Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) had appointed as commander and ruler – and this act is undoubtedly a sin and forbidden, and one of the major destructive sins (kaba'ir mubiqah). Therefore, Abu Bakr, after hearing this statement, was unable to remain calm, became agitated, and resorted to disrespecting and demeaning him.

And during the lifetime of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), whenever people criticized Osama's leadership, the Noble Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) would become angry, admonishing and severely rebuking them.
But what has been said: that when the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) passed away, civil authority fell to Abu Bakr... till the end.

Thus, making the very claim a part of the evidence is to seize the matter at hand, for the attachment of civil authority to Abu Bakr is precisely the claim of the Ahle Tasannun. Therefore, all that has been said in connection with this introduction is rendered null.
However, what has been mentioned: that he can designate whoever he wishes to accompany Osama and keep whoever he wishes with him.

This is refuted by the fact that if Abu Bakr had this complete authority, the permission His request for Osama regarding keeping Umar's life with him was sheer nonsense and an entirely meaningless act, and the status of the Caliph is far more exalted than to engage in trivial and frivolous matters – which are in the power of enticing toward the ugly.
And it is mentioned in "Kanz al-Ummal" that Abu Bakr said:

ولکن أُکلّم أُسامة فی عمر ، یخلفه یقیم عندنا ، فإنه لا غنی بنا عنه ، والله ما أدری یفعل أُسامة أم لا ; والله إن أبی لا أُکرهه (492) . . فعرف القوم أن أبا بکر قد عزم علی إنفاذ بعث أُسامة ، ومشی أبو بکر إلی أُسامة فی بیته ، فکلّمه فی أن یترک عمر ، ففعل أُسامة ، وجعل یقول له : أذنت ونفسک طیبة ؟ فقال أُسامة : نعم . (493) انتهی .

"But I will speak to Osama about Umar, to replace him and stay with us, for we cannot do without him, and by Allah, I do not know if Osama will do it or not; and by Allah, my father will not coerce him." (492) So the people understood that Abu Bakr had resolved to send out Osama's army, and Abu Bakr went to Osama in his house and spoke to him about leaving Umar, and Osama did so, and he kept saying to him: "Have you consented with a good heart?" Abu Bakr replied, "Yes." (493). End

footnote.p: (492) It has mistakenly appeared in [A]: "(And by Allah, my father will not coerce him)" instead of "(And by Allah, my father will not coerce him in this matter)."
(493) [A] In the book "Al-Ghazawat" (The Battles). [B] Kanz al-'Umal 5 / 313. [Kanz al-'Umal 10 / 576 (printed by Mu'assasat al-Risalah, Beirut).

para.p: This statement clearly and unequivocally indicates that Abu Bakr did not see himself as having the choice in returning Umar, otherwise, why would he say that if Osama were to hesitate in leaving Umar, he would not coerce him in this matter? Because this statement clearly indicates that the choice in this matter belonged to Osama, not Abu Bakr.

As for what he said: "It is fitting for the appointed king to keep some of the officials in his presence, as he sees the well-being of the kingdom and the state in this; and in such an extent of discretion, there is no opposition to the first king or rebellion against his command. Opposition would be if he were to appoint another ruler in his place, neglect that important matter, <69> or make peace with the rivals regarding it."

Thus, this is a kind of sophistry; for there is no doubt that this matter constitutes opposition, and one who denies this matter is not worthy of address. And what difference is there between someone preventing the envoy of the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) from carrying out his mission and someone preventing his appointed commander from his rule? Surely, in both cases, opposition to him would be inevitable. However, some fanatics have claimed that opposing the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) after his passing is permissible. They have not restricted this permission to just this opposition but rather assert that in all matters where the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) – God forbid – issued a ruling based on ijtihad, opposition to him in those matters is permissible.
The falsity of this claim is evident in numerous ways, as you already know.
As for what he said: "And the phrase: ‘May God curse the one who lags behind it’ is never found in the books of (the so-called) Ahl al-Sunnah wa al-Jama‘ah." (494)

footnote.p: (494) [A] (Faydah:) The denial by Shah Sahib of the existence of the phrase: "May Allah curse the one who lags behind the army of Usaamah" in the books of Ahle Tasannun.
