para.p: This is proof of ignorance and lack of knowledge, for the mentioned phrase is recorded in the book “Melal wa Nehal” by Shahrastani, who was an Ash‘ari, and in Sharh al-Mawaqif (495), quoting from al-Aamidi (496).

footnote.p: (495) Refer to Sharh al-Mawaqif, 8/376.

(496) [A and B] The original statement of Aamidī appears in the fourth section of the seventh principle, where he discusses the ruling on those who oppose the truth from among the people of the Qibla, in the book Afkaar al-Abkaar, as follows:
And before delving into the verification of the truth and the refutation of falsehood in this matter, it is necessary to point out the different sects of those who have diverged from among the proponents of Islamic doctrines and to highlight the view of each group. Through this, the distinction between disbelief and faith becomes apparent. Thus, we say: The Muslims, at the time of the passing of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family), were united in one creed and one belief – except for those who concealed hypocrisy while outwardly displaying agreement. However, disputes later arose among them regarding matters of ijtihad, the purpose of which was to establish the rulings of the Sharī‘ah and to preserve the principles of the religion; such disputes neither lead to faith nor to disbelief. One such example is their disagreement when the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) said during his final illness: "Bring me an inkwell and parchment so that I may write something for you, after which you will never go astray." At this point, ‘Umar said, "The Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) is overcome by pain; the Book of God is sufficient for us."
And the dispute grew loud over this matter until the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) said: "Leave me, for it is not appropriate to dispute in my presence." Similarly, they differed after that regarding delaying the dispatch of Usaamah's army, despite the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) having said: "Prepare the army of Usaamah; may God curse the one who lags behind it." Yet, some insisted on the necessity of following this command, while others delayed, awaiting what would happen to the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy family) during his illness… till the end of the narration.
[Abkaar al-Afkaar, 373 (manuscript copy), 3/342 (Beirut edition)].
And Aamidi is among the great Imams and esteemed leaders of the Ahle Tasannun, as Yaafi’i mentioned in the historical work Miraat al-Jinaan, in the events of the year 631 AH, where he said:
And in that year passed away the eminent scholar, the jurist, the Usuli, Abu al-Hasan Ali ibn Muhammad, known as Sayf al-Din al-Amidi al-Tha'labi al-Hanbali al-Shafi'i, the author of brilliant compositions, possessing a lofty status, whose works are beneficial and instructive, and which originate from a remarkable intellect… till the end.
[Mir'at al-Jinan, 4/73].
And likewise, Ibrahim ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Mun‘im said in Tarikh Muzafari:
Then came the year 11 AH, in which the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy family) dispatched an army to Sham and appointed Usama ibn Zayd as their commander. He ordered him to advance with cavalry towards the borders of Balqa and Darum. While they were preparing for the journey, the illness of the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy family) began, so they became preoccupied with him. The Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) then said: "Prepare the army of Usama! May God curse the one who lags behind it." A dispute arose among them; some said, "We must obey the words of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) and proceed with the expedition." Others said, "Our hearts do not allow us to leave him while he is ill. We will wait until we see what happens."
Tarikh Muzafari: There is no available information regarding a printed or manuscript version of the book. A description of the book and its author will be mentioned in the third criticism of Uthman.
And Ibrahim bin Abdullah, the author of Tarikh Muzafari, is among the imams of hadith scholars, the trusted jurists, and the reputable historians of the Ahle Tasannun. Taqi Abu Bakr bin Ahmad bin Shiba [Shahba] al-Dimashqi al-Asadi said in Tabaqat Fuqaha Shafi'iyya:
Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin Abd al-Mun‘im bin Ali bin Muhammad, known as Ibn Abi al-Dam, was Qazi Shihab al-Din Abu Ishaq al-Hamdani – with a silent meem – from Hama. He was born in Jumada al-Awwal, 583 AH. He traveled to Baghdad, where he studied fiqh, and he narrated hadith in Cairo and various parts of Sham. He was appointed as the judge of his hometown and was an imam in jurisprudence, a historian, and a poet. His writings reflect his virtue. He passed away in Jumada al-Thani, 642 AH, in Hama. Among his works is Sharh Mushkil al-Wasit.
And it is approximately twice the size of al-Wasit, containing extensive discussions, rare benefits, and unique insights. His work Adab al-Qada is a single volume filled with valuable points. He also authored a book on history concerning Islamic sects.
Al-Zahabi said: "He authored al-Tarikh al-Kabir [al-Muzafari]."
[Tabaqat al-Shafi‘iyyah, 2/99].
And Salah al-Din Khalil bin Aibak al-Safadi said in the history book Wafi bil-Wafayat:
Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin Abd al-Mun‘im bin Ali, Qazi Shahab al-Din Abu Ishaq al-Hamdani al-Hamawi al-Shafi‘i, known as Ibn Abi al-Dam, was the judge of Hama. He was born there in 583 AH, traveled, and studied hadith in Baghdad. He narrated hadith in Hama, Cairo, and Aleppo. He was a poet, writer, and scholar, and he authored several works. He corresponded on behalf of the ruler of Hama. He wrote al-Tarikh al-Kabir al-Muzafari and al-Firaq al-Islamiyyah. He passed away in 642 AH.
[Al-Wafi bil-Wafayat, 6/25].
And it is mentioned in Kashf al-Zunun:
"Al-Tarikh al-Muzafari" by Qazi Shahab al-Din Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin Abi al-Dam al-Hamawi, who passed away in the year 642 AH. It is a historical work specifically focused on the Islamic nation, consisting of approximately six volumes."
[Kashf al-Zunun, 1/305].
And Abd al-Rahman bin Abd al-Rasul bin Qasim said in Mir'at al-Asrar:
"Three days before his passing, the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) commanded Abu Bakr to lead the prayer. And Usama bin Zayd bin Haritha, whom he had previously appointed as a commander, was nominated to lead the campaign to Sham. Two days before his passing, on Saturday, the 10th of Rabi' al-Awwal, despite his illness, the Prophet personally tied the standard for Usama with his blessed hands, prayed for his success, and granted him permission to depart. Usama took the standard and left, setting up camp in Juruf to gather the army. The leading figures of the Muhajirun and Ansar, such as Abu Bakr, Uthman bin Affan, Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, Abu Ubaydah bin al-Jarrah, and others, were ordered to join Usama’s army. However, some people found it difficult and, in a tone of objection, said: 'How can this young man be made a commander over the Muhajirun?' When this statement reached the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family), he became very angry and said: 'Whoever lags behind Usama’s army is cursed.' So the entire group of Companions had no choice but to join Usama. None remained with the Prophet except Banu Hashim and his family; all the Companions were with Usama at Juruf. As they prepared to set out, Usama was about to mount when his mother, Umm Ayman, sent word that the Prophet was in his final moments. Usama returned, and the senior Companions, who had already departed, also turned back upon hearing this news. End.
[Mir'at al-Asrar: No known printed edition or available manuscript].
Al-Baghdadi said in Idah al-Maknun, 2/457:
"Mir'at al-Asrar wa Sawati' al-Anwar is authored by one of the scholars of India, as mentioned by the author of Khazinat al-Asfiya."
And in A'yan al-Shi'a, 2/68-69, within a discussion, it is stated:
"The Sufi mystic, Abd al-Rahman, in Mir'at al-Asrar, is the same source from which Shah Waliullah al-Dehalwi, the father of Shah Abd al-Aziz, the author of Tuhfat al-Ithna 'Ashariyya, and the book Al-Intibah 'ala Ma Qil quoted."
Sayyid al-Mar'ashi also cited it in Sharh Ihqaq al-Haqq, 13/93.
And from the book Mir'at al-Asrar, Shah Waliullah’s father quoted in his treatise Al-Intibah fi Salsil Awliya Allah, stating:
"It is mentioned in Mir'at al-Asrar that Hazrat Ganj Shakar said in Rahat al-Qulub: 'I wanted to bestow the noble prayer mat of the Kingdom of India upon someone else, but a Divine voice called out, saying: Shaykh Nizam al-Din is on his way; wait until he arrives'... and so on."
[Al-Intibah fi Salsil Awliya Allah: No known printed edition or available manuscript].
Al-Baghdadi mentioned it in Idah al-Maknun, 1/129, stating:
"Al-Intibah fi Salsil Awliya Allah is authored by one of the scholars of India."

para.p: And Abu Bakr Johari narrated it, and Mulla Yaqub Lahori, the commentator of “[Sahih] Bukhari,” also explicitly stated in his “Treatise on Beliefs” the mention of a curse (lan‘ah) for contravention of joining the army of Osama, and he is struggling to protect Abu Bakr from cursing (La'n).
And we will not merely suffice with referring to the aforementioned books, but will also quote the original wording of their statements.
So know that in the book "Melal wa Nehal" – among the disputes of the companions – it is mentioned:

الخلاف الثانی فی مرضه ، إنه قال : « جهّزوا جیش أُسامة ، لعن الله من تخلّف عنها » (497) ، فقال قوم : یجب علینا امتثال أمره – وأُسامة قد برز من المدینة – ، وقال قوم : قد اشتدّ مرض النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فلا تسع قلوبنا لمفارقته والحالة هذه ، فنصبر حتّی نبصر أیش (498) یکون من أمره . (499) انتهی .

The second dispute during his illness was that he said: "Prepare the army of Osama! May God curse the one who lags behind it." (497) Some said, "We must obey his command – Osama has already set out from Madinah." Others said, "The Prophet’s illness (peace be upon him and his holy family) has intensified, and our hearts cannot bear to leave him in this state. We will wait and see what (498) happens." (499) End.

footnote.p: (497) In the source: (from him).
(498) In the source: (what).
(499) [A] Page: 11 (printed version German). (12). [B] Milaal wa Nihaal 1 / 20 (Egyptian edition) 1317 and 1 / 11 (German edition). [Milaal wa Nihaal 1 / 23].

para.p: That is, the second dispute was that the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy family) said: "Prepare the army of Osama! May God curse the one who lags behind Osama's army." So, a group said: "It is obligatory upon us to obey the command of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family)." (500) And Osama had already left Madinah by the Prophet’s command. But others said: "The Prophet’s (peace be upon him and his holy family) illness has become severe, and our hearts cannot bear to leave that honorable one, may Allah's blessings be upon him and his holy progeny, in this state, so let us be patient and see how his matter will ultimately unfold.

footnote.p: (500) In [A], it mistakenly says: (to comply).

para.p: And this Muhammad ibn Abd al-Karim ibn Abi Bakr Ahmad al-Shahrastani is one of the greatest scholars and imams of Ahle Tasannun, as mentioned in Ibn Khallikan's "Tareekh":

أبو الفتح محمد بن أبی القاسم عبد الکریم بن أبی بکر أحمد الشهرستانی ، المتکلم علی مذهب الأشعری ، کان إماماً مبرزاً فقیهاً متکلماً ، تفقّه علی أحمد الخوافی – المقدّم ذکره – وعلی أبی النصر القشیری . . وغیرهما ، وبرع فی الفقه ، وقرأ الکلام علی أبی القاسم الأنصاری وتفرّد فیه ، وصنّف کتباً ، منها : کتاب نهایة الاقدام فی علم الکلام ، وکتاب الملل والنحل (501) ، وتلخیص الأقسام لمذاهب الأنام ، وکان کثیر المحفوظ ، حسن المحاورة ، یعظ الناس ، ودخل بغداد سنة عشر وخمس مائة فأقام فیها (502) .

Abu al-Fath Muhammad ibn Abi al-Qasim Abd al-Karim ibn Abi Bakr Ahmad al-Shahrastani, the theologian following the Ash'ari school, was an eminent imam, a jurist, and a theologian. He studied fiqh under Ahmad al-Khawafi – whose mention has preceded – and under Abu al-Nasr al-Qushayri… and others, and he excelled in jurisprudence. He studied theology under Abu al-Qasim al-Ansari and was unique in it, and he authored several books, including: "Nihayat al-Aqdam fi Ilm al-Kalam" (The Ultimate Step in the Science of Theology), and "Kitab al-Melal wa al-Nehal" (Book of Sects and Religions) (501), and "Taalikh al-Aqsam li-Madhahib al-Unam" (Summary of Categories on the Doctrines of the Worthy), and he had a large memory, was good at dialogue, and would admonish the people. He entered Baghdad in the year 510 and stayed there (502).

footnote.p: (501) The source adds: (and al-Manahij wa al-Bayyinaat, and Kitab al-Mazare’ah).
(502) [A] the letter Meem. [B] Wafiyat al-A'yaan 3 / 403 (Cairo edition 1367). [Wafiyat al-A'yaan 4 / 273].

para.p: And it is mentioned in the "Sharh Mawaqif":

قال الآمدی : کان المسلمون عند وفاة النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم علی عقیدة واحدة وطریقة واحدة إلاّ من کان یبطن النفاق ویظهر الوفاق ، ثم نشأ الخلاف فیما بینهم – أولا – فی أُمور اجتهادیة لا توجب کفراً ولا ایماناً ، وکان غرضهم منها إقامة مراسم الدین وإدامة مناهج الشرع القویم ، وذلک کاختلافهم عند قول النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم – فی مرض موته – : « ائتونی بقرطاس أکتب لکم کتاباً لا تضلّوا بعدی » . . حتّی قال عمر : إن النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم قد غلبه (503) الوجع ، حسبنا کتاب الله ! وکثر اللغط فی ذلک حتّی قال النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم : « قوموا عنّی ، لا ینبغی عندی التنازع » .

Al-Amadi said: The Muslims were united in belief and practice at the time of the Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) death, except for those who concealed hypocrisy while outwardly showing agreement. <70> Then, initially, differences arose among them regarding matters of ijtihad that did not necessitate disbelief or faith, and their aim was to establish the ceremony of religion and the continuation of the pathways of the sound Shari'ah, and this was like their differences at the saying of the Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, during his illness of death: "Bring me a parchment so I can write for you a document that you will not go astray after me..." Until Umar said: "The Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, is surely being overcome by (503) pain; the Book of Allah is sufficient for us!" And the clamor increased regarding this until the Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, said: "Leave me alone, it is not appropriate to have disagreements in my presence."

footnote.p: (503) In "Sharh al-Mawaqif": absence (ghaybah).

para.p: وکاختلافهم بعد ذلک فی التخلف عن جیش أُسامة ، فقال قوم : وجب الاتباع لقوله علیه [ وآله ] السلام : « جهزوا جیش أُسامة ، لعن الله من تخلّف عنه » ، وقال قوم بالتخلّف انتظاراً لما یکون من رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فی مرضه . (504) انتهی .

And like their disagreement after that in remaining behind from the expedition of Osama, where some said: "Following his command is obligatory," peace be upon him and his holy progeny, "Prepare for the expedition of Osama, may Allah curse anyone who remains behind him," while others said to remain behind, waiting for what would occur from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, during his illness. (504)

footnote.p: (504) [A] At the end of the book, there is a supplement mentioning the sects alluded to by the prophets. (12). [B] "Sharh Mawaqif" 8 / 377 (printed in Egypt in 1325). [Mawaqif 3 / 649-650, "Sharh Mawaqif" 8 / 376].

para.p: And Mulla Ya'qub Tunbani said at the end of his "Resalah Aqaid" (505) regarding the mention that the Shi'ah criticize the companions: "And they may criticize based on the hadith of Osama regarding the two Shaykhs."

footnote.p: (505) [A and B] This treatise is, thank God, available with me. (12). [Its manuscript has not reached us, and we do not know of its printing; however, Shaikh al-Amini quoted from it in "al-Ghadir" 6 / 72 - in the midst of his statement - and said: "Master Ya'qub al-Lahauri mentioned it in his 'Resalah Aqaid' and discussed its indication of the Imam's superior knowledge and virtue."]

para.p: أمّا الجواب عن حدیث جیش أُسامة ، فهو : إنه لم یکن تخلّف الشیخین عنه تخلفاً یتعلّق به اللعن ; لأن التخلف الذی یتعلق به اللعن (506) هو ما کان بلا ضرورة ; لأن الأُمور الضروریة مستثناة شرعاً وعرفاً ، وقد کان لأبی بکر . . . فی ذلک ضرورة عظیمة وهو أمر النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم إیاه بالإمامة وإقامته مقامه فی الصلاة ، والنبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم لمّا أمره بها علم أن إقامته عنده کانت مرضیة له ، وکیف یصحّ جعل رجل إماماً للمسلمین فی الصلاة بعد ما علم أنه صار مستحقاً للعن علی ما زعموا ؟ ! (507)

As for the answer to the narrative about Osama's army, it is: The fact that the two sheikhs did not attend him was not a failure (takhlif) that would warrant cursing (la'n); because the failure that would warrant cursing (506) is one that occurred without necessity, since necessary matters are, by Divine Law and common understanding, exempt from such cursing. And there was a great necessity (darurah) for Abu Bakr . . . in that situation, namely, the Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) command to him regarding leadership (imamah) and establishing him in his place in prayer (salah). And when the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) commanded him, he knew that his presence there was pleasing (mardiyyah) to him. How could it be correct to appoint a man as an imam of the Muslims in prayer after knowing he had become deserving of cursing (la'n) according to their claim?! (507)

footnote.p: (506) The phrase: "because the failure that would warrant cursing" is noted in the margin of [A] as a correction.
(507) Resalah Aqaid:

para.p: Ibn Abi al-Hadid, al- Mu'tazili, narrated from Abu Bakr al-Jawhari that he reported through his chains of narration:

إن رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم أمر فی مرض موته أُسامة بن زید بن حارثة علی جیش فیه أجلّة المهاجرین والأنصار ، منهم : أبو بکر وعمر وأبو عبیدة بن الجراح وعبد الرحمن بن عوف وطلحة والزبیر ، وأمره أن یغزو (508) علی مؤتة حیث قتل أبوه زید ، وأن یغزو وادی فلسطین ، فتثاقل أُسامة وتثاقل الجیش بتثاقله ، وجعل رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فی مرضه یثقل ویخفّ ، ویؤکّد القول فی تنفیذ ذلک البعث حتّی قال له أُسامة : بأبی أنت وأُمّی أتاذن لی أن أمکث أیاماً حتّی یشفیک الله ؟

That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) commanded, in the illness of his death, Osama ibn Zayd ibn Harithah to lead (jish) in it among a congregation of the foremost (ajal) of the Emigrants (Muhajirin) and the Helpers (Ansar), including: Abu Bakr, Umar, Abu Ubaydah ibn al-Jarrah, Abdul Rahman ibn Awf, Talhah, and Zubayr, and he commanded him to campaign (508) in Mu'tah where his father Zayd was killed, and to campaign in the valley of Palestine. But Osama hesitated, and the urgency of the army became heavy with its heaviness, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, began to grow heavier and lighter in his illness, reaffirming his words about the execution of that expedition until Osama said to him, "May my father and mother be sacrificed for you! Do you permit me to stay for a few days until Allah heals you?"

footnote.p: (508) In the source: "to lead."

para.p: فقال : « اخرج وسر علی برکة الله » .
He replied, "Go out and proceed with the blessing of Allah."
فقال : یا رسول الله ! [ ص ] إن خرجت (509) وأنت علی هذا الحال ، خرجت وفی قلبی قرحة منک .
Osama said, "O Messenger of Allah! peace be upon him and his holy progeny, if I go out (509) while you are in this condition, I will leave with a sorrowful heart."

footnote.p: (509) In [A], there is an error: it states (You went out) instead.

para.p: فقال : « سر علی النصر والعافیة » .
He answered, "Proceed with victory and health."
فقال : یا رسول الله ! [ ص ] إنی أکره أن أسأل عنک الرکبان . .
Osama continued, "O Messenger of Allah! peace be upon him and his holy progeny, I dislike to ask the travelers about you..."
فقال : « أنفذ لما أمرتک به » .
He said, "Fulfill what I commanded you."

ثم أُغمی علی رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم وقام أُسامة فتجهّز للخروج ، فلمّا أفاق رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم سأل عن أُسامة والبعث ، فأُخبر : أنهم یتجهّزون ; فجعل یقول : « أنفذوا بعث أُسامة ، لعن الله من تخلّف عنه » ، ویکرّر ذلک ، فخرج أُسامة واللواء علی رأسه ، والصحابة بین یدیه حتّی إذا کان بالجرف نزل ومعه أبو بکر وعمر وأکثر المهاجرین ، ومن الأنصار : أُسید بن حصیر وبشیر بن سعد . . وغیرهما من الوجوه ، فجاءه رسول أُمّ أیمن یقول له : ادخل فإن رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم یموت .

Then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, fell unconscious, and Osama stood up to prepare for departure. When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, regained consciousness, he asked about Osama and the expedition. He was informed that they were getting ready; so he kept saying, "Send off Osama's expedition. May Allah curse anyone who delays in joining him," and he repeated this. Osama went out with the banner on his head, and the companions were before him until, when they reached al-Jurf, he descended with Abu Bakr and Umar and most of the Muhajirin, and among the Ansar were Usayd ibn Hujayr and Bashir ibn Saad... and others of note. Then a messenger from Umm Ayman came to him, saying: "Enter, for the Messenger of Allah May Allah's peace and blessings be upon him and his holy progeny. Has died.”
فقام من فوره فدخل المدینة واللواء علی رأسه ، فجاء به حتّی رکزه فی باب رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم ، وقد مات فی تلک الساعة .

And he stood up from <71> that very moment and entered the city with the banner on his head, and he came with it until he planted it at the door of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him and his holy progeny, and he had died at that hour.
قال : فما کان أبو بکر وعمر یخاطبان أُسامة – إلی أن ماتا – إلاّ بالأمیر (510) .
He said: So Abu Bakr and Umar were speaking to Osama – until their deaths – only as the Commander (amir). (510)

footnote.p: (510) [A] Volume six in the explanation of his statement: "When the news of the Saqifah reached him" connected to another statement. (12). [B] Ibn Abi al-Hadid's Commentary 6/52 (Cairo ed. 1963).

para.p: And Ibn Abi al-Hadid has said regarding Abu Bakr al-Jawhari:
وأبو بکر الجوهری ، هذا عالم محدّث کثیر الأدب ، ثقة ، ورع ، أثنی علیه المحدّثون ، ورووا عنه مصنفاته وغیر مصنفاته . (511) انتهی .
And Abu Bakr al-Jawhari, this is a knowledgeable hadith narrator, very cultured, trustworthy, pious, and the hadith scholars praised him and narrated his works and other than his works. (511) End.

footnote.p: (511) [B] Sharh Ibn Abi al-Hadid 16/210.

para.p: And as for what he said: And even if it were hypothetically correct, its meaning is... to the end.
So this is nothing but a twisted explanation and misinterpretation, and what evidence is there for the intention of this meaning?

It is strange that he himself has admitted in this book that interpreting the texts of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) according to their apparent meanings is the creed of the Ahle Tasannun, yet still he clings to such (512) crude interpretations, or rather, explicit distortions!

footnote.p: (512) In [A] it mistakenly repeats: "(such)."

para.p: If such frivolous interpretations can be justified in such a clear statement, then no desired conclusion will be established from any definite statement. What the clear meaning of his words is that: "May God Almighty curse anyone who disobeys Osama's command"; to interpret it in this way – that leaving Osama alone and shirking from the important matters of the Romans to avenge Zayd ibn Harithah is forbidden – is to go beyond even the Batinites (those who claim hidden meanings).
Moreover, he himself has said regarding the Imamate in his explanation of the verse (مَنْ یَرْتَدَّ مِنْکُمْ عَنْ دِینِهِ) (whoever from among you turns back from his religion) (513):

footnote.p: (513) Surah Al-Maidah (5): 54.

para.p: "And the fundamental principle is established that when the particle (مَن) is used in the context of condition and consequence, it becomes general. And as has been said in the example: (من دخل حصن کذا . . فله کذا) (whoever enters such and such a fortress, for him is such and such); thus, in this verse as well, whenever someone becomes an apostate, a people described by these attributes will emerge for him." (514) ...

footnote.p: (514) [A and B] page 392 (printed edition, Delhi). [Tuhfah Ithna Ashariyyah: 187].

para.p: Accordingly, the particle (مَن) in the phrase "من تخلّف عنها" (whoever withdraws from it) should also be general, making the exception of Abu Bakr unjustifiable, even though the validity of this exception depends on Abu Bakr being commanded to serve in the Imamate, as his words explicitly indicate. And since his being commanded to the Imamate is not established, his exception should also not be justifiable.
Despite the fact that his being commanded to serve in the Imamate does not constitute a reason for his exception, as previously mentioned.
But what he said: Al-Shahrastani (al-Shahrastani) in Al-Milal wa al-Nihal (The Religions and Sects) stated: "This statement is a fabricated fabrication."
Thus, it is a clear falsehood and a blatant lie, and the original wording of his statement, which includes the assertion of the aforementioned statement, was quoted earlier.

It is the height of audacity that the Addressee not only extends his fabrication against the honorable scholars of truth (Ahl al-Haqq) – on whom he has dared in most of this book – but also goes further, attributing falsehoods to his own scholars as well – in blind imitation of Kabuli!

Poor Al-Shahrastani himself narrates the statement « لعن الله من تخلّف عنها » "May Allah curse whoever wavered from it" and certainly and categorically attributes it to the Prophet of Abundant Mercy (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and the Addressee, with complete audacity and bravery, falsely claims that he said this statement was fabricated and invented.

However, what he stated: that some Persian writers, who consider themselves hadith scholars (muhaddithin) of Ahle Tasannun, have included this statement in their accounts, is not sufficient to compel the Ahle Tasannun.

Thus, the response is that it is not only Persian writers who name themselves hadith scholars of Ahle Tasannun that have included this statement in their books, but other respected scholars of Ahle Tasannun <72> have also presented it and explained it with certainty and conviction.

And it should not remain hidden that Khwaja Kabuli, in "Sawa'iq," responds to this criticism regarding the mention of the phrase « لعن الله من تخلف عنها » "May Allah curse anyone who neglects it" [by saying]:
وإیراد من ینتمی نفسه إلی محدّثی أهل السنة فی سیره من غیر إسناد ، لا یوثق به . (515) انتهی .
And the statement of one who attributes himself to the narrators of Ahle Tasannun in his biography, without chain of narration (Isnad), is not reliable. (515)End.

footnote.p: (515) Sawa'iq, page 254.

para.p: And the son of Kabuli has explicitly stated in the margin that: what is meant by (one who attributes himself) is Jamal al-Din Muhaddith, as he said:
قوله : ( إلی محدّثی أهل السنة ) ، وهو الشیخ جمال الدین فی سیره : روضة الأحباب ، فلا یوثق به . . إلی آخره (516) .
His statement: "(to the narrators of the Ahle Tasannun)" refers to Shaikh Jamal al-Din in his biography: Rawdat al-Ahbab, so it is not reliable... to the end. (516)

footnote.p: (516) Margin of Sawa'iq:

para.p: And the Addressee has also intentionally or inadvertently (517) mentioned this very same point from Kabuli, and the qualification added by the Persian-speaking writers indicates a preliminary understanding, and in any case, to rule the exclusion of Jamal al-Din from the Muhaddithin of the Ahle Tasannun is one of the strange matters; because the elders of the Ahle Tasannun consider Jamal al-Din to be among the trustworthy narrators (Muhaddithin) and great scholars (518), as Mulla Ali Qari said in "Sharh Mishkat" while explaining the hadith: "You will not enter Paradise until you believe, and you will not believe until you love one another":

footnote.p: (517) [A] about the intention of the author of Sawa'iq. (12).
(518) [A] and [Faydah:] The validation (Tawthiq) of Jamal al-Din Muhaddith, the author of Rawdat al-Ahbab. (12).

para.p: As for the copies of Mishkat that are authentic, reliable, and read before the great scholars, such as Al-Jazari (al-Kabir), and Sayyid Usul al-Din, and Jamal al-Din al-Muhaddith… and other present copies, all omit the noon (519).

footnote.p: (519) [A] Beginning of the book "Al-Adab," First Chapter, Chapter on Salutation. [Murqaat al-Mafaatiih 8/457].

para.p: And Shaikh Abd al-Haq Dehlawi, and Mulla Ya'qub Lahori, and Husain ibn Muhammad Diyarbakri, in their books (520), will narrate from his book "Rawdat al-Ahbab" and regard it as reliable, and even the one addressed in "Risalat Usul Hadith" (521) by Jamal al-Din al-Muhaddith considers him one of his trusted teachers of certification, and also views his book "Rawdat al-Ahbab" as better than all compositions on the science of biography!

footnote.p: (520) In [A], it was (themselves), which was corrected.
(521) Ta'rib 'Ajalat al-Naafi'a ("Risalat Usul Hadith"): 100.

para.p: However, what is said: Third: that Abu Bakr experienced a usurpation of position after the demise of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) among the individual believers, becoming a caliph and sitting in place of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)… until the end.
This is thus refuted by several points:

First point: That Abu Bakr's delay until the death of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) in departing with Osama, despite that Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) strong insistence, is certainly a grave sin and wrongdoing, and this point mentioned cannot be adequately addressed in response to this statement.

Second: The assumption we have made, that Abu Bakr was unable to perform the act of following Osama due to becoming a caliph and the change of position, then why did Umar, who had not yet become a caliph, restrain him from following? And this is the second sin, similar to the first. Unless they claim that the true caliph was Umar, and poor Abu Bakr was the mere semblance of a caliph, as he himself admitted (522), the objection returns.

footnote.p: (522) It was narrated that a Bedouin came to Abu Bakr and said: "Are you the caliph of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)?" He said: "No." The Bedouin asked: "Then what are you?" He replied: "I am the one who is the semblance (Khalifa) after him... that is, the one who stands in his place after him." See: Kanz al-Ummal 12 / 531, Tarikh Madinat Dimashq 19 / 497, al-Nihayah 2 / 69, Lisan al-Arab 9 / 69, Taj al-Arous 6 / 103, al-Fa'iq 1 / 339, al-Durr al-Manthur 5 / 306, and others.

para.p: Third: Not every change of position (Inqilab) leads to a change of every ruling, rather what is explicitly stated should be sufficient on its own, so how can a Nasibi (open enemy of the Ahlulbayt) prove that becoming a caliph means that the caliph would disregard the affairs of the noble personality of the Messenger (O Messenger) of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and oppose the commands and prohibitions of that revered figure (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)?

It is completely astounding to see the interlocutor, who at one moment uses Abu Bakr's being a caliph as evidence for the obligation to follow him, and at another moment makes his caliphate a justification for opposing the command of that esteemed figure (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)!

Fourth: The first role, which was to go to war against the Romans in obedience to Osama, was assigned to Abu Bakr by the command of the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and the second role, which consisted of being a caliph becoming and sitting in place of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was, without the command of that Noble One (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) <73> by unanimous agreement, thus the second office in no way implies the dissolution of the first, and by the command of the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) the rulings of the first office should be applicable to him, not the rulings of the second office.
And from this explanation, it becomes clear that: what he has derived from this premise, stating:
"So, when Abu Bakr became the caliph of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and in his place, why should he not accompany Osama?"
is entirely false and sheer nonsense.

As for what he said: Fourth: That it is assumed Abu Bakr was specifically commanded to go himself with Osama to fight the Romans, and his appointing someone to succeed him in prayer did not exempt him; the duty of important matters of the caliphate and protecting the city (Medina) and the dignity of the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) also did not render his excuse for not attending acceptable... until the end.
Then, it is refuted by the fact that: the manner of appointing a successor in prayer became a matter of report.

And engaging in important matters of the caliphate was entirely forbidden to Abu Bakr, as has been made clear, and protecting the city (Medina) and the dignity of the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was not obligatory upon Abu Bakr, so how could these mentioned matters serve as proof of the validity of his excuse for not accompanying Osama?!
As for what he said: and infallibility (Ismah) is not a condition in leadership (Imamah).

He is therefore challenged by the fact that: this was previously mentioned in the refutation of the seventh chapter, in the discussions on the conditions of Imamate have been expressed adequately and with sufficient proof (523), stating that: the infallibility (Ismah) of the Imam from both minor and major sins is a prerequisite for attaining the rank of Imamate among the creation, based on merit. Therefore, the removal of infallibility from Abu Bakr necessitates the removal of his merit for Imamate.

footnote.p: (523) This refers to the book "Burhan al-Sa'adah" by the author; please see the introduction to the research.

para.p: As for what he said: and the committing of major sins (kaba'ir) by him is not established with anyone from the Shia or Ahle Tasannun.
It is rejected; because Shaikh Abdul Haq Dehlawi stated in "Sharh Mushkat":

"And a major sin is that [which] has a fixed punishment (hadd) determined upon it in the Sharia, or a warning (wa'idi) has occurred regarding it, or a prohibition (nahy) from it has been established through definitive evidence (qati' (524))." (525) Thus ends his statement.

footnote.p: (524) In the source: (qat'ii).
(525) [A and B] Kitab al-Iman, Chapter on Major Sins. [Ish'aat al-Lama'at 1 / 72].

para.p: And it is mentioned in "Mufhim," the commentary (Sharh) on Sahih Muslim:
وی عن ابن عباس ( رضی الله عنه ) إنه قال :
Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) is reported to have said:
الکبائر : کلّ ذنب ختمه الله بنار أو غضب أو لعنة أو عذاب . . ونحو هذا عن الحسن البصری (526) .
"Major sins are every sin that Allah has sealed with fire, or anger, or curse, or punishment..." And something similar is reported from Al-Hasan al-Basri (526).

footnote.p: (526) [A and B] Chapter on Major Sins from Kitab al-Iman. (12). [In Mufhim 1 / 283, it is stated: And from Al-Hasan: "It is every sin that Allah has sealed with fire, or anger, or curse, or punishment... And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas that it includes everything Allah has forbidden."]

para.p: And a curse has befallen those who refrain from joining the army of Osama, so the one who commits it would be a transgressor (fasiq). However, according to the statement of Ibn Abbas and al-Hasan, this is apparent. And according to what Abdul Haq mentioned, it is because the curse (la'n) is also a warning (wa'id).

And this is sufficient to refute this opinion for the audience, otherwise, it is firmly established among the Shia that Abu Bakr, in reality, had no faith, what then to speak of committing major sins (kaba'ir)!

As for what he says: that these are one or two criticisms that the Shia establish from the traditions of the Ahle Tasannun against Abu Bakr and his likes, the first will not be established, and even if, hypothetically, it were to be established... until the end.

Thus, the criticisms of Abu Bakr are not limited to one or two criticisms, rather, his faults are many, and – praise be to Allah – most of them have been established in this book, leaving no room for the skepticism of an adversary (mu'and).

And whenever even one reproach is established against Abu Bakr – that would render his leadership (imamate) invalid – it will be proven that he was a usurper and unjust in the Caliphate, and from this, the lack of faith and complete hypocrisy will become evident; thus, whenever his hypocrisy and lack of faith are established, it will be clear that all his virtues (fada'il) are fabrications (mawdu'at) and slanders of the Ahle Tasannun.

In conclusion: what this Nasibi has imagined, that after establishing one or two criticisms, his virtues will remain eligible for consideration (i'tibaar) in the eyes of anyone, is nothing but an illusion. Rather, as soon as his lack of faith (imaan) and being cursed (mal'oon) is established, it is impossible that any recognition remains regarding him.
If a virtue for him is established, otherwise it would entail that the accursed unbeliever (kaafir al-mal‘oon) would be regarded as praiseworthy (mamdooh), which is self-evidently false.
And despite that, the fabricated virtues of Abu Bakr narrated through the method of Ahle Tasannun, how will the Shi‘ah consider them credible, so that they measure him against these criticisms?!
However, what has been said: some of those are also narrated and authentic in the books of the Shi‘ah.
It has been previously established (527) that what is narrated and authentic in the books of the Shi‘ah never indicates the superiority (fadilah) of Abu Bakr.

footnote.p: (527) This refers to his other writings in refutation of "Tuhfat al-Tha‘labīyah" (Gift of the Ithna-‘Asharīyah), such as "Burhaan al-Sa‘aadah" (Proof of Happiness).

para.p: As for the claim that, among the Shi‘ah, the Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) command is not necessarily for obligation, as Al-Murtada explicitly stated in Al-Durar wa al-Ghurar (The Pearls and the Gems).

So, if the intention is that, among all the scholars of the Shi‘ah, the command of the Lawgiver (shari‘) is not necessarily for obligation – as the apparent meaning of his words suggests – then this is a clear falsehood and a disgraceful slander, because the belief of most of the investigators among the scholars of the Shi‘ah (may Allah be pleased with them) is that the command is for obligation, and this is also the well-known and prevailing belief, and Sayyid Al-Murtada (may Allah have mercy on him) also chose this belief that the command is for obligation, except for a distinction between the well-known belief and the belief ofSayyid Murtaza is one who states: In the case of a matter (Amr), it is generally obligatory both legally and linguistically, and according to Sayyid Murtaza (may Allah have mercy on him), it is a shared term in language between obligation and recommendation, and in legal custom (urf), it is determined to signify obligation, just as Sayyid Murtaza mentioned in his book "Zari'ah," which deals with the principles of jurisprudence (usul al-fiqh):

ونحن وإن ذهبنا إلی أن هذه اللفظة مشترکة فی اللغة بین الندب والإیجاب ، فنحن نذهب إلی أن العرف الشرعی المتفق المستمرّ قد أوجب أن یحمل مطلق هذه اللفظة – إذا وردت عن الله وعن الرسول ( صلی الله علیه وآله وسلم ) – علی الوجوب دون الندب ، وعلی الفور دون التراخی . (528) انتهی بقدر الحاجة .

"And we, although we maintain that this term is shared in language between recommendation (nadb) and obligation (ijab), believe that the established, consistent legal custom (urf shar'i) has necessitated that the general use of this term – when it comes from Allah and the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) – be interpreted as obligation (wujub) rather than recommendation (nadb), and as immediate (forur) rather than deferred." (528) This is enough to meet the need.

footnote.p: (528) Al-Zari’ah 1 / 53.

para.p: Therefore, a mere command from the Legislator (Shari') – according to both views – will be considered obligatory (wajib), and based on this, even if other indications of obligation (wujub) do not arise, Abu Bakr would be considered disobedient (asi) for neglecting to fulfill Osama's command, while the indications of obligation (wujub) are, in fact, still present.
However, what Sayyid Murtaza (peace be upon him) stated in his book "Dorar wa Gorar" regarding the rulings of the hadith of the story of Mariah al-Qibtiyyah, that:

ممّا فیه أیضا من الأحکام : اقتضاؤه أن مجرد أمر الرسول ( صلی الله علیه وآله وسلم ) لا یقتضی الوجوب ; لأنه لو اقتضی ذلک لما حسنت مراجعته ولا استفهامه ، وفی حسنها ووقوعها موقعها دلالة علی أنها لا یقتضی ذلک (529) .

"Among the rulings it also entails is that a mere command of the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) does not imply obligation; because if it did, neither his revisiting nor his questioning would be appropriate. The appropriateness of both and their occurrence in their proper context indicates that it does not imply that." (529)

footnote.p: (529) [B] Amali al-Murtaza 1 / 78 (Cairo edition 1373). [Al-Amali 1 / 55].

para.p: So that is not the belief of Sayyid Murtaza (may Allah have mercy on him), for you understood that Sayyid Murtaza (may Allah have mercy on him) himself stated in "Zari'ah" that: his belief is that the absolute command of the Legislator (Shari') is to be understood as obligatory (wajib), and strong evidences and clear proofs derived from the Quran and hadiths have established this belief. Therefore, if there is one hadith that contradicts it, it will not cause any harm.

However, since some scholars have chosen the same [view] that: a mere command of the Legislator does not imply obligation (wujub) until a sign of obligation is established, we will also respond according to this belief, which is that: in the matter of dispute – namely, the command of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) for the enforcement with the army of Osama – signs of obligation are present. Thus, Abu Bakr must have been in the wrong for his defiance, as a sinner.

Among the <75> signs of obligation is the statement: "May Allah curse whoever neglects it," which clearly indicates the obligation of the command and makes it evident that one who opposes this command is subject to curse.

Among them is that the noble Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), in the midst of severe illness and the intensity of disease, repeatedly commanded its enforcement and inquired about the state of the army's enforcement; therefore, inevitably, a matter that receives such emphasis, intensification, repetition, and urging in this state will be obligatory. This is why Qazi al-Qozat (Ibn Khallikan) did not deny the indication of the command regarding the original obligation (wujub), but rather denied its immediate obligation (wujub), so that Abu Bakr's delay from Osama's army does not result in his disobedience, as he said:
إن الأمر لا یقتضی الفور ، فلا یلزم من تأخر أبی بکر عن النفوذ أن یکون عاصیاً (530) .
Indeed, the matter does not require immediacy, so the delay of Abu Bakr in carrying out the command does not necessarily mean he was disobedient. (530)

footnote.p: (530) Al-Mughni 20 / Q 1 / 344 states: And we know that if he had approached him and said, "Enforce the expedition of Ubaydullah," he would not have been considered one of them, so likewise, if he is carried out, it could be said at that time: The very nature of the matter requires his delay, so how could he be disobedient by delaying? Rather, if he had enforced it with them, he would have been disobedient by that.

para.p: And Sayyid Murtaza – peace be upon him – in his book "Shafi" responds to him by establishing the indication of the command as requiring immediate action, as he said:

فأمّا خطابه ( صلی الله علیه وآله وسلم ) بالتنفیذ للجیش ، فالمقصود به الفور دون التراخی ; أمّا من حیث مقتضی الأمر علی مذهب من رأی ذلک لغة أو شرعا ، من حیث وجدنا جمیع الأُمّة – من عهد الصحابة إلی هذا الوقت – یحملون أوامره [ ونواهیه ] (531) علی الفور ویطلبون فی تراخیها الأدلة . ثم لو لم یثبت کل ذلک ، لکان قول أُسامة : ( لم أکن أسأل عنک الرکبان ) ، أوضح دلیل علی أنه عقل من الأمر الفور ; لأن سؤال الرکب عنه بعد وفاته لا معنی له .

As for his address (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) to enforce the expedition to Jarud, the intention behind it was immediate action rather than delay; concerning the necessity of the command according to the belief of those who viewed it as such, whether linguistically or legally, we find that the entire Ummah – from the time of the Companions until now – carries out his commands [and prohibitions] (531) as requiring immediacy and seeks evidence for any delays. Moreover, even if all of this were not established, Ubaydullah's statement: "I was not going to ask you about this", would be the clearest evidence that he understood the matter as requiring immediacy; because questioning the group about it after his death would be meaningless.

footnote.p: (531) The addition is from the source and [B].

para.p: وأمّا قول صاحب الکتاب : ( إنه لم ینکر علی أُسامة تأخیره ) ; فلیس بشیء ، وأیّ إنکار أبلغ من تکراره الأمر ، وترداده القول فی حال یشغل عن المهمّ ویقطع عن الفکر إلاّ فیها .

And as for the statement of the author of the book: "None of them denied Ubaydullah's delay" ; this is inconsequential, and what denial could be more significant than the repetition of the command and the reiteration of the statement in a situation that distracts from what is important and cuts off thought, except in this?
وقد یکون وجوب الأمر علی المأمور تارة بتکرار الأمر وأُخری بغیره (532) .
The obligation of the command on the commanded may sometimes be established by repetition of the command and other times by different means. (532)

footnote.p: (532) [B] Shafi: 246 (printed in 1301 AH) . [Shafi 4 / 147 - 148].

para.p: And with this, if Abu Bakr had gone with the army of Osama – and it is said after a delay – the words of the judge of judges would have had the capacity to be mentioned. However, since he refrained from the very act of going, his opposition to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was established, and the discussion about the urgency or non-urgency of the matter became pointless.

But what has been said: we came to the statement: « لعن الله من تخلّف عنها » "May Allah curse whoever neglects it," then this is not found in the books of the Ahle Tasannun, so they are not in need of a response from him.
So, his response has passed.

But what has been said: the term (whoever) is general among the Shia – as they have explicitly stated in the books of principles – so in this case, the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) and other Muslims are included in this... until the end.

Thus, the generality of the term (whoever) cannot entail the truth of the warning implied by the mentioned statement against the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) and other Muslims who were not part of Osama's army, because if someone says: "Whoever enters my house from the Banu Hashim, honor him," and a person from the Banu Umayyah enters that person's house, they will not be deserving of honor despite the generality of the term (whoever). This matter is similar; because a warning of neglect cannot be conceived except concerning those who were commanded to obey Osama. Thus, the meaning of this statement is that: whoever from among those who were commanded to obey Osama neglects the army of Osama, that person is cursed, whether it be Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, or anyone else.
But what has been said: If they say that the warning is specific to those appointed with Osama.

We reply: «جهّزوا جیش أُسامة» "Equip the army of Osama" cannot be addressed to the appointed ones, for equipping and organizing the army of Osama, in essence, would mean to speak of organizing the army of Osama in a meaningless way.

So the answer is that you understood the meaning of equipping in the language, which is to prepare the necessities of a traveler, and in preparing the necessities of a traveler, there is no harm in preparing their own necessities or those accompanying them, just as Ibn Hajar said in "Fath al-Bari" in the explanation of the Hadiths in the chapter (Virtue of Equipping a Warrior) from the sections of the book of Jihad in "Sahih Bukhari" after narrating a Hadith:
ففیه إشارة إلی أن الغازی إذا جهّز نفسه أو قام بکفایة من یخلفه بعده کان له الأجر مرتین (533).
So there is an indication in it that if a warrior equips themselves or takes care of the needs of someone to follow them after, they will have the reward twice. (533)

footnote.p: (533) [B] Fath al-Bari 6 / 32 (Cairo edition 1325). [Fath al-Bari 6 / 37].

para.p: And this statement of that Imam (peace be upon him) also issued after appointing those designated with the army of Osama, so what is so surprising that the command to equip the army could be to those present, and the warning for neglecting the army of Osama could be related to the appointed ones of that army?!
But what has been said: Then the address is general to all Muslims.

This is contradictory to what was first said: « جهّزوا جیش أُسامة » "Equip the army of Osama," an address to the appointed ones cannot be, for equipping and organizing the army of Osama exactly like the army of Osama is an utterance without meaning; because the appointed ones were also among the Muslims.
However, what is said about the phrase « لعن الله » "May Allah curse" is also related to this aforementioned statement.

So the answer is that, in this case, it would necessitate that the warning applies to those who were not commanded to go with the army of Osama, and the issuance of this meaning from the Wise and Wise One (Hakim) is not conceivable. Therefore, the phrase « لعن الله من تخلّف عنها » “May Allah curse whoever refrains from it” would only apply to those who were commanded and obligated in connection with the accompaniment and following of Osama.
As for what is said about defying God's command in the eyes of the Shia from the Prophet Adam (peace be upon him) and the Prophet Yunus (peace be upon him) being undoubtedly established,

Then, the answer is that comparing Abu Bakr's refusal to accompany the army of Osama – which was certainly forbidden (haram) and subject to cursing (La'an) – to the actions of the Prophet Adam (peace be upon him) is a flawed analogy (qiyaas ma‘ al-faariq), for Abu Bakr's action was forbidden (haram) and one of the major sins (kabair) leading to punishment (iqab) and torment ('adhab), while the Prophet Adam (peace be upon him) made a preferable omission (tark awla) rather than a neglect of an obligation (tark wajib), and a preferable omission is not a cause of the Lord's punishment upon anyone, just as Sayyid Murtaza 'Ilm al-Huda said in the book “Tanzih al-Anbiya wa al-A'imma”:

أمّا المعصیة ; فهی مخالفة الأمر ، والأمر من الحکیم تعالی قد یکون بالواجب وبالندب معاً ، فلا یمتنع علی هذا أن یکون آدم ( علیه السلام ) مندوباً إلی ترک التناول من الشجرة ، ویکون آدم بمواقعة (534) تارکاً نفلا وفضلا ، وغیر فاعل قبیحاً ، ولیس یمتنع أن یسمّی تارک النفل : عاصیاً ، کما یسمّی بذلک تارک الواجب ، فإن تسمیة من خالف ما أُمر به – سواء کان واجباً أو نفلا – ب : أنه عاص ظاهرة ، ولهذا یقولون : أمرت فلاناً هکذا (535) وکذا من الخیر فعصانی وخالفنی ، وإن لم یکن ما أمر به واجباً .

As for the sin; it is a violation of the command, and the command of the Wise (Hakim), the Exalted, may be with both an obligation and a recommendation (ndib) together, so it would not be impossible for this to be Adam (peace be upon him) was Divinely appointed to refrain from partaking of the tree, and Adam, by engaging (534), would be leaving a voluntary act and an extra blessing, and not committing something ugly. However, it would not be unreasonable to call one who leaves a voluntary act: disobedient (asi), just as one would call a person who leaves an obligatory act by that term. For the designation of one who contravenes what they were commanded – whether it be obligatory or voluntary – as being disobedient (asi) is evident, and thus they say: "I commanded so-and-so to do this (535) and that from among the good, but he disobeyed me and went against me," even if what he was commanded was not obligatory.

footnote.p: (534) In the source and [B]: (by engaging in it).
(535) In the source: (to do this).

para.p: فأمّا قوله تعالی : ( فَغَوی ) (536) ، فمعناه : إنه خاب ، لأنّا نعلم إنه لو فعل ما ندب إلیه من ترک التناول من الشجرة لاستحقّ الثواب العظیم ، فإذا خالف الأمر ولم یصر إلی ما ندب إلیه فقد خاب لا محالة من حیث لم یصل إلی الثواب الذی کان یستحقّ بالامتناع ، ولاشبهة فی أن لفظة ( غوی ) تحتمل الخیبة (537) ، قال الشاعر – شعر – :

As for His statement, the Exalted, saying: (So he faltered) (536), its meaning is: He failed, for we know that if he had done what he was urged to do by refraining from partaking of the tree, he would have deserved the great reward. Therefore, if he disobeyed the command and did not resort to what he was urged to, he has certainly failed in that he did not attain the reward he would have deserved by abstaining, and there is no doubt that the term (faltered) (ghawa) can imply such a failure (537). The poet said – poem -:

footnote.p: (537) In [A], it mistakenly reads: (the explicit).

para.p: فمن یلق خیراً یحمد الناس أمره *
Whoever encounters good, people will praise his matter,
ومن یغو لا یعدم علی الغی لائماً (538)
and whoever falters will not lack a blame on his failure." (538)

footnote.p: (538) [B] Tanzih: 11, Najaf Ashraf edition, 1379 AH. [Tanzih al-Anbiyaa (peace be upon them): 24-25]

para.p: As for the Prophet Jonah (peace be upon him) after him, there is no evidence from the narrations of the Shia that he opposed the command of an obligatory act, and what this Nasibi has presented regarding Prophethood is a narration. (539)

footnote.p: (539) Tuhfat Ithnaa 'Ashariyya: 165.

para.p: The issuance of a decree opposing the obligatory (hukm wajib) <77> from the blessed Prophet Yunus, peace be upon him and our Prophet [and his holy progeny], does not remain established and confirmed (thabit wa mutahaqqiq), as is recorded in "Husam al-Islam" (540) in a sufficiently clear and adequate manner. Therefore, whoever wishes to be informed about it may refer to that work (541).

footnote.p: (540) The book "Husam al-Islam wa Saham al-Malam" is a refutation of Chapter Six of "Tuhfat al-ithna'ashariyya" by Maulana Sayyid Dildar Ali Nasirabadi. For further explanation, please refer to the Researcher’s Preface.
(541) Husam al-Islam: 91-92.

chapter.title: Fourth Criticism: Incompetence to Manage Affairs

para.p: Dehalvi’s claim
He said: Fourth Objection:

That the Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) sometimes did not appoint Abu Bakr as governor over a matter related to the establishment of the religion and the firm (Shari') law, and whosoever is not worthy of the governance of a matter of the Muslims, how could they be worthy of the general governance of the Muslims?!
Answering this objection has been done in several ways:

First: That this claim is a pure lie and an outright slander. By the consensus of the people of history and chronicles, both Shia and the Ahle Tasannun, it is established and correct that after the defeat of Uhud, when it was reported to him that Abu Sufyan, after returning, was remorseful and intended to attack Medina, he (the Prophet) granted permission to confront him, and Abu Bakr faced them. And in the fourth year, during the expedition of Banu Nadir, one night Abu Bakr al-Siddiq was made the commander of the army, while he (the Prophet) honored the state of the house with his presence. And in the sixth year, when they set out for the expedition of Banu Lihyan, that tribe, having heard of the attention of that apparent one (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), took refuge in the mountains. He (the Prophet) stayed at their home for two days, sending out detachments, among which was a major detachment under the leadership of Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, which was permitted to head towards Kura' al-Ghamim (542). And in the Battle of Tabuk was commanded by the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, to be carried out with the Divine Approval that the armies of support should gather alongside him outside the illuminated city of Medina at Thaniyyat al-Wada' (543), and the commander of the army would be the Honest One (Siddiq), with the ranks of the army established under his authority. And in the Battle of Khaybar, when the esteemed Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, was afflicted by a pain in his temple during (544) the siege of the fortress, he appointed Abu Bakr as his deputy and sent him for the conquest of the fortress, and on that day, Abu Bakr exhibited fierce combat.

footnote.p: (542) Al-Hamawi said: Kura' al-Ghamim: a location between Mecca and Medina... And Nasr said: Kura' al-Ghamim is a location near Medina between Rabigh and al-Juhayfah. See: Mu'jam al-Buldan 4 / 214. And he stated in another place: Kura' al-Ghamim, a location in the region of Hijaz between Mecca and Medina, is a valley in front of Asfan, eight miles away, and this Kura' is a black mountain at the edge of the volcanic area extending to it. Refer to: Mu'jam al-Buldan 4 / 443.

(543) Thaniyyat al-Wada' - with the "waw" pronounced open - is a name signifying parting at the time of departure, and it is a rise overlooking the city that those wishing to go to Mecca would tread upon. There are differing opinions regarding its naming... However, the correct view is that it is an ancient, pre-Islamic name given for the farewell of travelers. See: Mu'jam al-Buldan 2 / 86, and also refer to: Qamus al-Muhit 3 / 92, Taj al-Arus 11 / 50.
(544) In [the text], by mistake: (during) has been repeated.

para.p: And in the seventh year, Abu Bakr was also sent against a group of Banu Kulab, and Salamah ibn al-Akwa' became specifically appointed to Abu Bakr with his mission and fought against Banu Kulab, killing some and capturing others, and he also returned with them. The commander of the army against Banu Fazara (545) was the Honest One (Siddiq), as Hakim narrates from Salamah ibn al-Akwa':

footnote.p: (545) In the source: (Qarazah).

para.p: أمّر رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم أبا بکر ، فغزونا ناساً من بنی فزارة (546) ، فلمّا دنونا من الماء أمرنا أبو بکر فعرسنا ، فلمّا صلّینا الصبح أمرنا أبو بکرفشننّاالغارة . . (547) إلی آخر الحدیث .

The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, appointed Abu Bakr, and we fought against people of Bani Fazara (546), and when we drew near to the water, Abu Bakr commanded us to set up camp, and when we prayed the morning prayer, Abu Bakr ordered us to launch the raid… (547) to the end of the narration.

footnote.p: (546) In the source and al-Mustadrak: (Qurazah).
(547) Al-Mustadrak 3 / 36.

para.p: And it is mentioned in "Ma'arij" and "Habib al-Siyar" that:

After the Battle of Tabuk, some Bedouins came in [the presence of] the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and said that a group of Bedouins had gathered in the Valley of Sand, claiming a desire for an Attack (Shabikhun) (548). The Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) gave his banner to Abu Bakr al-Siddiq and made him the commander of the army, sending him to that group.

footnote.p: (548) In [A] it was (Shabikhun), which has been corrected.

para.p: Also, when a house of fighting broke out among the Banu Amr ibn Awf, and the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was informed in the afternoon, he went to their neighborhood to rectify the situation. He instructed Bilal to tell Abu Bakr that if the time for prayer arrived and I do not come, he should lead the people in prayer. And indeed, the time for the afternoon prayer happened in this manner; and when, in the ninth year, Hajj became obligatory, and his (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) going was delayed due to some matters, he appointed Abu Bakr al-Siddiq as the leader of the Hajj, sending him with a large group of companions to Mecca to perform the rituals of Hajj there and to instruct the people on the principles of this great act of worship. The delegation of leading the prayer during his illness of death, from the night of Thursday until the morning of Monday, <78> is so well-known that it does not require further explanation.

Now, it must be contemplated that the matters of religion which pertain to the leader consist of these three things: first, jihad (struggle), second, hajj (pilgrimage), third, prayer (namaz), and in all three matters, Abu Bakr as-Siddiq (the Truthful) has been appointed as His deputy in His presence. What other religious matter remains in which Abu Bakr did not possess the competence for delegation (niyaba) and leadership (imamate)?!

Second: We accept that the Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) sometimes did not appoint Abu Bakr as an overseer (wali) for a matter; however, it was because he regarded him as his minister (wazir) and counselor (mashir), and without his presence, no work of the affairs of religion would be completed. It has always been the custom and habit of kings to not send ministers and great commanders for administrative tasks and military commands, nor to appoint an emir over detachments (saraya); because major tasks become incomplete in their absence. And this point was itself indicated by the noble Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny).

Al-Hakim narrates from Hudhayfa bin al-Yaman, who said: I heard from the noble Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) that he was saying: "I intend to send people to distant and far-off kingdoms to teach the religion and obligatory duties, just as Jesus (peace be upon him) had sent the disciples."

The attendees said: "O Messenger of God!" (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) "Such men are already present, like Abu Bakr and Umar." The Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) replied: إنه لا غنی لی عنهما، إنهما من الدین کالسمع والبصر (Indeed, I have no need of them; they are both part of the religion like hearing and sight)!

And the noble Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) also said: "God, the Exalted, has granted me four ministers: two ministers from the inhabitants of the earth: Abu Bakr and Umar; and two ministers from the inhabitants of the heavens: Gabriel (Jibril) and Michael (Mikail)."

Third: The one who, if they were not sent for a task, would imply a lack of suitability for leadership, would have to conclude that Hassan and Hussain (peace be upon them) were also unworthy of leadership, God forbid such a thing; because the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) did not send either of them to any war or task, and appointed their half-brother (549), Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyyah, to tasks instead, until people asked Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyyah why your revered father assigns you to tasks in battles and dangerous situations, and does not separate you from Hassan and Hussain (peace be upon them), what is the reason for this? That Imam Zada (peace be upon him) replied justly: Hassan and Hussain (peace be upon them) are to the offspring of my father like two eyes in a human body, and others are like hands and feet, so that when tasks are ultimately completed by hands and feet, why should the eyes be troubled; rather, it is the nature of a human that the hand protects the eye in times of danger. (550) End.

footnote.p: (549) Banu al-alat: Sons of a man from different mothers. See Dehkhoda Dictionary.
(550) [B] Tuhfah: 267. [Tuhfah Ithna Ashariyyah 266-267].

para.p: The response from the respected author
I say:

Qazi al-Qozat (Ibn Khallikan) in the book "Mughni," and Muhaqqiq Khwaja Nasir al-Din (may God have mercy on him) in the book "Tajrid" (551), and Allama Hilli in the book "Kashf al-Haq and Nahj al-Sidq" (552), and Mawlana Muhammad Baqir Majlisi (may Allah have mercy on him) in the book "Haq al-Yaqin" and other esteemed scholars mentioned the essence of this objection and the eleventh objection in a single rebuttal.

footnote.p: (551) [B] [Sharh Tajrid] 1/295. [Sharh Tajrid: 401 (Zanjani's edition), 509 (Ameli's edition), and 204 (Subhani's edition).
(552) [B] Dalail al-Sidq 3/18.

para.p: Qazi al-Qozat (Ibn Khallikan) in the book "Mughni" stated:

قالوا : إنه لم یولّ أبا بکر الأعمال وولّی غیره ، ولمّا ولاّه الحج بالناس ، وأن یقرء علیهم سورة براءة ، عزله عن ذلک کلّه ، وجعل الأمر إلی أمیر المؤمنین ( علیه السلام ) ، وقال : « لا یؤدّی عنّی إلاّ أنا أو رجل منّی » ، حتّی رجع أبو بکر إلی النبیّ [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله ) ] (553) .

They said: "He did not appoint Abu Bakr to oversee the affairs and appointed others instead, and when he appointed him to lead the Hajj with the people, to recite Surah Barahat (Surah At-Tawbah) to them, he removed him from all of that and placed the matter in the hands of the Commander of the Faithful (Ali, peace be upon him), and said: 'None will perform this task on my behalf except for me or a man from me,' until Abu Bakr returned to the Prophet [Muhammad] (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)." (553)
And our master Muhammad Baqir Majlisi (may Allah have mercy on him) in the book "Haq al-Yaqin" said:

First Objection: That the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) used to delegate great matters that arose to the eminent companions, and he did not delegate any matter to Abu Bakr except for reading the verses of Surah Baraat (Surah At-Tawbah) to the people of Mecca; and when he set out, Gabriel (peace be upon him) descended and said: "Indeed, Allah, the Exalted, says that none will fulfill your message (554) except for you or someone who is from you." Then the Commander of the Faithful (Ali, peace be upon him) went and took the verses from Abu Bakr, and Abu Bakr was returned, and he recited the verses during the Hajj season to the people of Mecca. It is clear that the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) would not act without Divine Revelation, so the fact that Allah, the Exalted, first commanded him to give something to Abu Bakr and then took it back from him shows no wisdom other than that it becomes evident he lacks the qualifications for leadership and caliphate. and regarding the claim of some of the zealots that Abu Bakr was not deposed from the leadership of Hajj and was present alongside it, this is not mentioned in most of their reliable narrations, and the contrary is found in their narrations. Although this has no benefit for them.

footnote.p: (554) The addition is from the source.

para.p: And others have said that: It was the custom of the Arabs that their elder, when he made a covenant, should have that covenant broken by the elders of his tribe, this is an unfounded statement, and there is no record of it in any book of their earlier reliable texts.
Ibn Abi al-Hadid has acknowledged that: This is not known as the custom (555) of the Arabs, and this is an interpretation that the partisans of Abu Bakr have fabricated (556). (557)

footnote.p: (555) In the source: (customs).
(556) In the source: (invention).

(557) [B] Sharh Ibn Abi al-Hadid 17 / 200, where he said: And what is attributed to the custom of the Arabs is not well-known, rather it is an interpretation that the partisans of Abu Bakr formulated to evade Dissociation (Tabarra) from him.

para.p: Moreover, if a known customary practice had been established, it should not have been hidden from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and he would not have failed to send Abu Bakr at first. And if it was hidden from him (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), it should not have been hidden from Abu Bakr, Umar, and the other companions, who understood the customs of ignorance, and they would have alerted (558) him (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) that sending Abu Bakr is contrary to the principle.

footnote.p: (558) In the source: (alert).

para.p: Additionally, if this had been the reason, then when Abu Bakr returned fearful and sorrowful, the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) should have mentioned this excuse, and it is not mentioned in any narration, that the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) might have made this excuse (559), rather the excuse mentioned in the narrations is that he said: "Gabriel (peace be upon him) came down and said: Only one who is from you can deliver on your behalf."

footnote.p: (559) The addition is from the source.

para.p: And even stranger is that they take the deputation of leading prayer – which is not established to be by the command of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and whose contradiction is evident; and in their belief, any unjust (da'ir) or sinful (fajir) man can lead the prayer – as evidence for the caliphate of Abu Bakr; and they do not consider the removal of Abu Bakr and the entrustment of the verses to the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) by the command of God as a source of virtue for that noble figure. (560) Thus ends the discussion.

footnote.p: (560) [Haqq al-Yaqin] 154. [Haqq al-Yaqin 154-155].

para.p: The essence of this is that in these statements and similar ones, the mere lack of the appointment of a task to Abu Bakr has not been regarded as evidence of his unworthiness for the caliphate, but rather, the absence of appointment has been seen as evidence of his unworthiness in relation to his being removed from matters that he had been appointed to oversee, and this is clear.

In any case, although the one addressed may have exerted significant effort and sacrifice to answer this objection in various treatises and numerous missions to establish the authority of Abu Bakr, it is of no avail; because a portion of it is not even established among trustworthy scholars of the Ahle Tasannun, let alone it being suitable for consideration among the Shia.
Its explanation is that Ibn Hajar, in "Sawa'iq Muhriqah," has responded to this objection by saying:
والجواب عن ذلک : بطلان ما زعموه من أنه لم یولّه عملا ; ففی البخاری عن سلمة بن الأکوع . . إلی آخره (561) .

And the answer to that is: the falsity of what they claimed, that he (the Prophet) did not appoint him to any task; for in Sahih al-Bukhari, it is narrated from Salmah ibn Akwa' … till the end of the narration. (561)

footnote.p: (561) [A] Fifth chapter of the first book. (12). [B] al-Sawa'iq: 28 (Cairo edition 1375). [al-Sawa'iq al-Muhriqah 1 / 76].

para.p: And in “Sahih Bukhari” it is narrated from Salmah ibn Akwa’ that he said:
غزوت مع النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم سبع غزوات ، وخرجت فیما یبعث من البعوث تسع غزوات مرة علینا أبو بکر ومرّة علینا أُسامة (562) .

I fought in seven battles (ghazawat) with the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and I participated in nine battles that he would send to engage in expeditions (bi'uth) with him, sometimes under Abu Bakr and sometimes under Osama (562).

footnote.p: (562) [A] Chapter on the Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) sending of Usamah from the book of al-Maghazi. (12). [B] Sahih al-Bukhari 5 / 144. [Sahih Bukhari 5 / 88].

para.p: And Qastalani, in his explanation of the statement: “مرة علینا أبو بکر” "sometimes under Abu Bakr," said:
مرّة إلی بنی فزارة (563) وأُخری إلی بنی کلاب ، و [ ثالثة ] (564) إلی الحجّ (565) .
Once to Banu Fazara (563) <80> and another time to Banu Kilab, and [a third time] (564) to the pilgrimage (hajj) (565).

footnote.p: (563) [A] Fazara, like the Companions, is the name of a tribal father from Ghatfan. (12). [See: Lisaan al-‘Arab 5 / 55].
(564) The addition is from the source.
(565) Irshad al-Sari 6 / 386.

para.p: This means that Abu Bakr was appointed as a commander over us once towards Banu Fazara, another time towards Banu Kilab, and to the pilgrimage.
And in his explanation of the statement "sometimes under Osama," he said:

أمیرا إلی الحُرُقات (566) وإلی أُبْنَی النضیر – بضم الهمزة وسکون الموحدة ، ثم نون مفتوحة ومقصورة – من نواحی البلقاء ، وهذه خمسة ذکرها أهل السیر وبقیت أربع لم یذکروها فیحتمل أن یکون فی هذا الحدیث حذف ، أی ومرة علینا غیرهما (567) .

As a commander (Amir) to the Horoqaat (566) and to the Ubni al-Nadheer – with the hamzah on top pronounced and the solitary letter unmoved, then an opened and restricted noon – from the regions of al-Balqa, and these five were mentioned by the people of history, while four remained unmentioned, so it is possible that there is an omission in this narration, that is, one more time occurred upon us besides them (567).

footnote.p: (566) [A and B] Horoqaat - with the h and r both in the unpointed, and the q opened, and after the a, a dot above - attributed to the Hurqah, named so because a group was burned there by killing. (12) [See: Fath al-Bari 7 / 398].
(567) Irshad al-Sari 6 / 386.

para.p: That is, once under the command of Osama towards the Hurqat and another time towards the Ubni al-Nadheer from the regions of al-Balqa, and these five missions were noted by the people of history, and the remaining four were not mentioned, so there is a possibility that there is an omission in this narration, meaning one time there was a commander (Amir) over us other than Abu Bakr and Osama.
And Ayni in "Umdat al-Qari Sharh Sahih al-Bukhari" said:

قوله : ( تسع غزوات ) ، منها سریة أبی بکر إلی بنی فزارة ، ذکره مسلم ; وسریته ایضاً إلی بنی کلاب ، ذکره ابن سعد ; وبعثه إلی الحج سنة تسع ; ومنها سریة أسامة التی وقع ذکرها فی الباب ; وسریته إلی أُبنی – بضم الهمزة وسکون الباء الموحدة ثم نون ومقصورة – وهی من نواحی بلقا (568) ، وذلک فی صفر ; فهذه الخمس التی ذکرها أصحاب المغازی ولم یذکروا غیرها ، علی أن فی بعض الروایات لم یذکر عدداً فی البعوث . (569) انتهی .

His statement: (nine ghazwats), including the expedition of Abu Bakr to Banu Fazarah, mentioned by Muslim; and his expedition also to Banu Kilab, mentioned by Ibn Sa'd; and his dispatch to Hajj in the year nine; and one of them is the expedition of Osama mentioned in the chapter; and his expedition to the Ubni – with the hamzah on top pronounced and the solitary letter unmoved, then a noon and restricted – which is from the regions of al-Balqa (568), and that was in Safar; so these five that the companions of maghazis mentioned, and they did not mention others, on the condition that in some narrations, no number is mentioned regarding the expeditions. (569) End quote.

footnote.p: (568) In the source: (al-Balqa).
(569) [A and B] Chapter on the Sending of the Prophet [peace be upon him and his holy progeny] Usamah from the Book of Campaigns (al-Maghazis). [Umdat al-Qari 17 / 272 - 273].

para.p: Similarly, Ibn Hajar al-Asqalani – who is one of the foremost scholars of the Ahle Tasannun – said in the explanation of this hadith:
أما البعوث : فسریة أبی بکر إلی بنی فزارة ، کما بیّن من حدیثه عند مسلم ، ثم سریته إلی بنی کلاب ، ذکرها ابن سعد ; وبعثه إلی الحج سنة تسع . .

As for the expeditions: the expedition of Abu Bakr to the Banu Fazara, as explained in the narration of him found with Muslim, then his expedition to the Banu Kilab, which Ibn Sa'd mentioned; and his dispatch to perform Hajj in the year nine...

وأما أُسامة ، فأول ما استعمل فی السریة التی وقع ذکرها فی الباب ، ثم فی سریته إلی أُبْنی – بضم الهمزة وسکون [ الباء ] الموحدة ، ثم نون [ و ] مقصورة – وهی من نواحی بلقا (570) ، وذلک فی صفر ، فوقفنا ممّا ذکره علی خمس سرایا وبقیت أربع فلیستدرک علی أهل المغازی فإنهم لم یذکروا غیر الذی ذکرته بعد التتبع ، ویحتمل أن یکون فیه حذف وتقدیر . . أی ومرّة علینا غیرهما .

And regarding Osama, he was first appointed in the detachment mentioned in the chapter, then in his expedition to Ubnai – with a dammed alif and a silent [identical] ba, followed by a n with a kasrah – which is from the regions of Balqaa (570), and that was in Safar, so we have confirmed from what he mentioned five detachments, and four remain. This should be noted by the people of the campaigns (al-maghazis), for they did not mention anything other than what I have indicated after investigation, and it is possible that there is an omission and implication in it...indeed, there may have been other instances besides them.

footnote.p: (570) In the source: (al-Balqaa).

para.p: وأیضاً ; فإنه لم یذکر فی بعض الروایات للبعوث عدداً . (571) انتهی .
Also, he did not mention a number for the expeditions (bi'uth) in some narrations. (571) End.

footnote.p: (571) [A and B] Ibid, compared with the original. [Fath al-Bari 7 / 399].

para.p: From these statements, it is clear with utmost clarity that the expeditions (bi'uth) which the Ahle Tasannun claim Abu Bakr was a commander of were all three, and not more than that: the claim of the Addressee regarding the leadership of Abu Bakr, except for the matter of the three campaigns (baʻuth thalathah), is sheer falsehood and absolute fabrication.

However, what is said is that it is established and correct by the consensus of the scholars of biographies and histories – both Shia and Ahle Tasannun – that after the defeat at Uhud, when news reached that Abu Sufyan had returned in remorse and intended to attack the city again, the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) granted permission to confront him, and Abu Bakr went out to face them.

And in the margin of this statement, it is written: And among the scholars of biographies, this expedition (ghazwah) is named the Expedition of Humara' al-Asad (Ghazwat Humara' al-Asad); because the camp of the Muslims at that time, which had gathered with Abu Bakr for that expedition, was at the location of Humara' al-Asad. And some have said that the place of halt for Abu Sufyan and the polytheists was that very location (572).

footnote.p: (572) Margin of Tuhfat al-Ithnaa 'Ashariyyah: 539.

para.p: Therefore, it is refuted for several reasons:

First reason: That there is no mention or evidence of this incident in the books of biographies and histories of the Shia, and if the Addressee has seen this account in any credible book, let him clarify it.
Second: That the admission of Qastalani, Ayni, and Ibn Hajar that the leadership of Abu Bakr was not established beyond the three expeditions (sariyyah) contradicts this.
Third: That the scholars of biographies and historians of the Sunnis have explicitly stated

That the Messenger of Allah, may peace be upon him and his holy progeny, had risen during this expedition (ghazwah) is not to say that he had granted permission to Abu Bakr. Most historians have agreed that that noble figure, may peace be upon him and his holy progeny, had entrusted the banner of war in this expedition (ghazwah) to the God-worshiping Hand of Allah, the Prevailing Lion, Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon them both.
And some of them mentioned the handing over of the banner to Abu Bakr, according to one saying and a single narration – the one who asserts and narrates it is neither known nor recognized! -

Due to the fact that they are suspected of being excessive in their love for Abu Bakr, their statement may not be considered reliable; and what Ibn Hajar refutes it with in “Al-Fath al-Bari Sharh Sahih Bukhari” within the explanation of the Hadiths of the Prophet's Banner is noteworthy:
أخرج أحمد – بإسناد قوی – من حدیث ابن عباس : إن رایة النبیّ [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله ) ] کانت تکون مع علی [ ( علیه السلام ) ] ، ورایة الأنصار مع سعد بن عبادة . . إلی آخر الحدیث . (573) انتهی .
