Ahmad narrated – with a strong chain of narration – from theHadith of Ibn Abbas: "The banner of the Prophet, may peace be upon him and his holy progeny, used to be with Ali, peace be upon him, and the banner of the Ansar was with Sa'd ibn Ubadah... until the end of the Hadith." (573)

footnote.p: (573) [A] Chapter on what was said about the banner of the Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, from the Book of Jihad. (12). [B] Al-Fath al-Bari 6 / 78 (Cairo edition 1325). [Al-Fath al-Bari 6 / 89].

para.p: And the author of “Al-Isti'ab” narrated from Ibn Abbas:
قال : لعلی [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله ) ] أربع خصال لیست لأحد غیره : هو أول عربی وعجمی صلّی مع رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم ; وهو الذی کان لواؤه معه فی کل زحف . . (574) إلی آخر الحدیث .

He said: "Ali, peace be upon him, had four traits that no one else had: he was the first Arab and non-Arab to pray with the Messenger of Allah, may peace be upon him and his holy progeny, and he was the one whose banner was with him in every battle..." (574)

footnote.p: (574) [A] In the biography of Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him, from the letter Ain. [B] Al-Isti'ab 2 / 457. [Al-Isti'ab 3 / 1090].

para.p: Fourth: The one who did not have the opportunity to confront anyone in this battle, even considering the possibility of the mentioned narration being correct, could be a proof of his honor and virtue and his ability to engage in combat, regarding the successors of Abu Bakr.
Witness to these circumstances and an instance of this statement is that Usul al-Din (575) al-Muhaddith, in his book “Darj al-Durar,” said about the events of the third year:

footnote.p: (575) [A and B] Usul al-Din was one of the greatest Muhaddithin and major trustworthy scholars of the Ahle Tasannun. Ali Qarqi explicitly stated in his “Sharh Mishkat” that he was one of the senior shaykhs. [Murqat al-Mafatih Sharh Mishkat al-Masabih 1/40, and in several instances, he expressed his reliance on him. See 2/79 and 3/13, 341, 546, and 6/333 and 8/122, 457 for details.] He is also included in the chain of permission of the scholarly Naasib, as he mentioned in his treatise on the Usul of Hadith, while discussing the chains of narration of hadith books: “Mishkat al-Masabih” by Shaikh Abu Tahir from Shaikh Ibrahim al-Kurdi, and he from Shaikh Ahmad al-Qushashi, and he from Shaikh Ahmad bin Abdul Quddus al-Shannawi, and he from Sayyid Ghunfar bin Sayyid Ja'far al-Nahrawani, and he from Shaikh Muhammad Sa'id known as Mir-Kalan – who were Shaykh of Mecca in his time – and he from Sayyid Nasim al-Din Mirak Shah, and he from his esteemed elder uncle, Sayyid Usul al-Din Abdullah bin Abdul Rahman bin Abdul Latif bin Jalal al-Din bin Yahya al-Shirazi al-Husayni... to the end. (12) [Ta'rib al-'Ajala al-Nafi'a (Treatise on the Usul of Hadith): 99-100].

para.p: In this year, the Incident of the Red Abyss (Ghazwat al-Hamra al-Asad) occurred. The reports of it and the accounts of it, may Allah have mercy on them, have been investigated as follows: It was the end of Saturday when the Master of Messengers (576) (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) returned from Uhud to his familiar home.

footnote.p: (576) In [A], it mistakenly says: (Messenger).

para.p: On the night of Sunday, a group of the distinguished Ansar kept vigil until daybreak at the threshold of the Celestial Realm (Sahib al-Marqab) of the Presence. The next day, when he offered the morning prayer in congregation, he said to Bilal (may Allah be pleased with him) to proclaim in the city that: "The decree of Prophethood has been established in such a manner that a host of friends will set out from behind the enemies, and every breathing being that was not present in the Battle of Uhud must not come out with us."

Jabir requested emphatically: "I have been deprived of that state for the sake of my father and to protect his family, and today I wish to be in service." Due to the attention that the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) showed to Jabir, he was the only one permitted; and that same day, Ibn Umm Maktum was appointed as the Caliph of Medina, and a standard was entrusted to Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him), – though according to one account, it was given to Abu Bakr al-Siddiq – and despite the weakness and wounds they had, they set out. They were taken to Hamla' Asad, which is approximately eight miles (more or less) (577) from there to Medina, and they were brought to the Imperial Camp (Ashkar-i Humayun) (578), and on Monday night, they kindled five hundred fires in that place so that the aura of their majesty would reach the surrounding areas, and the verse: ( الَّذِینَ اسْتَجابُوا لِلّهِ وَالرَّسُولِ مِنْ بَعْدِ ما أَصابَهُمُ الْقَرْحُ لِلَّذِینَ أَحْسَنُوا مِنْهُمْ وَاتَّقَوْا أَجْرٌ عَظِیمٌ ) (Those who responded to Allah and the Messenger after what befell them of injury will have a great reward, for those who excelled among them and feared [Allah]) (579), bore witness to their circumstances and revealed their outcome (580). And the purpose of the Presence (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) with this was mentioned attention was that the rumor of the weakness and disarray of the Islamic army should not spread, but rather the tribes and the revived, and the enemies and the friends, should know that they have no faltering or shortcoming <82>. And when the polytheists of Quraysh realized that movement, they would not incline to return towards Medina, and this endeavor was ultimately entirely correct, for it was consistently established that Quraysh, upon returning, when they reached Ruha' (581), became regretful and stopped there, saying: "We have made a great mistake in this return; our duty is to go back and utterly defeat Muhammad, peace be upon him [and his holy Predecessors], and his companions." (582) Then they resolved to return, and they saw a caravan going to Medina. They exaggerated to them that: "When you reach Yathrib, tell the people of Muhammad that all of Quraysh are returning with the intention of your destruction." And the people of this caravan conveyed this news in Hamra' As'ad to the companions of the Messenger, peace be upon him [and his holy Predecessors], and they greatly threatened them with seriousness (583); the Muslims felt no kind of uncertainty, but rather, their conviction increased in the matters, and the essence of this story was repeated among them – a poem:

footnote.p: (577) In the source: (more or less).
(578) In the source: (set up in the Imperial Camp).
(579) Surah Al-Imran (3): 172.
(580) In the source: (outcome).

(581) Al-Ḥamawī said: Ruhaa' means spirit (ruḥ) and rest (raaḥa) from resting (istiraaḥa), and the Day of Spirit (Yawm Ruḥ) means a good (ṭayyib) day... What we have said is supported by what Ibn al-Kalbī mentioned, saying: "When Tubbaa' returned from fighting the people of Medina intending Mecca, he camped at Ruhaa', so he remained there and rested, and named it: Ruhaa'." He was asked, "Why was it named Ruhaa'?" He replied: "Because of its openness and tranquility." It is from the work of al-Far' for about forty days. . . See: Mu'jam al-Buldan 3 / 76.
(582) In [A] and the source (ghaarimat) is also read.
(583) In [A] mistakenly: (hadd) has been mentioned.

para.p: هر کسی تدبیر کاری میکند
Everyone devises a plan for their affairs
ما رها کردیم با نعم الوکیل
We have turned away, trusting in the Best Guardian (Naeem al-Wakeel)

As the verse states: (الَّذِینَ قالَ لَهُمُ النّاسُ إِنَّ النّاسَ قَدْ جَمَعُوا لَکُمْ فَاخْشَوْهُمْ فَزادَهُمْ إِیماناً وَقالُوا حَسْبُنَا اللّهُ وَنِعْمَ الْوَکِیلُ…) (Those to whom the people said, "Indeed, the people have gathered against you, so fear them." But it only increased them in faith, and they said, "Sufficient for us is Allah, and He is the Best Guardian…) (584) until the end of [two] (585) other verses, correcting this state and speech.

footnote.p: (584) Surah Aal Imran (3): 173.
(585) The addition is from the source.

para.p: And it is narrated that: In that situation, no one remained with Ma'bad ibn Abi Ma'bad Khaza'i, because the tribe of Khaz'a had an affection and a long-standing bond with the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), who had come from Tihamah as a sign of condolence and sympathy to be in the service of that Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny and sacred lineage), after the Muslim army had passed through Hamla' Asad and returned to their homes. He reached Abu Sufyan and the Quraysh in Ruha, and they asked him: What news do you have? He replied: Muhammad (peace be upon him and his holy progeny and sacred lineage) is with a large group who have stayed behind from Uhud and are on their way to you. They will catch up soon, and it is determined that no one will be able to resist them. That word had a strong effect, and the Quraysh became afraid, seeing no possibility of a direct return, and they abandoned that intention. The Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny and sacred lineage) stayed in Hamla' Asad for three days and sent three men from Bani Sulaym to spy on the polytheists, two of whom (586) fell into the hands of the enemy and were killed; and the Master of Messengers (peace be upon him and his holy progeny and sacred lineage) sent a group to bury both of them in one grave. From the congregation in that expedition, the disbelievers (Kuffar) of Abu Ghura, a poet who was among the captives of Badr, the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) conferred favor upon him, freeing him, and made an agreement with him that: He would not fight against the Muslims thereafter; and he broke this covenant, being present at Uhud, and was again taken captive by the hands of the companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny). When he was brought before the luminous visage of the Master of Humanity, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), he wept profusely, saying, "Free me just once more." He replied, "I will not do such a thing, so that you may lower your hand to your beard in Mecca and say, 'I played with Muhammad (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) twice.'"

footnote.p: (586) The addition is from the source.

para.p: And a reliable report stated: « لایلدغ المؤمن من جُحر مرتین » "A believer is not bitten from the same hole twice", and in this moment, the news arrived. Then they killed Abu Ghura, and on Friday, peace returned to Medina in the company of safety and tranquility and the duration of that absence was no more than five nights, and Allah knows best. (587) End.

footnote.p: (587) Duraj al-Durur: 477-481.

para.p: The noble scholar Muhaddith also mentioned this story in "Rawdat al-Ahbab," nearly in these same words, and during his narration, he said:

He made Ibn Umm Maktum a leader (Amir) in Medina and summoned his banner (Alam), giving it to Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him) – and according to another narration, to Abu Bakr al-Siddiq – and they left Medina, going as far as the place of Hamara' Asad… until the end of the story. (588)

footnote.p: (588) Rawdat al-Ahbab, folios: 81-82.

para.p: It is thus rejected on the grounds that: there is no mention or trace of this meaning <83> in the famous books of the biographies of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) (seerah) and history (tarikh), therefore, transmitting the phrases of some trusted books of sirah and tarikh of the Ahle Tasannun that include an explanation and detail of this expedition (ghazwah) must be conceivable here. So, know that it is mentioned in the book "Daraj al-Durar":

And in that year – meaning the fourth year – the Ghazwah of Banu al-Nadir took place. Those knowledgeable in the matters of the art of historical narratives and sirah have investigated that: after the Master of the Messengers, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, rendered the pure land covered with the dust of the hooves of His Perspective (Tarsh) along with His Honor, the conduct of the opponents with him, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, occurred in various ways. Quraysh and their followers set about to engage in warfare and combat, while the tribes of Arabia withdrew from battle and set their feet in the garment of waiting, until the outcome of the situation of that lord, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, became clear (589). After that, groups (590) would find themselves gradually entering into the ranks of followers.

footnote.p: (589) In the source: "became clear."
(590) The addition is from the source.

para.p: The conditions of this group were also diverse; some wished for the banners of the emergence of the Muhammadan religion, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, to be raised, like Banu Khuza'ah, while another group desired the opposite, like Banu Bakr, and some spent their time indifferent, neither for nor against.

And the hypocrites of Medina outwardly appeared to be with the Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, in a state that they were being taken away, and inwardly, it was entrusted to them the path of friendship with His enemies.

And the Jews of Qaynuqa, Banu Nadir, and [Banu] Qurayza, in the early days, fell within the circle of the covenant and pact of the Master of Souls and Hearts (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), on the condition that they would not fight with the Muslims and would show friendship and enmity with their friends and enemies (591); and among these three peoples, the Banu Qaynuqa were the first to violate the covenant after the event of Badr, and the account of that group was mentioned in its place. Finally, the Banu Qurayza also broke their oath, and the details of that group's story will be recorded after the mention of al-Ahzab.

footnote.p: (591) In the source: (nunmayand), and the meaning is that they would be friends with their friends and enemies with their enemies.

para.p: From the Banu Nadir, this year, the breaking of the pact became evident, and they bade farewell to their homes, and they had a stronghold in the village of Zahra (592) in the regions of Farah (593) and were residing there.

footnote.p: (592) Zahra is the name of a location in Medina; see Taj al-Arewis 1 / 485, al-Qamus al-Muhit 2 / 43.

(593) In the source: (Far'a). Al-Hamawi said: Far'a is a village in the outskirts of Medina, to the left of al-Suqiya, eight burds (a form of distance) from Medina on the road to Mecca, and it was said: four nights.
It has a pulpit, date palms, and abundant water... It is like a district, and in it are several villages, pulpits, and mosques of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny).
See: Mu'jam al-Buldan 4 / 252.

para.p: In that area, Amr ibn Umayyah al-Damri, having escaped from the calamity of the expense, turned his attention to staying in the company of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and in one of the houses, he encountered two men from Banu Amir who were under the protection of the final Prophet of the Age (peace be upon him and his holy progeny). Umar was not aware of the details of their covenant and pact. After he learned that they were from Banu Amir, he endured it until they fell asleep, then he killed them both, thinking that he had, to some extent, made amends for the past. When he reached the Assembly of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and presented that story, the Prophet replied: "You have killed two who were in our protection. It is now necessary to engage in paying their blood money." And because there was a bond and friendship between Banu Amir and Banu Nadir, the Master of Prophets (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), along with a group of companions, one of whom was Ali al-Murtaza (peace be upon him), honored the tribe of Banu Nadir to complete the important matter of the mentioned blood money, and they sat in the courtyard of the houses of that group. He expressed the purpose he had with the notables of the people, and they agreed to carry it out. Secretly, they said to one another: "We will not find a more suitable opportunity than this to ease the matter for Muhammad (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)." The duty is to drop a stone from the roof onto his head and completely free ourselves of him." Salama ibn Mishkam said: "Do not pursue this thought, for he will soon receive news from the Unseen." They did not listen. Umar ibn Jahhash took responsibility for that task. At that time, Gabriel (peace be upon him) arrived with the command of the Lord of the worlds, and informed the Master of the Messengers (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) of their determination and intention. The Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) stood up on the pretext of purification from that assembly and Ali (peace be upon him) was asked to stay and he said: "You should remain here while I go to Medina, and whoever among the companions comes out of this house, send him to follow me."

By the command of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), it was acted upon, so much so that companions came out in succession from (594) that place, and hurriedly went after the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny). When they reached the Master, they said: O Messenger of Allah! (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), did you not report any news and became preoccupied? He replied: "The Jews intended treachery," and he recounted the past to his companions; and after returning to the honorable house, he sent Muhammad ibn Muslima to the Banu al-Nadir, saying: "You may stay in this land (595), and you will have ten days' grace. After that, it is ordained that whoever among this people you see will be killed." They busied themselves in arranging the matter and sought to set out, Abdullah ibn Ubayy ibn Salul, the hypocrite, sent a message to those people, saying: "Do not pay attention to the words of Muhammad (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), do not leave your home, and be assured that there are two thousand men, skilled with swords (596), who will be with me in support and assistance, and Qurayza and Ghatafan, who are also your allies, will not fail to act and will prepare the conditions of cooperation and agreement."

footnote.p: (594) The addition is from the source.
(595) In the source: (Do not stay).
(596) In the source: (Followers).

para.p: The Jews [Rejected] (597), having been deceived by the baseless promises and tales of the hypocrites, sent news to the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) that: "We will not leave our familiar dwelling in any direction, and you should not leave anything undone to the best of your ability."

footnote.p: (597) The addition is from the source.

para.p: The Master of the Worlds (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), when he heard the explanation of their claim, raised a tumult of Takbir (Allahu Akbar) that reached the skies and said: "The Jews claim to fight!" Then he made Ibn Umm Maktum his deputy in Medina, entrusted the flag to Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him), and marched an army toward them. He performed another prayer there and maintained the siege of that group for fifteen or sixteen days, cutting down some of their date palms, each of which they valued more than a beloved slave, as the verse: (ما قَطَعْتُمْ مِنْ لِینَة…) (You do not cut down any tree...) (598) indicates; and the Jews would rain down stones and arrows from behind their stone fortress. Ultimately, the hypocrites of Medina and the supporters of [the tribe of] Banu Qurayzah and Ghatafan lost hope, and the Presence of the True One cast terror into their hearts until they became content with withdrawal, arranging for Muhammad ibn Muslima to be in charge of that group, so that each of the three village chiefs could take a camel-load of food for the journey. In another narration, it is stated that from the wealth they could carry, the camels were able to bear – excluding weapons – they made it a certainty upon that people and sent them away. And Yamin ibn Umayr and Abu Sa'id ibn Wahb (599) were from that group.

footnote.p: (598) Surah Al-Hashr (59): 5.
(599) Yamin ibn Amr ibn Kab and Abu Sa'd ibn Wahb, as in Al-Isabah 7/146. Ibn Hajar explicitly stated in Al-Isabah 7/169 that (Abu Sa'id) is an error.

para.p: They entered the circle of the people of Islam, and the belongings, possessions, and lives of those two infallible ones remained intact; and the rest of the Jews were expelled, most of them going to the towns of Edr'at (600) and Jericho (601), and the family of Abi al-Haqiq and the family of Hayy ibn Akhtab joined the Khaybaris, and all their wealth and weapons [which] – were fifty helmets and fifty shields and three hundred and forty swords – the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him [and his holy progeny], took into his own possession and did not impose a fifth on them, preparing it instead for expenses. And there is a narration that states: he allowed a group of the Emigrants (Muhajireen) and a few of the Helpers (Ansaar) to benefit from that. (602) End.

footnote.p: (600) [A and B] Edr'at - with the ر (ra) pronounced softly and the ر (ra) opened - is a city in Syria. (12) [Al-Hamawi said: EDR'AT - with the initial vowel, then a pause, and the ر (ra) softened, and an unmarked ع (ayn), and an added ا (alif) and ت (ta) - is like a plural of A'darat - a plural of ذراع (dhira') - a plural of something small, and it is a town on the outskirts of Syria, beyond the land of Balqa and Amman. See: Mu'jam al-Buldan 1 / 130].

(601) [A and B] Jericho - with the initial vowel and a softened ر (ra) like Zalkha - is a city in Syria, and it is also called اَرْیَحا (Aryiha) - with the initial vowel like Karbala. Muntaha al-Arab [Page: 481]. (12) [Al-Hamawi said: Jericho - with the initial vowel, then a softened ر (ra), and a silent ی (ya), and a ع (ayn) unmarked, and in brief, and some have narrated it with a خ (kha) with dots - is a Hebrew term, and it is the city of the Giants in the Jordanian valley in the land of Syria. Note: Mu'jam al-Buldan 1 / 165].
(602) Daraj al-Durur: 388 - 492.

para.p: And in the “Roudat al-Ahbab,” the account of this expedition is mentioned in words very similar to these. (603)

footnote.p: (603) Roudat al-Ahbab, folios: 81 - 82.

para.p: And Husain ibn Muhammad ibn al-Hasan al-Diyarbakri narrated in "Tarikh Khamis" regarding this same expedition:

وفی المنتقی : ثم إن رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم خرج یوم السبت ، وصلّی فی مسجد قبا ومعه نفر من الأصحاب ، منهم : أبو بکر وعمر وعلی [ ( علیه السلام ) ] والزبیر وطلحة وسعد بن معاذ واسید بن حصین وسعد بن عبادة ، ثم أتی منازل بنی النضیر وکلّمهم فی دیة الرجلین من بنی سلیم الذین قتلهما عمرو بن أُمیة الضمری ، ویستعینهم فی عقدها (604) ، وکانوا قد عاهدوا النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم علی ترک القتال ، وعلی أن یعینوه فی الدیات – کما مرّ – وکان لهم حلف مع بنی عامر ; قالوا : نعم یا أبا القاسم ! قد آن لک أن تأتینا وتسألنا حاجة ، اجلس حتّی نطعمک ونعطیک الذی تسألنا ، فجلس رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم الی جدار یهودی وجلس أصحابه ، فهمّ الیهود بالغدر ، فخلی بعضهم إلی بعض ، قالوا : إنکم لم تجدوا محمداً أقرب منه الآن ، فمن یظهر علی هذا البیت ویطرح علیه صخرةً فیریحنا منه ؟ فقال عمرو بن جحاش : أنا . – قیل : کان ذلک بإشارة من حیی بن أخطب – ، فقال سلام بن مشکم : لا تفعلوا ، والله لیُخبرنّ بما هممتم به .

And in al-Muntaqa it is mentioned: Then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) went out on Saturday and prayed in the Mosque of Quba with a few of the companions, including: Abu Bakr, Umar <85>, Ali (peace be upon him), and Zubayr, Talha, Sa'd ibn Mu'adh, Usayd ibn Hujayn, and Sa'd ibn Ubadah. Then he went to the houses of Banu al-Nadir and spoke to them about the blood money (diya) for the two men from Banu Sulaym who were killed by Amr ibn Umayyah al-Damri, and sought their assistance in securing it (604). They had previously pledged allegiance to the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) to refrain from fighting and to assist him in matters of blood money, as mentioned earlier, and they had an alliance with Banu Amir. They said: Yes, O Abu al-Qasim! It is time for you to come to us and ask us for a need. Sit until we provide you with food and give you what you request. So, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) sat by the wall of a Jew, and his companions sat with him. The Jews contemplated treachery, and some of them approached each other, saying: You will not find Muhammad closer than he is now. Who will show superiority over this house and throw a stone on him, relieving us of him? Amr ibn Jahhash said: I will do it. – It is said that this was by the gesture of Hayy ibn Akhtab. – But Salam ibn Mushkam said: Do not do it. By Allah, he will be informed of what you are contemplating.

footnote.p: (604) In the source: (Iqalahuma).

para.p: [ فأمسک الله یده وعصمه ] (605) وجاء جبرئیل فأخبره فخرج صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم راجعاً إلی المدینة ، ثم دعا علیاً [ ( علیه السلام ) ] فقال : « لا تبرح مکانک ، فمن خرج علیک من أصحابک فسألک عنی فقل : توجّه إلی المدینة » ، ففعل ذلک حتّی انضمّوا إلیه ، ثم تبعوه ولحقوا به . کذا فی المنتقی . وفی الاکتفاء : خرج راجعاً إلی المدینة وترک أصحابه فی مجالسهم . (606) انتهی .

So Amr ibn Jahhash went to a large millstone to throw it on him, [Then Allah restrained his hand and protected him] (605) and Gabriel (Jibril) came and informed him, so he (peace be upon him) went out [and upon his family] (peace be upon them) returning to Medina. Then he called Ali (peace be upon him) and said: "Do not leave your place, so if anyone from your companions comes to you and asks about me, tell them: He has gone to Medina." He did this until they joined him, then they followed him and caught up with him. Thus is mentioned in the Muntaqa. And in the Iktifa, it is stated that he returned to Medina and left his companions in their gatherings. (606)

footnote.p: (605) The addition is from the source.
(606) [A and B] In the events of the fourth year, compared in two copies of Khamis. (12). [Tarikh Khamis 1 / 460].

para.p: Then, at this time when the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) went to Medina out of fear of the treachery of the Jews, he did not appoint Abu Bakr as the commander over the army, and where could the army have been at that time that would have made him a commander?! There were only a few companions who had gone with the noble Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) to the Jews for conversation, not for battle, and whatever that Noble One (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was commanded to do, he entrusted to the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him).

And if the intention is that after this incident, when the Respected Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) had gone to fight Banu Nadir with an army and had besieged them, he came to Medina one night and appointed Abu Bakr as the commander of the army, then establishing this matter with a sound narration is necessary, and it is mentioned in the books of history and battles, such as "Rawdat al-Ahbab," "Daraj al-Durar," "Mawahib ladunniyah," and "Tarikh Khamis", "Seer-e Kazerooni" and "Insan al-Uyun" and the book "Al-Rawd al-Aniq" by al-Suhaili find no mention or indication of this meaning or statement.

However, what is said is: In the sixth year, when he set out for the expedition of Banu Lahyan (607), that tribe, having heard of the attention of that Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, fortified themselves on the mountaintops. The Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, stayed for a day or two in their home and sent expeditions to the surrounding areas, among them a significant expedition led by Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, which was granted permission to head towards Kura' al-Ghamim.

footnote.p: (607) [A and B] Lahyan - with both a broken and a opened laam - a tribe from Hudhayl represented by the dotted dhaal. (12) [See: Kitab al-Ayn 3/297, Fath al-Bari 1/184, and al-Isti'ab 2/779].

para.p: So know that in the reliable and famous books of history and chronicle, no mention or indication is found of Abu Bakr's leadership in this expedition, just as is mentioned in the book "Daraj al-Durar":

And in the month of Rabi al-Awwal in the sixth year of Hijrah, the expedition of Banu Lahyan occurred. The scholars of seerah mention that the Master of Messengers, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, intended to take action against the companions of Raji' (608) – who had captured (609) and killed Asim, Khubaib (610), and some others were – seeking revenge, then he made Ibn Um Maktum a governor in Medina, and set out with two hundred men and twenty horses to the Levant under the pretext of paying attention to the direction of Sham; he intended to unexpectedly catch them <86> unaware, but most likely that group had been informed, or they themselves had taken precautions (611) and had fortified themselves in the mountains. When the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) arrived there, he did not see the enemy, and he sent the majority (612) of the cavalry towards Asfan, two horsemen from them went as far as Kuraʿ al-Ghumaym (613), and the intention was that the Quraysh would experience a real sense of fear.

footnote.p: (608) [A and B] Raji' - with a opened raa' and a broken jīm, and a u in the end - the name of a location in the land of Hudhayl, where the incident occurred nearby in Safar of the fourth year. (12) Al-Hamawi said: Ibn Ishaq and al-Waqidi stated that Rabi' is a water source of Hudhayl, and near al-Hudha' between Mecca and Ta'if. See: Mu'jam al-Buldan 3/29.
(609) The addition is from the source.
(610) In the source: (Khubaib).
(611) In [A], it mistakenly says: (to himself).
(612) In [A], it mistakenly says: (grains).
(613) [A and B] Kuraaʿ al-Ghumaym: a valley between the two sacred mosques, two stations from Mecca, and a location close to Mecca. (12). [See: Mu'jam al-Buldan 4 / 214, 443].

para.p: And one narration states that during that journey he himself reached Asfan. (614) End.

footnote.p: (614) Darj al-Durar: 559.

para.p: However, what the author of "Rawdat al-Ahbab" said is that:

Abu Bakr... sent ten horsemen to Ghumaym to let the news of the Islamic army reach the Quraysh and to instill fear in their hearts, and they went to that place, and encountered no enemy in any agreement, then returned to the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and resumed accompanying that lord (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) until they returned to Medina, and the duration of their absence on that journey was fourteen nights and days. (615) End.

footnote.p: (615) Rawdat al-Ahbaab, pages: 96-97.

para.p: So, since the source of this narration has not been mentioned, it cannot be trusted, and how can it be reliable when Qastalani, Ibn Hajar, and Ayni have acknowledged that the leadership of Abu Bakr (Abu Bakr) is not established outside of the three mentioned expeditions (sariyyah)?!

And even if we assume its correctness, then the claim of the Addressee that this expedition was significant is undoubtedly a falsehood, slander, deception, and misrepresentation, as this expedition was not major; rather, the significant expedition was that of Muhammad ibn Muslimum, in which, as explicitly stated by the author of "Rawdat al-Ahbab", there were thirty horsemen, who charged upon the enemies and killed several unbelievers (kuffar), and captured one hundred fifty camels and three thousand sheep as spoils (616); and in this expedition, there were only ten horsemen, who did not encounter any enemy in battle nor did they seize any spoils.

footnote.p: (616) Rawdat al-Ahbab, p. 96-97.

para.p: Furthermore, the sending of Abu Bakr and ten others for a necessary task does not imply that Abu Bakr had leadership over them.

It is from this that Qastalani, despite admitting this meaning that the leadership of Abu Bakr outside of the three mentioned expeditions is not established, said in "Mawahib Ladunniyah" regarding this raid:
وبعث أبا بکر فی عشرة فوارس لتسمع بهم قریش فیذعرهم فأتوا کراع الغمیم ثم رجعوا ولم یلقوا کیداً . (617) (618) انتهی .

And he sent Abu Bakr with ten horsemen to make themselves heard by the Quraysh, thereby frightening them. so they came to the hoofs of Al-Ghamim, then returned without encountering any plot. (617) (618) End.

footnote.p: (617) In the source: (one). See: Al-Mawahiib al-Ladunniyah 1 / 256.

(618) [A and B] in "Bulugh al-Maram" briefly records that in "Seerah Shamiyyah": Then he sent two horsemen - and it was said, Abu Bakr with ten horsemen - to be heard by the Quraysh, thus frightening them, so they came to the hoofs of Al-Ghamim, and did not encounter any plot [one]. It is finished. [Bulugh al-Maram: Sabil al-Huda wa'l-Rishad (Seerah Shamiyyah) 5 / 30]. And this statement is explicit that Abu Bakr's sending in this expedition is a matter of disagreement, rather the apparent wording suggests that the more reasonable conclusion is that he only sent two individuals. The term (it was said) according to the insight of the virtuous Rashid, indicates weakness and uncertainty. (12) H.

para.p: Thus, it became clear that Qastalani also does not consider the sending of Abu Bakr with these ten horsemen as a reason for Abu Bakr's leadership, otherwise, the contradiction between this statement and the one mentioned in the "Sharh Sahih al-Bukhari" would be inevitable.

However, what he said: in the battle of Tabuk, the command of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was implemented, that the forces of support (junood nasrat) should gather at the Thaniyat al-Wida, outside the city of Madinah al-Munawwarah, with the Commander of the army being the Truthful (Siddiq), and the members of the army were arranged in accordance with him.

Therefore, Abu Bakr's leadership in this army is not established. Indeed, the Ahle Tasannun claim that the banner of war (619) was in the hands of Abu Bakr in this expedition, and in a statement, assuming its correctness, the direction was that Almighty God had informed the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) that in this expedition, there would be no opportunity for combat and fighting the enemy, and that, aside from the use of sword and spear, the people of aggression would be obedient and submissive to that Prophet. Therefore, at the time of departing for this expedition, he appointed Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him) as his caliph in Medina, who would receive the banner of war from that Prophet in all battles; thus, if he gave the banner of war to Abu Bakr in this expedition, it could not imply his superiority and virtue.

footnote.p: (619) In [A] mistakenly (here) it is stated: (was).

para.p: Similarly, delegating the presentation of the army's affairs to Abu Bakr – assuming its correctness – cannot be taken as evidence of his virtue; and the statement is concerning the acceptance of significant responsibilities, not trivial actions!

However, what is said: On the day of the Khaybar expedition, when the noble Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was afflicted with a headache, and it was during the siege of the fortress, he appointed Abu Bakr as his deputy and sent him for the conquest of the fortress, and on that day, Abu Bakr displayed fierce fighting.

Then it is rejected by stating that mentioning the story of Khaybar here is entirely pointless; because the scholars of the Shia have not denied the story of Khaybar, rather what they have said is that this story is a cause of a blemish on Abu Bakr, not evidence of his virtue, just as Sayyid Murtaza Ilm al-Huda stated in his book "Shafi":

وربّما ذکروا : إنه أخّر عن الولایات وقدّم غیره ، وإنه عزل عن أداء سورة البراءة بعد أن توجّه بها ، وعزل أیضاً عن الجیش الذی بعثه لفتح خیبر بعد أن فتح (620) أثره ، وأورد الرسول [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله ) ] عقیب عزله من القول ما لا شک فی خروجه مخرج التهجین والتوبیخ . . حتّی أن کثیراً من أصحابنا ذهبوا إلی أن ما تضمنه قوله علیه [ وآله ] السلام فی تلک الحال من الوصف لأمیرالمؤمنین ( علیه السلام ) بمحبته لله ورسوله [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله وسلم ) ] ومحبة الله ورسوله له یدلّ علی إنتفائه عمن عزل عن الولایة . . ویذکرون أشیاء کثیرة من هذا الجنس مذکورة فی الکتب المشهورة ویستخرجون من جمیعها کون الرجل ممّن لا یصلح للإمامة ! (621)

And they may mention: He was delayed from the governorships and other positions were given precedence over him, and he was dismissed from performing a Surah of Bara'ah (Repentance) after he had been assigned to it, and he was also removed from the army that he sent him to open Khaybar after he had opened (620) its aftermath, and the Messenger [ (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) mentioned following his removal words that undoubtedly appeared to be in the nature of reprimand and reproach . . So much so that many of our companions believed that what his statement [peace be upon him and his holy progeny] contained in that situation described Amir al-Momineen (peace be upon him) as loving God and His Messenger [(peace be upon him and his holy progeny)] and God's and His Messenger's love for him indicated its absence from one who was removed from leadership . . They mention many such things recorded in well-known books and deduce from all of them that the man was one who was not suitable for imamate! (621)

footnote.p: (620) In the source: (May Allah curse it).

para.p: The implication of some narrations from that time is that Abu Bakr took the banner of the Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) without the permission of that holy individual and went to fight the people of Khaybar! Just as Wali Allah mentioned in his epistle “Tafzeel al-Shaikhain” (The Superiority of the Two Shaykhs):

عن بریدة الأسلمی قال : کان رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم ربّما أخذته الشقیقة ، فیلبث الیوم أو الیومین لا یخرج ، فلمّا نزل بخیبر أخذته الشقیقة ، فلم یخرج إلی الناس ، وإن أبا بکر أخذ رایة رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم . . ثم نهض وقاتل قتالا شدیداً ، ثم رجع

From Buraidah al-Aslami, who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) would sometimes be afflicted with migraine, causing him to remain indoors for a day or two without going out. When he arrived at Khaybar, he was afflicted with a migraine and did not go out to the people. Then, Abu Bakr took the banner of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), advanced, and fought fiercely, but then returned."
. أخرجه الحاکم (622) .
Reported by al-Hakim. (622)

footnote.p: (622) [A] in Ma'athir Abi Bakr. (12). [Qurat al-Aynayn: 187].

para.p: It must be understood that his statement: (And he did not come out to the people, although Abu Bakr took the banner of The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) explicitly indicates that the Noble Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not come out of his blessed tent, and Abu Bakr took the banner himself and went.
Apart from this, Abu Bakr, on that day, out of extreme fear, chose to flee rather than stay, until the Noble Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) said:
« لأُعطینّ الرایة رجلا یحبّ الله ورسوله ویحبّه الله ورسوله ، کرّار غیر فرّار » .
"I will give the banner to a man who loves Allah and His Messenger, and who is loved by Allah and His Messenger, vigorous, not fleeing."

And this noble hadith indicates that Abu Bakr did not find himself in the battle of jihad against the disbelievers, but was rather fleeing, and he did not love Allah and His Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), nor did Allah and His Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) love him.
Fakhr al-Razi also accepted the implication of this hadith regarding the flight of Abu Bakr and Umar, as he stated in the book "Arba'in":

أمّا الحجة السادسة ، وهی التمسک بقصة خیبر ، فجوابها : إن ذلک الکلام یفید أن مجموع الصفات المذکورة فی مدح الثانی غیر حاصل للأول ، فلمّا قال : « لأُعطینّ الرایة رجلا یحب الله ورسوله ، ویحبه الله ورسوله ، کرّاراً غیر فرّار » ، فهذا یدلّ علی أن ذلک المجموع ما کان حاصلا [ لأبی بکر وعمر ; لأن کونه کرّاراً غیر فرّار ما کان حاصلا ] (623) فیهما ، فکان ذلک المجموع غیر حاصل فیهما ، وعدم کونه کرّاراً غیر فرّار لا یوجب نقصاناً [ فی الفضیلة ] (624) ، ألا تری أن الأنبیاء أفضل من الملائکة عند الشیعة مع أنّا نقطع أنه لیس للأنبیاء من القدرة الحسیة ذرّة من القدرة التی للملائکة ؟ ! (625) انتهی .

As for the sixth proof, which is the reliance on the story of Khaybar, its answer is: That statement suggests that the totality of the qualities mentioned in praise of the second is not possessed by the first. So when he said, "I will give the banner to a man who loves Allah and His Messenger, and who is loved by Allah and His Messenger, vigorous, not fleeing (karar ghayr farrar)," this indicates that this totality was not present [for Abu Bakr and Umar; for being vigorous, not fleeing was not something found] (623) in either of them, so that totality was not achieved in both of them, and his not being one who attacks again and again (but rather runs away does not imply a deficit [in virtue] (624), do you not see that the prophets are considered better than the angels in the view of the Shia, while we <88> firmly believe that the prophets have not even a particle of the tangible ability that the angels possess?! (625) End.

footnote.p: (623) The addition is from the source.
(624) The addition is from the source.

(625) [A and B] The original was supported, a manuscript of "U'arbaʿīn" is available in the library of Ayatollah Fī al-ʿAAlamīn, the esteemed Aliyyin Maab, our master Seyyid Dilidar Ali Sahib - may Allah exalt his status in the Abode of Peace - and a copy is also available with me by Divine grace. (12). [U'arbaʿīn: 478].

para.p: As for Abu Bakr's (Abi Bakr) strong display in the Battle of Khaybar (Khaybar) on that day,

it is impossible, rather, it is explicitly clear from the implication of « لأُعطینّ الرایة . . » "I will certainly give the banner…" until the end that he fled, just as Fakhr al-Razi (Fakhr al-Razi) also accepted.

What is truly astonishing is that when Ibn Taymiyyah saw the story of Khaybar clearly stated as a detriment to the two Shaykhs, he denied the very act of the two Shaykhs going to battle (ghazwah) before the Commander of the Faithful (Amir al-Momineen) (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and said that: This notion is one of the falsehoods, as he stated in response to "Minhaj al-Karamah":

الذی ثبت فی الصحیح : إن علیاً [ ( علیه السلام ) ] کان غائباً عن خیبر ، لم یکن حاضراً فیها ، فتخلّف عن الغزاة ; لأنه کان أرمد ، ثم إنه شقّ علیه التخلف عن النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فلحقه ، فقال النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم قبل قدومه : « لأُعطینّ الرایة رجلا یحبّ الله ورسوله ، ویحبّه الله ورسوله ، یفتح الله علی یدیه » ، ولم تکن الرایة قبل ذلک لا لأبی بکر ولا لعمر ولا قرّبها واحد منهما ، بل هذا من الأکاذیب ، ولهذا قال عمر : فما أحببت الإمارة إلاّ یومئذ . . إلی آخره (626) .

What is established in the authentic (ṣahih) texts is that Ali (ʿAli) [peace be upon him and his holy progeny] was absent from Khaybar, he was not present there, so he stayed back from the fighters (ghazin); because he was suffering from an eye ailment (armad), then he was late in following the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), so he caught up with him. The Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) said before his arrival: "I will certainly give the banner to a man who loves Allah and His Messenger, and who is loved by Allah and His Messenger. Allah will grant victory through his hands," and the banner had not been given to either Abu Bakr or Umar before that, nor had either of them approached it. Rather, this is one of the lies. For this reason, Umar said, "I did not desire leadership except on that day…" to the end (626).

footnote.p: (626) [A and B] In response to the seventh argument, from the evidences taken from the Sunnah regarding the Caliphate of the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him), this is mentioned in the Second Method. (12) [Manhaj al-Sunnah 7 / 365-366].

para.p: Then why does the interlocutor argue and insist on something that is among the lies in the eyes of his Imams? !

In this contradiction and inconsistency, a sensible and rational mind should reflect that whenever they see a single matter as something that detracts from the Caliphs, they rise to deny and contradict it (627); and whenever they consider it to affirm a virtue – even if it ultimately leads to disgrace and humiliation – they brace themselves to establish and validate it (628)!

footnote.p: (627) In [A], it mistakenly says: "sees."
(628) Chust: quick and agile.

para.p: As for what he said, that in the seventh year, Abu Bakr was sent to confront a group of the Banu Kulab, and Salamatu ibn al-Akwa' became appointed as Abu Bakr's messenger, and he was with the Banu Kulab, he fought (muharabah) and killed some, taking others captive, and brought them, and he was also the commander of the army (amir al-jaysh) of Abu Bakr al-Siddiq over the Banu Fazarah.

Then its response is this: The claim of Qasṭalani, Ibn Hajar, and ʿAyni – the commentators of "Sahih al-Bukhari" – regarding the leadership (imarat) of Abu Bakr is established in these two expeditions (sariyah). However, the expressions in the books of military campaigns (ghazwa) indicate that Qasṭalani, ʿAyni, and Ibn Hajar were shown an error, having taken the expedition of the Banu Kulab and the expedition of the Banu Fazarah as two separate expeditions, whereas in reality, it was one expedition. However, there is a discrepancy in the narrations regarding whether this expedition of Abu Bakr was towards the Banu Kulab or towards the Banu Fazarah. The latter is considered correct, as Muslim narrated it, just as Qasṭalani himself said in "Mawahib Laduniyyah":
ثم سریة أبی بکر الصدیق إلی بنی کلاب [ بنجد ] (629) ناحیة ضربة فی شعبان سنة سبع ، ویقال : إلی فزارة ، فأسر منه جماعة وقتل آخرین ، وفی صحیح مسلم : فزارة ، وهو الصواب . (630) انتهی .

"Then the expedition (sariyah) of Abu Bakr al-Siddiq to the Banu Kulab [in Najd] (629) was an area called Durbah in Shaʿban in the seventh year. It is said: to the Fazarah, and he took many captive and killed others. And in Sahih Muslim: Fazarah, and this is correct." (630) End.

footnote.p: (629) The addition is from the source.
(630) Mawaahib Laduniyyah 1 / 294.

para.p: And Husain ibn Muhammad al-Hasan al-Diyarbakri mentioned in "Tarikh Khamis fi Ahwal al-Nafs al-Nafis" regarding the events of the seventh year:
ثم فی شعبان هذه السنة بعث أبا بکر الصدیق إلی بنی کلاب فی ناحیة ضربة (631) ، ویقال : إلی فزارة ، کما فی صحیح مسلم ، وهو الصواب . (632) انتهی .
"Then, in Shaʿban of this year, Abu Bakr al-Siddiq sent [an expedition] to the Banu Kulab in the area of Dhurba (631), it is said: to Fazara, as in Sahih Muslim, and this is correct. (632) End.

footnote.p: (631) In the source: (Dhuriyya). Ibn al-Athir said: Dhuriyya is a well in Hijaz, to which the protection of Dhuriyya is attributed. It is said that it was named after Dhuriyya, daughter of Rabia ibn Nizar. See: al-Nihaya 1 / 232.
(632) Tarikh al-Khamis 2 / 60.

para.p: And in "Uqd Thamin fi Tarikh Baladallah al-Amin," composed by Taqi al-Din (633), it is mentioned:

footnote.p: (633) 3- [A and B] The author of "Uqd Thamin fi Tarikh Baladallah al-Amin," Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Ali ibn Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahman, titled Taqi al-Din, was a Persian [whose base] from Mecca, Maliki, and he mentioned his own situation in this book, as well as the approbations of the scholars of his time - which were written on his works - and here I will quote some excerpts from Ibn Hajar al-Asqalani, the author of "Fath al-Bari," that he wrote about this book, and it is as follows: As for now; I have found this unique, remarkable history in its composition and strange in its genre, and I deemed it to surpass the compositions in this field with the sincerity of its essence and to be specialized with the absolute dignity of its words and meanings. It is a noble work on a noble subject for a noble city, which Allah has chosen and approved, which [the author] has beautifully articulated and refined in its elegance, the Master, Imam, Unique, Skillful, with a pure lineage, and a sharp, intelligent mind, Mufti [Taqi] al-Din, Mughni [Mufti] al-Muslimin, defender of the sanctity of jurisprudence and hadith, along with what is added to this of piety, the truth of which in name befits its essence, and worship, asceticism, and humility befitting one whom Allah has chosen. May Allah inspire him to be grateful for this blessing and preserve him for safeguarding the Sunnah. Said and written by: Ahmad ibn Ali al-Asqalani… and so on. (12). [Uqd Thamin 2 / 59 - 60].

para.p: ثم سریة أبی بکر . . . إلی بنی کلاب ، ویقال : فزارة بناحیة ضربة فی شعبان ، فسبی منهم جماعة وقتل آخرین (634) .
Then the expedition of Abu Bakr... to Banu Kalab, and it is said: to Fazara in the vicinity, struck in Sha'ban, and from them, a group was taken captive and others were killed. (634)

footnote.p: (634) Al-Aqd al-Thamin 1 / 257 (printed by Mu'assasat al-Risalah).

para.p: Thus, based on this, the authority of Abu Bakr can be established as lasting only in one expedition (<89>) during this prolonged time and extended period, except if it is believed that the Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), in the opinion of his audience and leaders – God forbid – was in need of Abu Bakr, and that without his presence, no religious matters could be successfully concluded, and major tasks would remain incomplete, making the authority of Abu Bakr in this one expedition also nothing but absolute falsehood and sheer lie!

However, what is said to be mentioned in "Ma'arij" and "Habib al-Siyar" is that: after the Battle of Tabuk, some Bedouins came in [the presence of] the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and said that a group of Bedouins had gathered in the Valley of Sand, claiming to raid. The Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) gave his insignia to Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, made him the commander of the army, and sent him to that group.

Therefore, reasoning with this story to demonstrate the virtue of Abu Bakr is akin to reasoning with the verse: ( لا تَقْرَبُوا الصَّلاةَ ) (Do not go near prayer) (635) to indicate the non-obligation of prayer; because after [this] statement, which the Addresse has narrated, what is mentioned in "Ma'arij" and "Habib al-Siyar" is explicit in the rout of Abu Bakr and also the rout of Umar, and it clearly indicates that nothing commendable occurred from the two Shaykhs in this expedition other than rout, until the one who, in the end, sent the noble Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) to suffice for this important task, and made the two Shaykhs subordinate and subject to that Immaculate One (peace be upon him and his holy progeny); and he, with wise management, discerning counsel, lofty determination, and resolute resolve, accomplished the opening of this significant matter (636), as mentioned in "Habib al-Siyar" after what the interlocutor has narrated, which states that:

footnote.p: (635) Surah An-Nisa (4): 43.
(636) Refer to Ma'arij al-Nubuwwah 4 / 242.

para.p: When Abu Bakr reached that place, he was once attacked by the disbelievers from all sides, and the army of Islam was defeated. Then, the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) bestowed another banner to the Commander of the Faithful, Umar ibn Khattab, and sent him with a group of Muslims to address that important matter. The Greatest Furqan also returned in defeat, following the way of the Sidq ibn Akbar, and Amr ibn As took charge of the eventual outcome of that affair. He too returned to Medina without accomplishing anything significant. After that, the Holy Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) established a banner for the noble Master of Authority, the Martyr (peace be upon him), and appointed him the leader of a group from the army of the Protector of Victory. He commanded that the two Shaykhs and Amr also accompany that army on that journey (637), and they must not exceed the wise decree of the King of Grace. The Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) accompanied him to the Mosque of the Confederates, the Commander of the Faithful, Ali (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and spoke of him in the following poem:

footnote.p: (637) In the source: (Mrafqat).

para.p: دعاهایی که بر لب نارسیده
Supplications that reached the unformed lips
نوید ( فاستجبناها ) شنیده
were heard as a promise (So We answered them)

and sent him towards the Valley of Sand and Ali al-Murtazah Karamallahi Wajhahu [(peace be upon him)] turned towards the goal, traveling by night and resting by day, going along one path and desiring rest. And when he neared the time of departure to the abodes of the polytheists, he moved slowly from a route that led to the mouth (638) of the valley, approaching the venerated self before the army. 'Amr ibn 'As sensed the movements and stillness of the exalted king, perceiving signs of victory and triumph, and wished to turn that important matter to loss. Accordingly, he said to the two Sheikhs...: "In this path, there are dangers from the wild beasts and wolves of this valley, and it is wise to launch a surprise attack (ghibat) from the higher side of the valley upon the enemies of the faith. (639)" The two Sheikhs shared this statement with Ali al-Murtaza (peace be upon him) but it did not find a way to his ears in acceptance. That noble one reminded them: "From the course of the mouth of the valley, it is possible to take revenge on your hearts' desires, but from the path that 'Amr ibn 'As has shown, <90> you will not be able to grasp your intended goal." Therefore, the Siddiq Akbar and the Faruq A'zam did not heed 'Amr ibn 'As's words, and he, becoming anxious, opened his mouth to frighten the soldiers, warning them against following the king of the guardians. However, they did not pay attention to his speech, and the Commander of the Faithful, Ali Karamollahi Wajhahu [ (peace be upon him) ], continued to travel the distance in accordance with the soundness of his judgment. And on a morning that coincided with the evening of the polytheists' humiliation, suddenly upon them, the sword of vengeance was set in the hands of the masters of disbelief and darkness. That group, unable to bear the sight of the lights of Zulfiqar of Haydar Karrar [ (peace be upon him) ], fled like bats from the manifest rays of the sun, and the sun of support and victory had risen from the horizon of the King's gracious favor, with the Surah Al-Aadiyaat (Surah 100) revealed in that incident, and the Messenger of Allah, with a demeanor of oncoming Prophethood (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), instructed his companions to rejoice in the victory.

footnote.p: (638) That is, the mouth of the valley.
(639) In [A], it is mistakenly written as (ghibat).

para.p: And when the Commander of the Faithful, Ali (peace be upon him), had arranged the affairs of the enemies of the faith according to his desire, banners of return were raised, and he came close to the surroundings of the city of Medina, the Master of the Prophets appointed his companions to greet the King of Men, and he himself set out ahead of them. At that moment, the eyes of the Commander of the Faithful, Haydar (peace be upon him), fell upon the Prophetic Presence (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and he dismounted from his horse. The latter said:

"O Ali (peace be upon him)! Mount, for Allah and His Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) are pleased with you." And the Commander of the Faithful, Ali (peace be upon him), began to weep from sheer joy, and the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) said:
« یا علی ! لولا أنی أشفق (640) أن یقول فیک طوائف من أُمتی ما قالت النصاری فی عیسی بن مریم ( علیه السلام ) ، لقلت فیک الیوم مقالا لا تمرّ بملأ من الناس إلاّ أخذوا التراب من تحت قدمیک » .

"O Ali! If it were not that I fear (640) some factions of my ummah would say about you what the Christians said about Jesus, son of Mary (peace be upon him), I would today speak of you in a way that no assembly of people would pass by without them taking dust from beneath your feet."

footnote.p: (640) In the source: (Atuq).

para.p: Poem:
چنین گفت آن روزخیرالاَنام [ ص ]
Thus spoke that day the Best of Creation (peace be upon him)
که اندیشه دارم ز بعضی مهام و گرنه حدیثی ز قدر علی [ ع ]
when I reflect on some affairs, and otherwise,
همی گفتم از غایت یک دلی که بر هرکه کردی ز امت گذر
I would have surely spoken of the worth of Ali (peace be upon him)
نهادی به جای قدمهاش سر زخاک قدمهاش برداشتی
in utmost oneness of heart, for on all to whom you showed consideration from the ummah, you placed their feet in your stead, you lifted from the dust of His feet
از آن آبروی دگر داشتی
as you possessed a different dignity.
انتهی (641) .
End (641).

footnote.p: (641) Habib al-Siyar 1 / 401 - 402.

para.p: Thus, this narration signifies a complete indication of the shortcomings of Abu Bakr and Umar, and from each part and each word of it, their inferiority and the ultimate grandeur of the rank of His Excellency, the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), becomes evident and manifest.

Moreover, the disbelief and hypocrisy, as well as the deceit and pretense of Amr ibn Aas also become apparent from it, and the matter of the magnificence and justice of all the companions will be undermined.

Additionally, the humiliation of the intellect of the two Shaykhs or their complicity in hypocrisy, and an intent to disrupt the support of Islam will become clear, as the words of Amr ibn Aas, which he spoke with the false intention of causing harm by obstructing this important matter through deception, were heard by attentive ears, and they presented them to the service of the one deserving of praise (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and were humiliated.

In summary; such a narration of the leadership of Abu Bakr and Umar, which includes several of their disgraces (642) (643), cannot serve as a proof of their virtue; and the people of truth will not deny such leadership, rather they will affirm it!!

footnote.p: (642) It was in [the text] (Oshan) which has been corrected.
(643) It mistakenly says here: (to) in [the text].

para.p: As some of the esteemed scholars have stated in this regard:

During the lifetime of the Master of Creation, Prophet Mohammad (peace be upon him and his holy family), the three elders (Abu Bakr, Umar and Uthman) were sometimes under the command of a slave-born [man] like Usamah, at times following an illegitimate-born [man] like Ibn al-‘Aas, and at times obedient and submissive to Abu ‘Ubaydah al-Jarrah – who was a mere gravedigger – as you have come to know. If they were ever granted leadership over a faction [of people], they returned in a manner disgraced and defeated, becoming a cause of grief for the Noble Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) and a scandal upon themselves, as occurred in the battles of Khaybar and Dhat al-Salasil. <91>

So how, merely upon the passing of that noble leader (peace be upon him and his holy family), did they suddenly become the most superior of all the companions and the most deserving of the supreme imamate and greatest leadership?!
As for what he said: [the Prophet] commanded Bilal, saying: "If I do not come, tell Abu Bakr to lead the people in prayer," as supposedly occurred during the time of ‘Asr prayer.

Then the narration from Bukhari, which contains this story, explicitly indicates that the imamate of Abu Bakr in this prayer did not take place by the permission of the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy family). Rather, it is clear from it that when the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy family) did not arrive, and the time for prayer had set in, Bilal, of his own accord, said to Abu Bakr:
"Will you lead the people in prayer?"
Abu Bakr replied:
"Yes, I will lead if you wish."
And this is the exact wording from Saḥiḥ Bukhari:

عن سهل بن سعد : إن أُناسا من بنی عمرو بن عوف کان بینهم شیء ، فخرج إلیهم النبیّ [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله ) ] فی أُناس من أصحابه ، یصلح بینهم فحضرت الصلاة ولم یأت النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فأذّن بلال بالصلاة ، ولم یأت النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فجاء إلی أبی بکر فقال : إن النبیّ [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله ) ] حبس ، وقد حضرت الصلاة ، فهل لک أن تؤمّ الناس ؟ فقال : نعم ، إن شئت ; فأقام الصلاة فتقدّم أبو بکر . (644) انتهی بقدر الحاجة .

From Sahl bin Sa'd: A group from the Banu 'Amr bin 'Awf had a dispute among themselves, so the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) went out to them with a group of his companions to reconcile between them. When the time for prayer arrived, the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) had not yet returned. So Bilal called the adhan for prayer, but the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) still did not arrive. Then [Bilal] went to Abu Bakr and said: "The Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) has been delayed, and the time for prayer has arrived. Would you lead the people in prayer?" He replied: "Yes, if you wish." So he [Bilal] pronounced the iqamah, and Abu Bakr stepped forward [to lead the prayer]. (644) End, quoted as needed.

footnote.p: (644) [A] Chapter: Whoever Entered to Lead the People in Prayer from the Book of Prayer. [w] Chapter: What Has Been Mentioned Regarding Reconciliation Between People from the Book of Reconciliation (12). [B] Saḥīḥ al-Bukhaarī 3/165 (printed in Egypt, year 1315). [Saḥīḥ al-Bukhaarī 2/63-64 and 3/165].

para.p: And it is also evident that if the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy family) had granted permission for Abu Bakr to lead the prayer, Bilal would not have asked in an interrogative and consultative manner: ( فهل لک أن تؤمّ الناس ؟ ) "Fahal laka an tu'umm al-nas?" Rather, he would have said:
"The Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy family) has commanded me to tell you that if he does not arrive, you should lead the prayer – so lead it."
Moreover, Abu Bakr would not have made his leadership contingent upon the approval and will of Bilal, nor would he have said: ( نعم إن شئت ) ("Yes, if you wish").

And from this, a group of commentators have argued that the preference of Abu Bakr was already established in the minds of the companions, which is why they put him forward. As Kirmani (645) mentioned in his commentary on this matter in the Book of Prayer:

footnote.p:
(645) [A] It is recorded in Bughyat al-Wu‘aat by Jalaal al-Dīn al-Suyuṭī:
"Muḥammad ibn Yusuf ibn ‘Alī ibn Sa‘īd al-Kirmaanī, then al-Baghdaadī, Shaykh Shams al-Dīn, the author of the commentary on Bukhaarī, the distinguished imaam in fiqh, ḥadīth, tafsīr, uSul, ma‘aanī, and Arabic language."
His son mentioned in Dhail al-Masaalik:
"He was born on Thursday, the twenty-sixth of Jumaadaa al-AAkhirah in the year 717 AH. He studied under his father Bahaa’ al-Dīn, then moved to Kirmaan, where he learned from ‘Aḍud and others, excelling beyond his peers and surpassing most scholars of his time. He then traveled to Damascus and Egypt, where he studied Bukhaarī under Nasir al-Dīn al-Faariqī and heard from many scholars. He performed Ḥajj, returned to Baghdad, and settled there. He was a man of complete integrity, cheerful in demeanor, and humble toward the poor and scholars, paying no attention to worldly people. Sultans would visit him in his home, seeking his supplications and advice."
Among his writings are Sharḥ al-Bukhaarī and Sharḥ al-Mawaaqif (12). [Bughyat al-Wu‘aat 1/279-280].

para.p: وفیه : إن أفضلیة أبی بکر کانت مقرّرة فی نفوس الصحابة حیث قدّموه للصلاة . (646) انتهی .
And concerning it: The preference of Abu Bakr was established in the minds of the companions, as they put him forward for prayer. (646) End.

footnote.p: (646) Sharḥ al-Kirmaanī ‘alaa al-Bukhaarī 5/67.

para.p: And this statement explicitly indicates that the companions put Abu Bakr forward for this prayer by their own decision, not by the command of the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy family).

As for what has been claimed: that in the ninth year when Hajj was made obligatory, and the Prophet’s (peace be upon him and his holy family) journey was delayed due to certain matters, he appointed Abu Bakr al-Siddiq as the leader of Hajj and sent him along with a large group of companions to Makkah to perform the rituals of Hajj.

Therefore, mentioning the story of Hajj in this context is utterly pointless, for even the scholars of the Shia have narrated the story of Hajj – as is evident from the words of Qazi al-Qozat (Ibn Khallikan). However, since, according to Sunni narrations – as will be mentioned later – Abu Bakr’s return from the journey has been established, while his reappointment as the leader of Hajj is not proven, there is no argument in this story.
And Sayyid al-Murtada ‘Alam al-Huda has stated in his book Shafi:

کما روی من بعض الطرق : ان أبا بکر – بعد أخذ السورة منه – کان والیاً علی الموسم ; فقد روی : إنه رجع – لمّا أخذ أمیر المؤمنین [ ( علیه السلام ) ] السورة منه – إلی النبیّ [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله وسلم ) ] ، وکان الوالی علی الحجیج فی الموسم والمؤدّی للسورة أمیر المؤمنین [ ( علیه السلام ) ] ولیس هذا ممّا یتفرّد به الشیعة فی النقل ; لأن کثیراً من أصحاب الحدیث قد رووه ، ومن تأمل فی کتبهم وجده فیها . (647) انتهی .

As has been narrated through some sources: that Abu Bakr – after the surah was taken from him – remained as the governor over the Hajj pilgrimage. It has been narrated that when Amir al-Momineen (peace be upon him) took the surah from him, he [Abu Bakr] returned to the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family), while the governor over the pilgrims in the season and the one who delivered the surah was Amir al-Momineen (peace be upon him). This is not something exclusively transmitted by the Shia, for many hadith scholars have also narrated it, and whoever examines their books will find it recorded therein. (647) End.

That is: As it has been narrated <92> through some Sunni sources that indeed Abu Bakr, after the Surat al-Bara’ah was taken from him, remained the governor over the Hajj season. It has also been narrated that when Amir al-Momineen ‘Ali (peace be upon him) took Surat al-Bara’ah from him, he [Abu Bakr] returned to the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family), while he [Amir al-Momineen] was the governor over the pilgrims in the Hajj season, and the one who delivered the verses was Amir al-Momineen (peace be upon him). And this narration is not of the kind that the Shia alone have transmitted, for most of the hadith scholars have also narrated this matter, and whoever examines their books will find it recorded therein.

As for, what he stated about the delegation of leadership in prayer during his illness at the time of his death, from the night of Thursday until the morning of Monday, is so well-known that it does not require elaboration.

So the answer is that (648): the zealous proof is compelling evidence for the invalidity of the matter regarding the Noble Messenger's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) designation of Abu Bakr for leading the prayer, namely that: the Ahle Tasannun claim there is a contradiction between Abu Bakr's appointment to accompany Osama and his command to lead the prayer; just as Ibn Taymiyyah has asserted, and Ibn Ruzbahan mentioned in "Ibtal al-Baatil":

footnote.p: (648) [A] (Faydah:) Evidence for the invalidity of the matter of leading the prayer by Abu Bakr. (12).

para.p: وقد قال الشیخ الجزری : من ادّعی أن أبا بکر کان فی جیش أُسامة فقد أخطأ ; لأن النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم بعد ما أنفذ جیش أُسامة ، قال : مروا أبا بکر فلیصلّ بالناس . ولو کان مأموراً بالرواح مع أُسامة لم یکن رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم یأمره بالصلاة بالإمامة . (649) انتهی .

And the Shaikh al-Jazri said: Whoever claims that Abu Bakr was in Osama's troop has erred; because the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) after sending out Osama's troop, said, "Order Abu Bakr to lead the people in prayer." If he had been commanded to stay with Osama, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) would not have ordered him to lead the prayer in his absence. (649) End.

footnote.p: (649) [A] Answer to the refutations against Abu Bakr. (12). [B] Dalaa'il al-Sidq 3/4 (Qom edition 1395). [Ihqaaq al-Haqq: 218].

para.p: Thus, it is entirely clear from this statement that there is a complete and explicit contradiction between the command to accompany Osama and the command to lead the prayer, and that the simultaneous occurrence of both is impossible. And since – praise be to Allah – Abu Bakr's presence among Osama's troop has been established through the narratives and explicit statements of trustworthy and reliable individuals from the Ahle Tasannun, indeed, even through the explicit assertion of the very one addressed, then the issuance of a command for him to lead the prayer is merely one of the fabricated, false, and superstitious claims.

And as for what has been said is accepted: that the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) sometimes appointed Abu Bakr as governor over a matter, but this was for the reason that he regarded him as his minister and advisor, and no task of the religious affairs could be completed in his absence.

Therefore, it follows that when Abu Bakr went to the expedition of Dhat al-Salasil on a mission from 'Amr b. al-'As – far from God – he did not complete any matter of the affairs of religion from the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) during this time. Is this not [nothing but] (650) explicit disbelief (kufr)?

footnote.p: (650) The addition is from [B]

para.p: Sayyid al-Murtadha said in his book al-Shafi – in refutation of the words of Qazi al-Qozat (Ibn Khallikan):

فأمّا من یدّعی : إنه لم یوّله لافتقاره إلیه بحضرته وحاجته إلی تدبیره ورأیه ! ! فقد بینّا إنه علیه [ وآله ] السلام ما کان یفتقر إلی رأی أحد ; لکماله ورجحانه علی کل أحد ، وإنّما کان شاور أحیاناً أصحابه علی سبیل التعلیم [ لهم ] (651) والتأدیب . . أو لغیر ذلک ممّا قد ذکر . . وبعد ; فکیف استمرّت هذه الحاجة واتصلت منه إلیهما ، حتّی لم یستغن فی زمان من الأزمان من حضورهما فیولّیهما ; وهل هذا إلا قدح فی رأی الرسول ( صلی الله علیه وآله وسلم ) ونسبته إلی أنه کان ممّن یحتاج إلی أن یلقّن ویوقف علی کل شیء ؟ ! وقد نزّهه الله تعالی عن ذلک .

As for one who claims that he did not appoint him due to needing him in his presence and his necessity for his management and counsel! We have explained that he (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was not in need of anyone's opinion; this was due to his perfection and superiority over everyone. Rather, he only consulted his companions at times as a means of teaching [them] (651) and discipline... or for reasons other than that which has been mentioned... Moreover, how could this need have continued and been connected from him to them, so that he did not become independent in any period of time from their presence, to appoint them? And is this not a slight on the opinion of the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and an implication that he was someone who needed to be taught and informed about everything? God, the Exalted, is far removed from that.

footnote.p: (651) The addition is from the source.

para.p: فأما ادّعاؤه : إن الروایة قد وردت بأنهما وزیراه ; فقد کان یجب أن یصحّح ذلک قبل أن یعتمده ویحتجّ به ; فإنا ندفعه عنه أشدّ الدفع (652) .

As for the claim that there is a narration stating that they were his two ministers: It must be corrected before he adopts it and uses it as an argument; for we will repel it from him with the utmost repulsion. (652)
As for what he said: "It has always been the custom and habit of kings to send high ministers and commanders to oversee the actions and command troops..." until the end.

The reason for this is the deficiency and inability of kings regarding the ultimate affairs of the world, and since the rulings of Shari'ah and religion are established by God, there is no need for anyone in that.
As for what he said: "This explanation was itself indicated by the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy descendants), and the judge narrates from Hudhayfah ibn al-Yaman..." until the end.
It is therefore refuted in several ways:
First: The fact that this narration is from the Ahle Tasannun, using it as an argument in opposition to the Shia is not correct!

Second: The reason for the establishment of this narration is also apparent, for if the matter were such that the Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy descendants) was in need of the two Shaykhs, and the affairs of religion could not be concluded without them, the Majestic Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy descendants) should not have sent Umar and Abu Bakr to the battle of Zaat al-Salaasil, and that too under the command of the illegitimate son Amr ibn al-As, nor would He have given either of them the authority to lead with the army of Osama.
Third: Scholars of Ahle Tasannun have deemed this narration of al-Hakim to be unreliable, as mentioned in "Kanz al-Ummal":

لقد هممت أن أبعث إلی الآفاق رجالا یعلّمون الناس السنن والفرائض ، کما بعث عیسی الحواریین ; قیل : فأین أنت من أبی بکر وعمر ؟ قال : إنه لا غنی [ بی ] عنهما ، إنهما من الدین کالسمع والبصر . ک . – أی رواه الحاکم فی المستدرک – وتعقّب عن حذیفة . (653) انتهی .

I was about to send men to the far-out regions to teach the people the Sunnah and the obligatory duties, just as ‘Isa (Jesus) sent the disciples. It was said: "What about Abu Bakr and ‘Umar?" He replied: "I have no need to be without them; they are to the religion like hearing and sight." .Refer:. – That is, al-Hakim narrated it in al-Mustadrak – and it has been criticized as being from Hudhayfah. (653) End.

footnote.p: (653) [A] The virtues of Abu Bakr and Umar from Chapter Two, Section Three, of the book of virtues, in the category of statements, from the letter "F," page 149, Volume Two. [B] Kanz al-Ummal 1436 [thus] (printed Hyderabad 1313). [Kanz al-Ummal 11 / 566 (printed by Mu'assissat al-Risalah, Beirut)

para.p: Thus, mentioning fabricated narrations about the virtues of Abu Bakr and Umar, which the Ahle Tasannun themselves have deemed unreliable, and challenging them, in contrast to the Shia, is extremely strange.
Fourth: Since this narration is considered correct (Sahih) by the Nasibi scholar, it became necessary for him to regard himself as a liar in the claim of sending Abu Bakr in multiple expeditions.

It is utterly astonishing that the Addressee does not reflect on the contradiction and inconsistency, despite his complete concern in proving the sending of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, of Abu Bakr to positions of authority in various expeditions, he will soon fully contradict himself by the mention of this fabricated hadith, which is apparent even to the fools who propagate it – let alone the knowledgeable – has made the nullity of their false claims evident.

As for what he said: that the Noble Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) also stated, that: "The Almighty God has granted me four ministers, two ministers from the people of the earth, Abu Bakr and Umar . . .," till the end.

Then, this narration (hadith) is also among the fabrications and unique claims of the Ahle Tasannun (654), and what Seyyed Ali Hamadani has recorded in his book "Mawdat al-Qurba" (Affection of the Progeny) indicates its fabricated nature:

footnote.p: (654) [A] (Faydah:) The Fabrication of the Hadith on the Ministry of the Two Sheikhs.

para.p: عن أبی موسی السعدی (655) . . . قال : کنت مع رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فی بقیع الغرقد (656) ، ومعه أبو بکر وعمر وعثمان ونفر من أصحابه وعلی [ ( علیه السلام ) ] ، فالتفت صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم إلی أبی بکر ، فقال : « یا أبا بکر ! هذا الذی تراه وزیری فی السماء ووزیری فی الأرض – یعنی علی بن أبی طالب [ ( علیه السلام ) ] – ، فإن أحببت أن تلقی الله وهو عنک راض فارض علیاً ، فإن رضاه رضاء الله وغضبه غضب الله » . (657) انتهی .

From Abu Musa al-Sa’adi (655)… who said: "I was with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, in the Baqee' al-Gharqad (656), and with him were Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, and several of his companions, and Ali (peace be upon him). The Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, turned to Abu Bakr and said: 'O Abu Bakr! This one you see is my minister in heaven and my minister on earth – meaning Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon them both) – so if you wish to meet Allah while He is pleased with you, be content with Ali, for His pleasure is the pleasure of Allah, and His anger is the anger of Allah.'" (657) End.

footnote.p: (655) [B] In the source: (al-Sa'di al-Humaydi).
(656) [B] In the source: (in the middle of Arafat).
(657) [A] The sixth chapter/affection (Mawaddah al-Saadesah). (12). [B] Mawdah al-Qurba: 60 (Lahore edition). [From it, Yanabee' al-Mawaddah 2 / 288-289].

para.p: It is also mentioned in "Muwadda al-Qurba":
وعنه – أی عن علی ( علیه السلام ) – قال : قال رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم (658) : « إنی رأیت اسمک مقروناً باسمی فی أربعة مواطن فآنست (6592) بالنظر إلیه :

And from him – that is, from Ali (peace be upon him) – he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) (658) said: "I saw your name linked with mine in four places, so I felt at ease (659) at the thought of it:

footnote.p: (658) [B] In the source: (to me, O Ali).
(659) [B] In the source: (and I turned).

para.p: « لمّا بلغت بیت المقدس فی معراجی إلی السماء وجدت علی صخرة بها : لا إله إلاّ الله ، محمد رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم أیّدته بوزیره ونصرته بوزیره . .

"When I reached Bait al-Maqdis in my Ascension (Mi'raj) to the heavens, I found (written) on a stone (tablet) there: There is no god but Allah, Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny). I supported him with his minister and aided him with his minister...
فقلت لجبرئیل : ومن وزیری ؟ قال : علی بن أبی طالب » .
So I said to Jibraeel (Gabriel): And who is my minister? <94> He replied: Ali ibn Abi Talib."
« فلمّا انتهیت إلی سدرة المنتهی وجدت علیها : إنّی أنا الله لا إله إلاّ أنا وحدی ، ومحمد صفوتی من خلقی ، أیّدته بوزیره ونصرته بوزیره .

"So when I reached the Lote Tree of the Utmost Boundary (Sidrat al-Muntaha), I found upon it: Indeed, I am Allah; there is no god but Me, alone, and Muhammad is My chosen one (Safiyy) from My creation. I supported him with his minister and aided him with his minister.
فقلت لجبرئیل : ومن وزیری ؟ قال : علی بن أبی طالب » .
So I said to Jibril: And who is my minister? He said: Ali ibn Abi Talib."
« فلمّا جاوزت من سدرة المنتهی وانتهیت إلی عرش ربّ العالمین فوجدت مکتوباً علی قوائمه : إنی أنا الله لا إله إلا أنا ، محمد حبیبی من خلقی ، أیّدته بوزیره ونصرته بوزیره » .

"Then, when I passed beyond the Lote Tree of the Utmost Boundary and reached the Throne of the Lord of the worlds, I found written on its pillars: Indeed, I am Allah; there is no god but Me, Muhammad is My beloved (Habib) from My creation. I supported him with his minister and aided him with his minister."
« فلمّا هبطت إلی الجنّة ، وجدت مکتوباً علی باب الجنة : لا إله إلاّ أنا ، محمد حبیبی من خلقی ، أیّدته بوزیره ، ونصرته بوزیره » . (660) انتهی .

"And when I descended to Paradise, I found written on the gate of Paradise: There is no god but Me, Muhammad is My beloved from My creation. I have supported him with My minister and aided him with My authority." (660) End.

footnote.p: (660) [A] Eighth Chapter/Affection. (12). [B] Mawaddat al-Qurbaa, page 84 (Lahore edition). [From him, Yanabi’e al-Mawaddah 2 / 309].

para.p: However, what he said: if not sending someone to a task indicates a lack of suitability for Imamate, it would follow that Hasan and Husain (peace be upon them) would also be unsuitable for the Imamate, God forbid; because Amir al-Momineen (peace be upon him) did not send either of them to any battle or task.
