Thus, it must be answered that this objection is a common occurrence; because Waliyullah, the father of the Addressee in “Izalat al-Khifa”, mentioned in the necessities of specific Caliphate:

And among the necessities of specific Caliphate is that that Holy One (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) will interact with the Caliph many times and in countless instances, just as the Amir interacts with one awaiting leadership (Muntazir al-Imarah) in words and actions, and this can be understood in several ways:
One: That he will explain his deservingness of the Caliphate and mention his virtues in relation to his interactions with the community.
Two: That he will manifest many signs, so that the jurists of the companions know that if he were to appoint a successor, he would appoint so-and-so.
And they would know that so-and-so is the most beloved of people to the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny).
And they would say: The Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) passed away while he was pleased with him... and whatever else may be in this regard.

Third: That in his lifetime, this person may command him to perform actions pertaining to his blessed self from the aspect of Prophethood, and this matter was desired in specific Caliphate to establish trust in the Caliph's leadership from the standpoint of Divine Law (Shara'). (661) End.

footnote.p: (661) [A] The beginning of the book, first chapter. (12). [Izalat al-Khafa 1 / 13].

para.p: If, according to the virtuous, biased father, the management of affairs related to the self of the one being endowed is an essential part of Caliphate, and the virtuous, biased one does not consider the Commander of the Faithful (Amir al-Momineen), (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), as the overseer of any matter concerning Hasan and Husain (peace be upon them), then it would imply that – God forbid – Hasan and Husain (peace be upon them) are not suitable for Caliphate.

Nevertheless, this comparison of Abu Bakr to Hasan and Husain (peace be upon them) is a flawed analogy (qiyaas ma‘ al-faariq); because even if, hypothetically, the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) did not appoint Hasan and Husain (peace be upon them) to oversee any matter, it would not be detrimental; because the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) had appointed them with clear evidence (nas) of Caliphate, and had not made them subject to anyone, nor removed them from a task after their appointment. This is in contrast to Abu Bakr, whom the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) at times made subordinate to 'Amr ibn 'As, and at other times subject to Osama, and from some matters he had appointed him to – such as conveying the chapter of Bara'ah (Repentance) – he had removed him, and with all this, he did not give a clear evidence (nas) regarding Abu Bakr, but instead appointed him to the leadership (Imamate) over both of these great ones.

Moreover, the failure of the Commander of the Faithful, Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), to send Hasan and Husain (peace be upon them) on any task is sheer falsehood and absolute slander; because it is mentioned in "Taarikh Yafi'i" in the events of the year thirty-six of the Hijrah, concerning the story of the Battle of Jamal (Camel), as follows:
وأرسل علی [ ( علیه السلام ) ] ابنه الحسن [ ( علیهما السلام ) ] إلی الکوفة مع ناصر الحق عمار یستنفران من فیها (662) .
And Ali (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) sent his son Hasan (peace be upon them) to Kufa with the Supporter of Truth, Ammar, to rally those in it (662).

footnote.p: (662) [B] Mar'at al-Janan 1 / 96 (Printed in Hyderabad, Deccan, 1337 AH).

para.p: That is: Ali (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) sent his son, Hasan (peace be upon them), towards Kufa with the Supporter of Truth, Ammar, to bring the people there to that Master (peace be upon him and his holy progeny). And the essence of this hadith is also mentioned in Sahih Bukhari from the narration of Abu Maryam:

لمّا سار طلحة والزبیر وعائشة إلی البصرة ، بعث علی [ ( علیه السلام ) ] عمار بن یاسر وحسن بن علی [ ( علیهما السلام ) ] ، فقدما علینا الکوفة فصعد المنبر ، وکان الحسن بن علی [ ( علیهما السلام ) ] فوق المنبر فی أعلاه ، وقام عمار أسفل من الحسن [ ( علیه السلام ) ] . . إلی آخر الحدیث (663) .

When Talha and Zubair <95> and Aisha went to Basra, Ali (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) sent Ammar ibn Yasir and Hasan ibn Ali (peace be upon them), and they came to us in Kufa. He ascended the pulpit, and Hasan ibn Ali (peace be upon them) was above the pulpit at its top, while Ammar stood lower than Hasan (peace be upon him)… until the end of the hadith. (663)

footnote.p: (663) [A] The Chapter on the Turmoil that Will Surge like the Waves of the Seas from the Book of Trials. (12). [B] Bukhari 9 / 56 ([Printed] Egypt, 1313 AH). [Sahih Bukhari 8 / 97].

para.p: Ibn Hajar said in Fath al-Bari in the explanation of this hadith:

وفیه جواز ارتفاع ذی الأمر فوق من هو أسنّ منه وأعظم سابقة فی الإسلام وفضلا ; لأن الحسن ولد أمیر المؤمنین [ ( علیهما السلام ) ] ، وکان حینئذ هو الأمیر علی من أرسلهم علی ( علیه السلام ) ، وعمار من جملتهم فصعد الحسن [ (علیه السلام) ] علی المنبر ، فکان فوق عمار . (664) انتهی بقدر الحاجة .

And it indicates the permissibility of one in authority being elevated above one who is older than him and has greater precedence in Islam and virtue; because Hasan was the son of the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon them), and at that time he was the leader of those whom Ali (peace be upon him) sent, and Ammar was among them. Thus, Hasan (peace be upon him) ascended the pulpit, being above Ammar. (664) This concludes what is necessary.

footnote.p: (664) [B] Fath al-Bari vol. 13, page 46 (Printed at the Khayriyya Press, Cairo, 1329 AH). [Fath al-Bari 13 / 50].

para.p: That is: In this hadith, it is established that the elevation of the Master of the Affair (Sahib al-Amr) over someone who is older than him in age is permissible; because Imam Hasan (peace be upon him) – the son of the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) – was, at that time, an emir over those whom the Noble Amir (peace be upon him) had sent, and Ammar was among them. Then Imam Hasan (peace be upon him) ascended to the highest point of the minbar and stood above Ammar.
And it is mentioned in the book "Jila' al-Uyun" that:

On the day of the Battle of Jamal, the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) called Muhammad ibn Hanifiyya and gave him his spear, saying: "Go and strike this spear on the she-camel of Aisha." When Muhammad approached the she-camel, the tribe of Banu Hanifa (665) obstructed him and prevented him. When Muhammad ibn Hanifiyya returned to his presence, Imam Hasan (peace be upon him) took the spear from his hand, went near the she-camel of Aisha, and plunged the spear into it, then returned to the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) with the spear bloodied. Thus, Muhammad ibn Hanifiyya's face changed from embarrassment. The Imam said: "Do not be ashamed that you were unable to do it while Hasan (peace be upon him) did; for he is the son of a Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and you are my son." (666) End.

footnote.p: (665) In the source: (Banu Dhubba).
(666) [A and B] Chapter Five on the state of Imam Husain (peace be upon him). [Jala' al-Uyun: 370-371, Chapter Three of the life of Imam Mujtaba (peace be upon him)

para.p: And the sending of the Noble Amir (peace be upon him) Imam Husain (peace be upon him) to fetch water whenever Muawiya had withheld it, and that Imam’s securing of the water source is also well-known.
And Qazi al-Qozat (Ibn Khallikan) has said:
ترکه أن یولّیه لا یدلّ علی أنه لا یصلح لذلک ، وتولیته إیاه لا یدلّ علی صلاحیة للإمامة ، فإنه قد ولّی خالد بن ولید وعمرو بن العاص ، ولم یدلّ ذلک علی صلاحهما للإمامة (667) .

"His being left to govern does not indicate that he is not suitable for it, and his appointment to it does not demonstrate his fitness for the Imamate (Imamah), for he has appointed Khalid ibn al-Walid and Amr ibn al-As, and this did not indicate their suitability for the Imamate." (667)

footnote.p: (667) The exact statement was not in the source, but Mufid's meaning was the same. Refer to al-Mughni 20 / vol. 1 / 349.

para.p: And Sayyid Murtaza Alam al-Huda, in refutation of this statement, has said:

قد علمنا بالعادة : إن من یرشّح (668) لکبار الأُمور لابدّ من أن یدرج إلیها من صغارها ، لأن من یرید بعض الملوک تأهیله للأمر بعده لابدّ من أن ینبّه علیه بکلّ قول و فعل یدلّ علی ترشیحه لهذه المنزلة ، ویستکفیه من أُموره وولایاته ما یعلم عنده أو یغلب علی الظنّ صلاحه لما یریده له ، وإن من یری أن الملک مع حضوره وامتداد الزمان وتطاوله لا یستکفیه شیئا من الولایات ، ومتی ولاّه عزله ، وإنّما یولّی غیره ویستکفی سواه ، لابدّ أن یغلب فی الظنّ : إنه لیس بأهل للولایة .

We have learned from experience that one who is nominated (668) for great affairs must first be introduced to them through smaller ones. For if a king wishes to prepare someone for authority after him, he must highlight him with every word and action that indicates his nomination for this position. He must entrust him with responsibilities and governances that demonstrate his competence or strongly suggest his suitability for what is intended for him. And if a king, despite his presence and the passage of an extended period of time, does not entrust him with any governances, and whenever he appoints him, he soon dismisses him, instead appointing and relying on others – then it must be strongly assumed that he is not fit for governance.

footnote.p: (668) [A] Nomination: Training him, and hence: He is being nominated for the ministry or for kingship... that is, nurtured and educated. (12). [See: al-Nihayah 2 / 225, Lisan al-Arab 1 / 711, and Taj al-Arous 4 / 50].

para.p: وإن جوّزنا أنه لم یولّه لأسباب کثیرة سوی أنه لا یصلح للولایة ، إلا أن مع هذا التجویز لابدّ أن یغلب علی الظنّ ما ذکرناه .
And even if we allow that he was not appointed for many reasons other than his unfitness for governance, still, despite this possibility, what we have mentioned must strongly prevail in assumption.

وأما خالد وعمرو فإنهما لم یصلحا للإمامة لفقد شروط الإمامة فیهما ، وإن کان یصلحان لما ولّیاه من الإمارة ; فترک الولایة مع امتداد الزمان وتطاول الأیام وجمیع الشروط التی (669) ذکرناها یقتضی (670) غلبة الظنّ لفقد الصلاح .

As for Khalid and Amr, they were not fit for Imamate due to the absence of its necessary conditions in them, even though they were suitable for the governorships they were appointed to. Thus, the absence of appointment to leadership despite the passage of time and the extension of days, along with all the conditions we have mentioned (669), necessitates (670) the strong assumption of their lack of suitability.

footnote.p: (669) In [A], there is a mistake: (the conditions) is written instead.
(670) In the source, it states (entails).

para.p: والولایة لشیء لا تدلّ علی الصلاح لغیره ، إذا کانت الشرائط فی القیام بذلک الغیر معلوماً فقدها ، وقد نجد الملک یولّی بعض أموره من لا یصلح للملک بعده لظهور فقد الشرائط فیه ، ولا یجوز أن یکون بحضرته من یرشّحه للملک [ بعده ] (671) ثم لا یولّیه علی تطاول الزمان شیئاً من الولایات ; فبان الفرق بین الولایة وترکها فیما ذکرناه .

And the appointment to a certain position does not indicate suitability for another if the conditions required for undertaking the latter are known to be absent. We often find that a king may assign some of his affairs to someone who is unfit for kingship after him due to the evident absence of the necessary conditions in him. It is not reasonable that someone who is being prepared for kingship [after him] (671) would remain in his presence without being assigned any governorship over an extended period of time. Thus, the distinction between appointment and non-appointment in what we have mentioned becomes clear.

footnote.p: (671) The addition is from the source.

para.p: فأمّا أمیر المؤمنین [ ( علیه السلام ) ] ; وإن لم یتولّ جمیع أُمور النبیّ ( صلی الله علیه وآله وسلم ) فی حیاته ، فقد تولّی أکثرها وأعظمها ، وخلّفه فی المدینة ، وکان الأمیر علی الجیش المبعوث إلی الخیبر ، وجری الفتح علی یدیه بعد انهزام من انهزم عنها ، وکان المؤدّی عنه سورة براءة بعد عزل من انعزل عنها (672) وارتجاعها منه ! (673) .

As for the Commander of the Faithful [(peace be upon him)], even if he did not take charge of all the affairs of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy family) during his lifetime, he was entrusted with most of them and the greatest of them. He was appointed as his successor in Medina, was the commander of the army sent to Khaybar, and the victory was achieved at his hands after those who had fled from it were defeated. He was also the one who delivered Surat al-Bara’ah on behalf of the Prophet after the one who had previously been assigned was dismissed (672) and it was taken back from him! (673).

footnote.p: (672) In the source - as in the margin of [B] - it states (after the removal of Abu Bakr from it).
(673) [B] al-Shafi, page 245 (Iranian edition, 1301). [al-Shafi 4/141].

chapter.title: Fifth Criticism: The Appointment of Umar to the Caliphate Despite His Dismissal from Managing the Charities

para.p: Dehalvi’s claim
He said: Fifth Objection:

That Abu Bakr al-Siddiq appointed Umar ibn al-Khattab as the overseer of all the affairs of the Muslims and made him the caliph of the Ummah, while at the time of the noble presence of the Master of the Worlds (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), Umar ibn al-Khattab had been appointed for one year to the duty of collecting alms, yet was again removed from this position. Appointing someone who was removed by the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) is to oppose the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny).

The response to this objection is that understanding Umar as removed is the height of foolishness. If a person is appointed to a task and that task ultimately concludes and their oversight comes to an end, one cannot say that that person has been removed from that appointment, and the cessation of Umar ibn al-Khattab's oversight was of this nature; the task of collecting alms was completed, and so his oversight also concluded. If we were to call this a removal, it would imply that every Prophet would be removed after death, and every Imam would be removed after their own death!

Another response: We accept that Umar was removed by the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), but he was like the case of Prophet Harun, who was removed from the caliphate after the return of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) from Mount Sinai. However, since he was independently a Prophet, this removal in his worthiness for the Imamate (Imamat) was not diminished, nor was that of Umar ibn al-Khattab, regarding whom it was indicated (لو کان بعدی نبیّ لکان عمر! – "If there were to be a prophet after me, it would be Umar!") This dismissal did not detract from his worthiness for the Imamate [of him].

Another response: The Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) opposition is that they should commit acts from which he has forbidden, not that one who is removed is appointed. So, if the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was forbidding the appointment of Umar and Abu Bakr appointed him, then certainly, opposition would have been necessary. And since this did not occur, where did the opposition arise?

And if doing what that Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) had not done was considered opposition to him, it would lead to the conclusion that Amir al-Momineen (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was also opposing that noble one in fighting (jihad) against Aisha, Allah forbid from that. (674)

footnote.p: (674) Tuhfat al-Ithnaa 'Ashariyya: 268.

para.p: The response from the respected author
I say:
In "Izalat al-Khifa," the composition of Waliyullah – who, according to the popular view, is the father of the virtuous Nasibi! – it is mentioned:

عن أبی البختری ، عن علی ( علیه السلام ) قال : « قال عمر بن الخطاب للناس : ما ترون فی فضل فضّل عندنا من هذا المال ؟ قال الناس : یا أمیر المؤمنین ! قد شغلناک عن أهلک وضیعتک وتجارتک ، فهو لک ، فقال لی : ما تقول أنت ؟ قلت : « قد أشاروا علیک » ، قال : قل ، فقلت : « لِمَ تجعل یقینک ظنّاً ؟ » فقال : لتخرجن ممّا قلت ; فقلت : « أجل ، والله لأخرجنّ منه ، أ تذکر حین بعثک نبیّ الله ساعیاً فأتیت العباس بن عبد المطلب فمنعک صدقته ، فکان بینکما شیء ، فقلت لی : انطلق معی إلی النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فلنخبرنّه بالذی صنع العباس ، فانطلقنا إلی النبیّ صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم فوجدناه خاثراً ، فرجعنا ; ثم غدونا علیه الغدو ، فوجدناه طیّب النفس ، فأخبرتَه بالذی صنع العباس ، فقال لک : « أما علمت أن عمّ الرجل صنو أبیه » . وذکرنا الذی رأیناه من خثوره فی الیوم الأول والذی رأیناه من طیب نفسه فی الیوم الثانی ، فقال : « إنکما أتیتمانی الیوم الأول وقد بقی عندی من الصدقة دیناران ، فکان الذی رأیتما من خثوری لذلک ، وأتیتما فی الیوم وقد وهبتهما (675) ، فذلک الذی رأیتما من طیب نفسی » ، فقال عمر : صدقت ، أما والله لأشکرنّ لک الأولی والآخرة » . (676) انتهی .

From Abu al-Bakhtari, from Ali (peace be upon him) who said: 'Umar ibn al-Khattab said to the people: What do you think about the surplus that has been given to us from this money? The people said: O Commander of the Faithful! You have been preoccupied with us, neglecting your family, your estate, and your trade, so it is yours. He said to me: What do you say? I said: They have already suggested it to you. He said: Speak. So, I said: Why do you make your certainty as a conjecture? He said: You must explain what you have said. So, I said: Yes, by God, I will explain it. Do you remember when the Prophet of God sent you as a collector, and you went to al-Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib, and he withheld his charity from you, and there was something between you, and you said to me: Come with me to the Prophet, peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family <97>, and we will tell him what al-Abbas has done. So we went to the Prophet, peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family, and we found him troubled, so we returned. Then we went to him early the next morning, and we found him in a good mood, and you told him what al-Abbas had done, and he said to you: Did you not know that a man's uncle is like his father's twin? And we mentioned what we saw of his trouble on the first day and what we saw of his good mood on the second day, and he said: You came to me on the first day when I had two dinars left from the charity, and that was why you saw me troubled, and you came to me on the day when I had given them away (675), and that was why you saw me in a good mood. 'Umar said: You have spoken the truth. By God, I will thank you for the first and the last. (676) End.'"

footnote.p: (675) In the source: (sent them away).

(676) [A] Fada'il Ali (peace be upon him) (12). [Izalat al-Khifa 2 / 267-268, and see also: Musnad Ahmad 1 / 94, Majma' al-Zawa'id 10 / 238, Musnad Abi Yali 1 / 414, Kunz al-'Ummal 7 / 192, Sharh Ibn Abi al-Hadid 12 / 100].

para.p: From this narration, it is evident that when that Master (peace be upon him and his holy lineage) assigned Umar the responsibility of the oversight of the charities, Abbas did not give him the charity, and a dispute arose between him and Abbas, and when Umar complained to that Noble One (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) about Abbas, that Noble One admonished him and said: "Do you not know that 'a man's uncle is like his father?!'" Then he disapproved of Umar’s action and did not consider him worthy of leadership, as he had not appointed him to oversee leadership as before. This is nothing but a dismissal, so the assumption that Umar’s dismissal was akin to an interruption of actions is purely mistaken and akin to "casting arrows in a battlefield of darkness".
And it is recorded in "Mishkat":

عن أبی هریرة قال : بعث رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم عمر علی الصدقة فقیل : منع ابن جمیل وخالد بن الولید والعباس ، فقال رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم : « ما ینقم ابن جمیل إلاّ أنه کان فقیراً فأغناه الله ورسوله ، وأمّا خالد ; فإنکم تظلمون خالداً ، قد احتبس أدراعه واعتدّه (677) فی سبیل الله ، وأمّا العباس ; فهی علیّ ومثلها معها » .ثم قال : « یا عمر ! أما شعرت أن عمّ الرجل صنو أبیه ؟ » متفق علیه (678) .

Narrated Abu Huraira: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family, sent Umar to collect the charity, and it was said: Ibn Jamil, Khalid bin Al-Walid, and Al-Abbas refused to pay. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family, said: 'What does Ibn Jamil resent except that he was poor and Allah and His Messenger enriched him? As for Khalid, you are being unjust to Khalid, he has dedicated his armors and his weapons (677) in the cause of Allah. As for Al-Abbas, it is my responsibility and its equivalent is with me.' Then he said: 'O Umar! Did you not know that a man's uncle is like his father's twin?' Agreed upon. (678)

footnote.p: (677) [A] This is the plural of 'itad. (12). [As in Qamus al-Muhit 1 / 312, Mu'jam Maqayis al-Lughah 4 / 216, and Ibn Manzur said: "Al-i'tad is the plural of 'itad, which is what a person prepares as military equipment." See Lisan al-Arab 6 / 45 and 5 / 93].
(678) [A and B] The beginning of the Book of Zakat. (12). [B] 1 / 560 (Damascus edition, 1380 AH). [Mishkat al-Masabih 1 / 558].

para.p: And Mulla Ali Qari said in "Sharh Mishkat":
« وأمّا خالد ; فإنکم تظلمون خالداً . . » بالتقوّل علیه ما لم یقله (679) .
"And as for Khalid; indeed, you are wronging Khalid. . ." by fabricating against him what he did not say. (679)

footnote.p: (679) The part: (by fabricating against him what he did not say) is not found in the source, or it has been omitted!! But a similar mention of this - as reported from Ibn Hajar - is provided: And it was said, you are wronging him with the claim of preventing the almsgiving from him, while he had, in fact, halted - as a form of Dissociation (Tabarra) - his weapons in the way of God, or intended by retaining them to prepare for jihad rather than for trade. Ibn Hazm also has a similar interpretation that: They wronged Khalid; for they attributed to him the prevention of almsgiving. See: al-Muhalli 5 / 237.

para.p: It is also said:
ثم قال : « یا عمر ! أما شعرت . . » ، أی علمت وتنبهت حیث اتهمت العباس بما قیل عنه . (680) انتهی .
Then he said, "O Umar! Did you not know…", meaning you were aware and alert when you suspected Al-Abbas regarding what was said about him. (680) End.

footnote.p: (680) Mirqat al-Mafatih 4 / 235. The part: (and you were alert when you suspected Al-Abbas regarding what was said about him) has been omitted from the source!!

para.p: And it is evident that the address "you are wronging" is directed towards Umar; because the Noble Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) had sent him to take almsgiving from Khalid and others, so what concern could this address have with anyone else?!
Moreover, the one asserting the statement: “منع ابن جمیل” (Khalid ibn Jamil prevented) is Umar, just as Ibn Hajar explicitly stated in "Fath al-Bari" where he said:
قوله : فقیل : ( منع ابن جمیل ) ، قائل ذلک عمر ، کما سیأتی – إن شاء الله تعالی – فی حدیث ابن عباس فی الکلام علی قصة العباس . (681) انتهی .

His statement, and it was said: (Khalid ibn Jamil prevented), the one who said this was Umar, as will appear – if God, the Exalted, wills – in the narration of Ibn Abbas in the discussion on the story of Al-Abbas. (681) End.

footnote.p: (681) Fath al-Bari 3 / 263.

para.p: And it is apparent that the act of injustice attributed to the one who claims this very matter is no different, but rather specifically to him, thus it becomes clear that an injustice and slander has occurred from 'Umar towards Khalid, and 'Ali al-Qari himself has explicitly attested to the occurrence of an accusation from him against Abbas; and if an injustice has occurred from 'Umar towards Khalid, and he has slandered him, and has not maintained a commendable relationship with Abbas, he has contended with him and caused him harm, and made accusations against him, then how could the appointment of such a person by Abu Bakr be permissible?!

And in another respect, 'Umar’s appointment by Abu Bakr was not permissible either, namely that: the dignitaries of the companions of the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) had a dislike for 'Umar’s leadership (682) as mentioned in "Kanz al-'Umal":

footnote.p: (682) [A] and [fa'yda:] The dislike of the dignitaries of his companions for 'Umar becoming Caliph.

para.p: عن عبد الرحمن بن عوف قال : دخلت علی أبی بکر فی مرضه الذی توفی فیه ، فقال : جعلت لکم عهداً من بعدی واخترت لکم خیرکم فی نفسی ، فکلّکم ورم لذلک أنفه رجاء أن یکون الأمر له ، ورأیت الدنیا قد أقبلت ، ولما تقبله هی جاءته (683) ، وستتخذون بیوتکم بستور الحریر ونضائد الدیباج ، وتألمون ضجائع الصوف الآذربی ، کأنّ أحدکم علی حسک السعدان (684) ،

From ʿAbd al-Raḥman ibn ʿAwf who said: I entered upon Abu Bakr during his illness in which he passed away, and he said: "I have made a covenant for you after me, and I have chosen for you the best among you <98> in my view. However, all of you have flared up with pride because of it, hoping that the matter would be yours. I have observed that the world is approaching, but it has not yet fully arrived – it is coming towards you (683). You will build your homes with silk curtains and cushions of brocade, and you will find discomfort in sleeping on Azerbaijani wool, as if one of you were lying on the thorns of al-Saʿdan. (684)

footnote.p: (683) In the source: (it came before it had fully settled).

(684) The phrase (on the thorns of al-Sa’adaan) in Kanz al-'Umal is missing in this narration, but it is mentioned in the previous narration on the same page. [Note: al-Sa’daan is a thorny desert plant]

para.p: ووالله لئن یقدم أحدکم فیضرب عنقه فی غیر حدّ خیر له من أن یسبح فی غمرة الدنیا . عق . طب . حل (685) .

By Allah! If one of you were to go forth and have his neck struck outside of a legitimate punishment, it would be better for him than to be fully immersed in the depths of the world." (`Aq, Tab, Hall) (685).

footnote.p: (685) [A and B] al-`Aqili, al-Tabarani, and Abu Na'im. (12). [A] "Fada'il Abu Bakr," from the category of actions, in the second chapter, third section, letter 'Alif'. (12). [B] See Kanz al-'Umal 6/323. [Kanz al-'Umal 12/532-533 (Printed by Moassesato al-Resalah, Beirut).

para.p: And (686) Zamakhshari stated in his book "Faiq" in the ninth chapter:

footnote.p: (686) In [A] mistakenly written (in) instead of (and).

para.p: [ برئ ] (687) أبو بکر . . . دخل علیه عبد الرحمن بن عوف ، فی علّته التی مات فیها ، فقال : أراک بارئاً یا خلیفة رسول الله [ ص ] ! فقال : أما إنی علی ذلک لشدید الوجع ، ولما لقیت منکم – یا معشر المهاجرین ! – أشدّ علیّ من وجعی ، إنی ولّیت أُمورکم خیرکم فی نفسی ، فکلّکم ورم أنفه أن یکون [ له الأمر ] (688) من دونه ، والله والله لتتخذون (689) نضائد (690) الدیباج ، وستور الحریر ، ولتألمنّ النوم علی الصوف الآذربی (691) ، کما یألم أحدکم النوم علی حسک السعدان ، والذی نفسی بیده لئن یقدم أحدکم فیضرب عنقه علی غیر حدّ خیر له من أن یخوض غمرات الدنیا .

[Baraʾ – to dissociate] (687) Abu Bakr... ʿAbd al-Raḥman ibn ʿAwf entered upon him during his illness in which he died, and said: "I see you recovering, O Caliph of the Messenger of Allah [peace be upon him and his holy progeny]!" He replied: "Indeed, I am in severe pain, and what I have suffered from you – O group of helpers (Muhajirin)! – is more severe upon me than my pain. I have appointed over your affairs, the best of you in my view, yet all of you have become swollen with pride, each wanting [the matter] (688) for himself instead of him. By Allah, by Allah, you will adopt (689) cushions (690) of brocade and curtains of silk, and you will find sleeping on Azerbaijani wool (691) as painful as one of you finds sleeping on the thorns of the saʿdan plant. By the One in Whose hand is my soul, if one of you were to advance and have his neck struck without due right, it would be better for him than plunging into the depths of the world.

footnote.p: (687) The addition is from the source.
(688) The addition is from the source.
(689) In the source: (You will surely take).
(690) [A] al-Nudayd: cushions and mats. (12). [See: al-Faiq 1/90].
(691) [A] al-Azarbaj: pertaining to Azerbaijan; and al-Azari was also narrated. (12). G [See: al-Nihayah 1/33, Lisan al-Arab 1/207, 387, Taj al-Arous 1/298, 497].

para.p: یا هادی الطریق ، جرت إنّما هوالفجر أو البجر ، – وروی البحر – .قال له عبد الرحمن : خفّض علیک یا خلیفة رسول الله [ ص ] ! فإن هذا یهیب (692) إلی ما بک .

O guide of the path, it has arrived – it is but dawn or destruction, – and it has been narrated as 'the sea'. ʿAbd al-Raḥman said to him: "Calm yourself, O Caliph of the Messenger of Allah [peace be upon him and his holy progeny]! For this increases (692) what is upon you."

footnote.p: (692) In the source: (yuhīḍuk). Shaykh al-Ṭurayḥī said: Haaḍa al-ʿaẓm hayḍan means "to break again after being set, so it is broken again after healing." Al-Jawharī said: "Every pain upon pain is a worsening affliction." It is said: Haaḍanī al-shayʾ – when something brings you back to your illness. See: Majmaʿ al-Baḥrayn 4/452, al-Siḥaaḥ 3/1113, Lisaan al-ʿArab 7/249.

para.p: وروی : أن فلاناً دخل علیه ، فنال من عمر وقال : لو استخلفت فلاناً ، فقال أبو بکر : لو فعلت ذلک لجعلت أنفک فی قفاک ، ولما أخذت من أهلک حقاً .

And it has been narrated: That a certain man entered upon him and spoke ill of ʿUmar and said: "If only you had appointed so-and-so." Abu Bakr replied: "Had I done so, I would have placed my nose at my back, and I would not have taken from my family their due right."

ودخل علیه بعض المهاجرین – وهو یشتکی فی مرضه – فقال له : [ أ ] (693) تستخلف علینا عمر وقد عتا علینا ولا سلطان له ؟ ! فلو ملکنا کان أعتی [ وأعتی ] (694) ، فکیف تقول لله إذا لقیته ؟ ! فقال أبو بکر : أجلسونی ، فأجلسوه ، فقال : [ أ ] (695) بالله تفرقنی ؟ فإنی أقول إذا لقیت : استعملت علیهم خیر أهلک ! (696)

And some of the Muhajirin entered upon him while he was suffering in his illness and said to him: "[Will] (693) you appoint ʿUmar over us when he has been harsh upon us and has no authority? If he were to rule over us, he would be even harsher [and harsher] (694). So what will you say to Allah when you meet Him?!" Abu Bakr said: "Sit me up," so they sat him up, and he said: "[ Will] (695) you separate from me by Allah? For I will say when I meet Him: I appointed over them the best of Your people!" (696)

footnote.p: (693) The addition is from the source.
(694) The addition is from the source.
(695) The addition is from the source.
(696) Al-Fa'iq fi Gharib al-Hadith 1 / 89.

para.p: And it is mentioned in Ibn Athir's "Nihayah":
وفی حدیث أبی بکر – فی عهده إلی عمر بالخلافة – : فکلّکم ورم أنفه علی أن یکون الأمر دونه (697) . أی : امتلأ وانتفخ من ذلک غضباً ! (698) (699)

And in the tradition (ḥadith) of Abu Bakr – in his covenant appointing ʿUmar as his successor: "Each of you swelled with pride at the thought that the matter (al-amr) was not given to him instead (i.e., was given to someone else) (697)." That is: He became full and inflated with anger because of it! (698) (699)

footnote.p: (697) In the source: "He has the matter from under him."
(698) In [A] mistakenly: "We are angry" is mentioned.
(699) [A] in the dictionary under "W R M" (12). [See: Nihayah 5 / 177].

para.p: Waliyyullah, in his treatises Tafdil al-Shaykhayn and Izalat al-Khafa, has quoted from Saḥiḥ al-Tirmidhi and al-Mustadrak from Zubayd ibn Harith, who said:
إن أبا بکر حین حضره الموت أرسل إلی عمر یستخلفه ، فقال الناس : أ تستخلف علینا فظّاً غلیظاً ؟ ولو قد ولینا کان أفظّ وأغلظ ، فما تقول لربّک إذا لقیته وقد استخلفت علینا عمر ؟ . . إلی آخر الحدیث (700) .

"Indeed, when Abu Bakr was near death, he sent for Umar to appoint him as his successor. The people said: 'Will you appoint over us a harsh and rude man? And if he were to lead us, he would be even harsher and ruder. What will you say to your Lord when you meet Him, having appointed Umar over us?'" ... to the end of the hadith. (700)

footnote.p: (700) [A] in Izzalateel-Khafa, in Chapter 4 of the first aim, and in the end of Ma'athir Siddiq is mentioned in two places. [Izaalatul Khafa 2 / 33, Qurat al-Eynayn 73. It should be noted that this matter was not found in Sunan Tirmidhi, but many from the generality have narrated the same, such as: Musannaf Ibn Shaybah 7 / 485, 8 / 574, Kanz al-A'mal Muqtqi 5 / 678, Tarikh al-Madinah Ibn Shaybah 2 / 671, Tarikh Madinat Dimashq Ibn Asakir 30 / 413, and similar in Sunan Bayhaqi 8 / 149 as narrated from Aisha].

para.p: And Hussein bin Ahmad Diyarbakri mentioned in "Tarikh Khamis":

وفی روایة قال – أی أبو بکر – لهم – أی رجال من المهاجرین والأنصار – : أترضون بخلافة خلیفة أُعیّنه لکم ؟ والله ما أُعیّن أحداً من أقربائی ، قالوا : قد رضینا من اخترت لنا ، فقال : قد اخترت عمر ، فقال له طلحة والزبیر : ما کنت قائلا لربّک إذا ما ولّیته مع غلظته .

And in one narration, it is said – meaning Abu Bakr – to them – meaning men from the Emigrants (Muhajirin) and the Helpers (Ansar) -: "Would you be satisfied with the caliphate of a caliph whom I appoint for you? By Allah, I will not appoint anyone from my relatives." They said: "We are satisfied with whoever you choose for us." He replied: "I have chosen Umar." Then Talhah and Zubair said to him: "What will you say to your Lord if you appoint him, given his sternness?"
وفی روایة : قال طلحة : أتولّی علینا فظّاً غلیظاً ؟ ما تقول لربّک إذا لقیته ؟ ! . . (701) إلی آخره .
And in another narration: Talhah said: "Will you appoint a harsh and coarse man over us? What will you say to your Lord when you meet Him?!"… (701) until the end.

footnote.p: (701) [A] The caliphate of Umar is mentioned in the second chapter of the conclusion. (12). [Tarikh Khamis 2 / 241]. Two copies of "Tarikh Khamis" have come into my possession, one from the library of Messiah al-Dawlah Bahadur, and the other from the library of Ahmad Hussein Khan Sahib Dam-e Majdihim.

para.p: And it is mentioned in "Riyad al-Nadirah":

وعن محمد بن سعد ، بإسناده : إن جماعة من الصحابة دخلوا علی أبی بکر – لمّا عزم علی استخلاف عمر – فقال له قائلون (702) منهم : ما أنت قائل لربّک إذا سألک عن استخلاف عمر علینا وقد تری غلظته ؟ (703) . . إلی آخره .

And from Muḥammad ibn Saʿd, with his chain of transmission: A group of ṣaḥabah entered upon Abu Bakr when he had resolved to appoint ʿUmar as his successor. Some of them said (702) to him: "What will you say to your Lord when He asks you about appointing ʿUmar over us, while you see his harshness?" (703) … until the end of the narration.

footnote.p: (702) In the source: (said).
(703) [A] Mention of Abu Bakr's covenant to Umar from the fourteenth section of the first chapter of the second part. (12). [B] Riyaḍ al-Nuẓara 1 / 237. [Riyaḍ al-Nuẓara 2 / 245].

para.p: And it is mentioned in "Kanz al-U'mmal" <99>:

عن عائشة قالت : لمّا حضر أبا بکر الوفاة استخلف عمر ، فدخل علیه علی [ ( علیه السلام ) ] وطلحة فقالا (704) : من استخلفت ؟ قال : عمر ، قالا : فماذا أنت قائل لربک ؟ ! قال : أبالله تفرقانی ! لأنا أعلم بالله ولعمر (705) منکما ، أقول : استخلفت علیهم خیر أهلک ! ابن سعد (706) .

Narrated from Aisha, who said: When death approached Abu Bakr, he appointed Umar as his successor. Then Ali [ (peace be upon him)] and Talha entered upon him and said (704): Who did you appoint as your successor? He said: Umar. They said: What will you say to your Lord?! He replied: Are you threatening me with Allah? For we know Allah and Umar (705) better than you two. I will say: I appointed the best of your people as a successor over them! Ibn Sa'd (706).

footnote.p: (704) In [A] mistakenly: (said) is mentioned.
(705) In the source: (with Umar).

(706) [A] This was compared with the "Muntakhab Kanz al-A'mal," which is also by Mulla Ali Naqvi. In the account of Umar's caliphate, this hadith is mentioned in the book al-Imara under the letter Hamza, and this hadith is also recorded in the virtues of Abu Bakr. (12). [Kanz al-A'mal 5 / 677].

para.p: The essence of it is that: It is narrated from Aisha that she said: Whenever Abu Bakr was close to death, he appointed Umar as his successor. Then Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him) and Talha entered upon Abu Bakr. Both said to Abu Bakr: Whom did you appoint as your successor after you? He said: Umar. Then both said: What will you say to your Lord? Abu Bakr replied: Are you threatening me with Allah?! The truth is that I know better than God and than Umar about you! I will say concerning God: I appointed the best of your people as a successor over the people.
And this narration was narrated by Ibn Sa'd. The extract ends here.
And also in "Kanz al-Ummal" in the virtues of Abu Bakr, this hadith is recorded as follows:

عن عائشة ، قالت : لمّا ثقل أبی دخل علیه فلان و فلان ، فقالوا : یا خلیفة رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم ! ماذا تقول لربّک غداً إذا قدمت علیه وقد استخلفت علینا ابن الخطاب ؟ فقال أبالله ترهبونی ، أقول : استخلفت علیهم خیرهم . ابن سعد (707) .

From 'A'isha, who said: When my father became ill, so-and-so and so-and-so entered upon him, and they said: O Caliph of the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)! What will you say to your Lord tomorrow when you stand before Him, having appointed Umar ibn al-Khattab as your successor over us? He said, "Do you think Allah will intimidate me? I will say: I appointed the best of them as a successor over them." Ibn Sa'd. (707)

footnote.p: (707) [B] Kanz al-U'mmal 6/325. [Kanz al-U'mmal 12/535-536 (Print by Mu'assasat al-Risalah, Beirut).

para.p: And these mentioned hadiths indicate in several ways the invalidity of Umar’s caliphate:
First: Ibn Hajar said in "Sawa'iq Muhriqah":
إنّما قال أبو بکر : ( أقیلونی ) ; لأنه خشی من لعنه [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله و سلم ) ] لإمام قوم وهم له کارهون (708) .
Abu Bakr only said (Uqiluni) because he feared being cursed (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) for being an imam of a people who were unwilling to have him. (708)

footnote.p: (708) [B] Sawaa'iq Muhriqah: 49 (Print in Egypt, 1375 AH). [Sawaa'iq Muhriqah 1/126].

para.p: That is, Abu Bakr did not say (Uqiluni) except for the fear that Abu Bakr feared the Prophet of Allah, Muhammad (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), cursing him for being an imam of a people that those people held in dislike. The extract ends here.
Therefore, it can be concluded that Umar is cursed upon the tongue of the Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and Abu Bakr is accused in his succession.

Second: The statement attributed to Abu Bakr: (فکلکم ورم أنفه – "All of you have a problem with my nose") indicates that all the companions of the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) were averse to Umar's caliphate. Thus, the consensus of the Honorary Companions on Umar's lack of competence and [lack of] deservingness for the caliphate became as clear as the dawn, and the invalidity of Umar's succession became evident as the midday sun.
Third: It is clear from these narrations that Umar was rude and coarse, and rudeness and coarseness are, as Ibn Rawzbahan admits, contrary to leadership (Imamate).

Moreover, many narrations from the Master of the Chosen (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) have been reported criticizing and denouncing this undesirable trait, which will be mentioned later, God willing.

Fourth: It is evident from these narrations that His Excellency Amir (peace be upon him) was also averse to Umar's caliphate and did not consider him fit for leadership, viewing Abu Bakr as sinful and deserving of the Lord's reprimand in his succession; and since the non-separation of that Excellency from the truth is undoubtedly established – as indicated by the hadith: "O Allah, turn the truth with him wherever it turns" (709) (اللهم أدر الحقّ معه حیثما دار) and others – then that Excellency's feelings of aversion and belief that Umar was unfit for caliphate were surely based on what is right.

footnote.p: (709) Refer to al-Ghadir 3 / 179, Appendices of Ihqaq al-Haq 5 / 626-628 and 7 / 470 and 16 / 394 and 17 / 134-136 and 20 / 584-585 and 23 / 646-647 and 30 / 227-228 and 31 / 956, and other sources.

para.p: And whenever the companions and His Excellency the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not find Umar suitable for the caliphate, then appointing Abu Bakr as a caliph over Umar must have been out of regard for him; and while Shah Waliyullah has mentioned in "Izalat al-Khafa" that: Abu Bakr himself narrated from that noble figure that he (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) said:

"Whoever takes charge of the affairs of the Muslims and appoints someone over them out of favoritism, upon him is the curse of Allah, and He will not accept from him any compensation or justice until He admits him into Hell". (710)

footnote.p: (710) [A] Note three, Chapter two, Topic one, Volume one. (12). [Izalat al-Khafa 1/16].

para.p: And it is even more astonishing that whenever the Noble Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), in the closeness of his death, requested a pen and paper for writing an explicit designation of the rightful caliphate and absolute imamate, Umar ibn al-Khattab uttered the words: ( إن الرجل لیهجر ) "Indeed, the man is rambling" and ( حسبنا کتاب الله ) "The Book of Allah is sufficient for us" and prevented the writing from taking place. Here, when Abu Bakr (711) wrote the will for the caliphate of Umar, he did not question or challenge it at all.

footnote.p: (711) In [A], there is mistakenly an "And" here.

para.p: And a poet has eloquently expressed this sentiment in verse, as he said:
أوصی النبیّ فقال قائلهم :
The Prophet made a will, and one of them said: *
قد ضلّ یهجر سید البشر
The Lord of mankind seems to be rambling.
ورأوا أبا بکر أصاب فلم
And they saw Abu Bakr acting correctly, so he
یهجر فقد أوصی إلی عمر
did not ramble; thus, he made a will to Umar.

However, what is meant by this is another response: that Umar was deposed, but like the presence of Harun (peace be upon him). So the answer is that: To consider Prophet Aaron (peace be upon him) as deposed is the height of foolishness, and the caliphate of Prophet Moses [(peace be upon him and his holy progeny)] for Prophet Aaron (peace be upon him) was established from the time of his appointment until the time of his passing [(peace be upon them)], and the caliphate from that Prophet Moses [(peace be upon him and his holy progeny)] would never have diminished upon his return to the Prophet Aaron (peace be upon him), as is elaborated in the discussion of Imamate in the books of the Shia.

And even if, hypothetically, the caliphate from that Prophet Aaron (peace be upon him) were to diminish upon the return of Prophet Moses [(peace be upon him and his holy progeny)], still the deposition of that Prophet would not necessitate a removal like the removal of Umar; because he himself stated in the matter of Imamate that:
استخلافی که مقید به مدت غیبت باشد ، بعد از انقضای آن مدت باقی نمیماند ، چنانچه در حق حضرت هارون هم باقی نماند ، و انقطاع این استخلاف را عزل نتوان گفت (712) .

An appointment constrained by a period of absence does not remain after the expiration of that period, just as it did not remain in the case of Prophet Aaron, and the interruption of this appointment cannot be said to be a deposition (712).

footnote.p: (712) [A and B] The second Hadith from the traditions regarding the matter of Imamate of the Commander of the Faithful [ (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) ] page 438 (printed edition, Delhi). [Tuhfa Ithna Ashariyya: 211].

para.p: Thus, by his own admission, Prophet Aaron (peace be upon him) was not deposed, but rather the interruption of the appointment occurred due to the termination of its duration, and the removal of Umar was not of this kind, as mentioned earlier.

Moreover, it is also with the consideration of the knowledgeable Addressee that when the independence (of Prophethood is achieved, a deposition does not result in a deficiency, as stated in the chapter on Imamate (713), so since Prophet Aaron was a prophet, if he were to be deposed, it would not indicate a deficiency in that Prophet; unlike Umar, whose claim to Prophethood could not be made unless he relinquished Islam.

footnote.p: (713) Tuhfa Ithna Ashariyya: 211.

para.p: However, what has been said is also true regarding Umar ibn al-Khattab, concerning whom it has been pointed out that (لو کان بعدی نبیّ لکان عمر) (if there were to be a prophet after me, it would be Umar)… and so on.

Thus, mentioning such fabricated hadiths that the Ahle Tasannun uniquely narrate in the context of a debate against the Shia is exceedingly strange and astonishing! (714) And how is it permissible for an infallible prophet to authorize Prophethood for someone who may have been tainted for many years with the filth of polytheism, injustice, and the worship of idols?!

footnote.p: (714) [A] and [Fa'idah:] Fabrication of the hadith: (لو کان بعدی نبیّ لکان عمر) (if there were to be a prophet after me, it would be Umar). (12).

para.p: (سُبْحَانَکَ هذَا بُهْتَانٌ عَظِیمٌ) “Glory be to You (O Allah)! This is a great slander?”. (715)

footnote.p: (715) Surah An-Nur (24): 16.

para.p: Moreover, the chains of narration (asanid) for this hadith are regarded as weak (maqduh) among the the Ahle Tasannun themselves; because in "Sahih al-Tirmidhi," this narration is transmitted with the following chains:
حدّثنا سلمة بن شبیب ، أخبرنا المقری ، عن حیاة بن شریح ، عن بکر بن عمرو ، عن مشرح بن هاعان ، عن عقبة بن عامر قال : قال رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم : لو کان بعدی نبیّ لکان عمر بن الخطاب .

Salamah ibn Shabeeb narrated to us, Al-Muqri informed us, from Hayah ibn Shurayh, from Bakr ibn Amr, from Musharrah ibn Ha'aan, from Uqbah ibn Aamir, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him [and his holy progeny]) said: "If there were to be a prophet after me, it would be Umar ibn al-Khattab."
هذا حدیث حسن غریب لا نعرفه إلا من حدیث مشرح بن هاعان . (716) انتهی .
This is sound (Hasan) yet strange (Gharib) hadith; we do not know it except through the narration of Musharrah ibn Ha'aan. (716) End.

footnote.p: (716) [A] Fada'il Umar ibn al-Khattab from the book of Fada'il. (12). [B] Al-Jami' li-Tirmidhi 2/215 (printed in Kanpur, India). [Sunan Tirmidhi 5/281-282].

para.p: And Ibn Hibban (717) – who is one of the imams and a memorizer of hadith, and is extremely reliable (718) – has deemed this Musharrah ibn Ha'aan to be weak, as Zahabi mentions in the book "Mughni," which is aimed at listing the weak and wounded, in his translation, saying:

footnote.p: (717) In [Aa] it erroneously says: Ibn Hayyan.

(718) [A and B] Sam'ani mentions in "Ansab" regarding the lineage of Al-Bashti: Abu Hatim Muhammad ibn Hibban ibn Ahmad ibn Hibban [al-Tamimi] al-Bashti, an imam of his time, who authored works on subjects that had no precedent, and traveled between Shash and Alexandria, studying fiqh under Abu Bakr ibn Khuzaymah in Nishapur, and writing in Basra from Abu Khalifah al-Jamahi, and in the Levant from Muhammad ibn Ubaydullah al-Kala'i... and many scholars; Abu Abdullah ibn Mundah and Abu Abdullah ibn al-Bayyih, the two hafizs... and others, heard from him. Al-Hakim Abu Abdullah mentioned him and said: Abu Hatim al-Bashti, the judge, was one of the vessels of knowledge in language, fiqh, hadith, and admonition, and he was one of the wise men; he authored works, and his writings in hadith were unprecedented. (12). [Ansab 1/349].

para.p: لیّنه ابن حبّان (720) (719) .
Ibn Hibban deemed him unreliable. (719) (720)

footnote.p: (719) In [A] it is erroneously written: Ibn Hayyan.
(720) [A] The book "Mughni" is available in the library of His Excellency Ayatollah Fi al-Alamin. (12). [Mughni 2/659].

para.p: Zahabi also stated in "Mizaan" that Ibn Hibban said: Musharrah is from 'Aqbah, with some unsubstantiated reports (manakir).

It is narrated that there was no following on that, and the correct view is that whatever he is unique in should be abandoned, and 'Aqili reported <101> that: Musharrah accompanied Hajjaj until Mecca and hung a catapult (manjaniq) on the Kaaba, and this is his statement:
مشرح بن هاعان المصری ، عن عقبة بن عامر ، صدوق لیّنه ابن حبان .
Musharrah ibn Ha'aan al-Misri, from 'Uqbah ibn 'Amir, was trustworthy (saduq) but Ibn Hibban considered him to be unreliable.
وقال عثمان بن سعید ، عن ابن معین : ثقة وقال ابن حبان : یکنّی أبا مصعب ، یروی عن عقبة مناکیر لا یتابع علیها ، روی عنه اللیث وابن لهیعة ، فالصواب ترک ما انفرد به .

And 'Uthman ibn Sa'id, from Ibn Ma'in, said: Trustworthy (thiqah). Ibn Hibban said: He would use the kunya Abu Mus'ab and narrate unusual reports (munakir) from 'Uqbah that were not supported by others. Al-Layth and Ibn Luheiy'ah narrated from him, so the correct action is to abandon what he uniquely reported.
وذکره العقیلی فما زاد فی ترجمته من أن قیل : إنه جاء مع الحجاج إلی مکّة و نصب المنجنیق علی الکعبة . (721) انتهی .
'Aqili mentioned him, but added nothing more to his description than stating: It is said that he came with Hajjaj to Mecca and set up the catapult on the Kaaba. (721) End.

footnote.p: (721) Mizan al-I'tidal 4 / 117.

para.p: And Ibn al-Jawzi also criticized Musharrah, asserting that a narrative similar to this one, which he narrated, is fabricated (mawdu') as stated in the book "al-Mawdu'at" (Fabrications) in the chapter on fabricated narrations regarding the virtues of Umar, saying:

الحدیث الثانی : أنبأنا إسماعیل بن أحمد ، قال : أنبأ ابن مسعدة ، قال : أنبأ جمرة ، قال : أنبأ [ نا ] ابن عدی ، قال : حدّثنا علی بن الحسن بن قدید ، قال : حدّثنا زکریا بن یحیی الوقاد ، قال : حدّثنا بشر بن بکر ، عن أبی بکر بن عبد الله بن مریم ، عن حمزة بن حبیب ، عن عُضَیف (722) بن الحارث ، عن بلال بن ریاح ، قال : قال رسول الله : لو لم أُبعث فیکم لبعث عمر . . ! !

Narration two: Isma'il ibn Ahmad told us, saying: Ibn Mas'adah informed us, saying: Jumrah informed us, saying: [U]bn 'Adiyy informed us, saying: Ali ibn al-Hasan ibn Qadid narrated to us, saying: Zakariya ibn Yahya al-Wuqad narrated to us, saying: Bashar ibn Bakr narrated to us, from Abu Bakr ibn Abdullah ibn Maryam, from Hamzah ibn Habib, from 'Udhayf (722) ibn al-Harith, from Bilal ibn Riyah, who said: The Messenger of Allah said: "If I had not been sent among you, 'Umar would have been sent instead..." ! !

footnote.p: (722) [A] with the dotted dhad, in diminutive form. (12).

para.p: قال ابن عدی : وحدّثنا عمر بن الحسن بن نصر الحلبی ، قال : حدّثنا مصعب بن سعد ، أبو خثیمة ، قال : حدّثنا عبد الله بن واقد ، قال : حدّثنا حیاة بن شریح ، عن بکر بن عمر ، وعن مشرح بن هاعان ، عن عقبة بن عامر ، قال : قال رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم : لو لم أُبعث فیکم لبعث عمر . . ! !

Ibn 'Adiyy said: And 'Umar ibn al-Hasan ibn Nasr al-Halabi narrated to us, saying: Mus'ab ibn Sa'd, Abu Khuthaymah, narrated to us, saying: Abdullah ibn Waqid narrated to us, saying: Hayat ibn Shuraikh narrated to us, from Bakr ibn 'Umar, and from Musharrah ibn Ha'yan, from Uqbah ibn 'Amir, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) said: "If I had not been sent among you, 'Umar would have been sent instead..." ! !
قال المصنف : هذان حدیثان لا یصحّان عن رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم . .
The author said: These are two hadiths that are not authentic from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)…
أمّا الأول : فإن زکریا بن یحیی کان من الکذابین الکبار ، قال ابن عدی : کان یضع الحدیث .
As for the first: Zakariyya ibn Yahya was one of the great liars. Ibn 'Adiyy said: He used to fabricate hadith.
وأما الثانی : فقال أحمد ویحیی : عبد الله بن واقد لیس بشیء .
And as for the second: Ahmad and Yahya said: Abdullah ibn Waqid is nothing.
وقال النسائی : متروک الحدیث .
An-Nasa'i said: His narrations are to be left.
وقال ابن حبّان : انقلبت علی مشرح صحائفه ، فبطل الاحتجاج به (723) .
Ibn Hibban said: The records of Musharrah became distorted, rendering his testimony invalid. (723)

footnote.p: (723) [A] was met with in the text of the book "Al-Mawdu'at" by Ibn al-Jawzi, in its original form, and I have it with you, Alhamdulillah, but it is about half, not complete. (12). [Al-Mawdu'at 1 / 320 - 321]

para.p: Al-Tabarani narrated this hadith through another chain from 'Ismat ibn Malik, and
Weakness is also found in his narrations, as esteemed Hakim Mirza Muhammad, may Allah exalt his status in the Abode of Honor, quoted from “Faiz al-Qadeer Sharh Jami' Saghir”:

لوکان بعدی نبیّ لکان عمر بن الخطاب. حم (724) ت (725) ک (726) عن عقبة بن عامر ; طب (727)، عن عصمة بن مالک ; قال البیهقی : وفیه الفضل بن المختار ، وهو ضعیف ; وأمّا خبر الدیلمی عن أبی هریرة : لو لم أُبعث لبعث عمر، فمنکر(728).

If there were to be a prophet after me, it would be Umar ibn al-Khattab. Ham (724) Ta (725) Kaf (726) from Uqbah ibn Amir; Tab (727), from Ismat ibn Malik; al-Bayhaqi said: And in it is Fadl ibn al-Mukhtar, and he is weak; and as for the report of al-Daylami from Abu Huraira: If I had not been sent, Umar would have been sent, it is rejected. (728)

footnote.p: (724) [A] Ahmad in the Musnad.
(725) [A] and Tirmidhi.
(726) [A] al-Hakim in the Mustadrak.
(727) [A] al-Tabarani.
(728) Faiz al-Qadeer 5 / 414.

para.p: And in “Kanz al-Ummal,” under the tabulation in “Jam' al-Jawami'” it is mentioned:
لو کان بعدی نبیّ لکنتَه ، قاله لعمر .
If there were to be a prophet after me, I would be him, he said this to Umar.
الخطیب فی رواة مالک ; وابن عساکر عن ابن عمر ، وقال : منکر .
Al-Khatib in Rawat Malik; and Ibn Asakir from Ibn Umar, and said: It is rejected.
لو لم أُبعث فیکم لبعث عمر .
If I had not been sent among you, Umar would have been sent.
عد (729) . وقال : غریب .
Ad (729). And he said: Strange.

footnote.p: (729) [A] Ibn Adi.

para.p: کر (730) . عن عقبة بن عامر .
Karr (730). An Ibn Qubaybih ibn ʿAmir .

footnote.p: (730) [A] Ibn ʿAsaakir.

para.p: عد . کر . عن بلال بن ریاح (731) .
ʿAd . Karr . An Bilal ibn Riyah. (731)

footnote.p: (731) In [A] it is mistakenly added here: (And ʿAd said: from Bilal ibn Riyah).

para.p: وقال عد : غیر محفوظ . وأوردهما ابن الجوزی فی الموضوعات . (732) انتهی .
And ʿAd said: Not preserved (ghayr mahfuẓ). And Ibn al-Jawzi mentioned both of them in (false traditions) al-Mawduʿat (732). Ended.

footnote.p: (732) [A] Virtues of ʿOmar ibn al-Khattab, in the section on actions. (12). [b] Kanz al-ʿAmaal 6 / 33. [Kanz al-ʿAmaal 11 / 581 (printed by Maktabat al-ʿIrfan, Beirut).

para.p: And it is mentioned in "Kanz al-Ummal":
عن ابن عمر : قال رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم لعمر بن الخطاب : لو کان بعدی نبیّ لکنته .
From Ibn ʿUmar: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) said to ʿUmar ibn al-Khattab: "If there were to be a prophet after me, it would be you."
خط (733) . وقال : منکرا (734) .
Khat (733). And he said: Denounced (Munkar). (734)

footnote.p: (734) In the source: (Denounced (Munkar). Karr). [A] Virtues of ʿOmar ibn al-Khattab, in the section on statements. (12). [B] Kanz al-ʿAmaal 6 / 147. [Kanz al-ʿAmaal 12 / 597 (printed by Maktabat al-ʿIrfan, Beirut).

para.p: As for what he said: the Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) contradiction is that he might engage in something he has prohibited, not that someone rejected by him would be appointed.
Then, the answer is that the Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) contradiction is broader than merely opposing his verbal command.

It may be that the Master was present or that the actions of that Master (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) were in opposition, and never did anyone restrict the opposition to what the Addressee mentioned; the Ahle Tasannun demonstrated perfect love in three things to repel their reproaches <102>, other falsehoods and slanders they would fabricate, and they were not afraid of the obligation of hearing them. Now, it has come to the point that they have started to deny the meanings of words as well!!

As for what he said: if doing something that that Master (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not do were to be an opposition to that Master, it would necessitate that His Eminence, Amir al-Momineen (peace be upon him), also opposed that noble one by fighting with Aisha.

The response is that the scholars of the Shia have not said that the mere act of an action which that Master (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not do, without the apparent reprehensibility of it, is an opposition to that Master. Rather, their intention is that the removal of Umar from the governance of charities (sadaqaat) is evidence of his incompetence, and opposing the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) in the oversight of the affairs of all Muslims with someone whose incompetence in overseeing some matters becomes apparent is, without doubt, reprehensible.

Moreover, this correlation would only have some semblance of reason if Aisha, at the time of the life of His Excellency, the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), opposed Allah, which is indicated by (وَقَرْنَ فِی بُیُوتِکُنَّ) “And stay in your houses” (735), emerging from her house without the permission of that Master and mounting a camel, and riding along with her nephew, she was galloping across a city of the Muslim lands; and the agent of that Holy Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), like Uthman ibn Hunayf, was being dragged out of the city by his beard, and the wealth of the city’s treasury (Bayt al-Mal) was being brought under his control; and despite these actions, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not engage in defending against this chaos (fitnah) and corruption.

footnote.p: (735) Surah al-Ahzab (33): 33.

para.p: And when Aisha became the source of these actions after the passing of that Holy Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), and he (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) had addressed Ali, the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him), saying: «ستقاتل بعدی الناکثین والقاسطین والمارقین» "You will fight the Those Who Break the Pledge (Nakithin), Those Who Be unjust (Qasiteen), and Those Who Estrange (Mariqeen) after me" (736); and had said to Zubair: «ستقاتله وأنت له ظالم» "You will fight him, and you will be unjust to him" (737). That is, you will engage in battle, Ali (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), with Aisha, while you be unjust.

footnote.p: (736) See Mulhiqaat Ihqaq al-Haqq 21 / 686.
(737) See Mulhiqaat Ihqaq al-Haqq 17 / 349 and 23 / 284 and 37 / 419, 496.

chapter.title: Sixth Criticism: Abu Bakr and Umar were put under the authority of others

para.p: Dehalvi’s claim
He said: Sixth Objection:

That the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him and his holy [and sacred] progeny, made Abu Bakr and Umar manifestations and followers of Amr ibn al-As, and appointed him as their leader, and similarly appointed Osama as their commander, if they had the competency for leadership, or if they were more deserving and preferable in this matter, why did he not make them leaders and instead make others subordinate to them?
The response to this objection has been stated in several ways:

First: That if not appointing them as leaders indicates either their lack of competency or that they are not the most excellent, then appointing someone else as a leader would necessarily indicate competency and superiority. If the Shia believe in the competency of Amr ibn al-As and Osama ibn Zayd for the Imamate and assert their superiority, then in this matter, the Ahle Tasannun would need to provide a response; otherwise, they would not.

Second: That there is no disgrace in specifically appointing an inferior (mafzul) as a leader over a superior (afzal), and this specific appointment does not indicate superiority or the competency for the greater leadership (Imamate al-Kubra); because in a specific preliminary matter of granting leadership, it is often based on a particular perceived necessity that, such expedience will ultimately be achieved by one of the lesser and fewer ones, not by the more virtuous and better ones, like what happened in the governance of Amr ibn al-As, who was a man of wisdom and possessed of cunning and stratagems. The aim was precisely this, to ruin his rivals through cunning and deceit, or he was aware of the plots of his rivals and their entanglements and hidden places. Others do not have this awareness, just as such persons are often given for thievery and clearing the way, night watch, and troop commanding, and such tasks are never accomplished by the great commanders.

Or in a specific leadership, the intent may be to provide solace and comfort to the heart of one who is grieving and mourning, and who has suffered injustice, as was the case with Osama, whose father had been martyred by the troops of Syria and Rome. If he were not made a leader and did not avenge his (738) father, he would not find solace, comfort, or attain a name and status.

footnote.p: (738) The addition is from the source.

para.p: Third: That the noble Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy [and pure] lineage, intended that Abu Bakr and Umar would inform [him] (739) of the dealings that the appointed ones and followers (Tabi'un) would have with the commander, and what kind of assurance should be given regarding the situation of the followers and the appointed ones. This matter could not be truly known with certainty (haqq al-yaqin) without once or twice making them subordinate to someone and appointing them under someone. Thus, it seems that this subordination was intended as a form of spiritual training (riyada) and the education of leadership (Reyasat) [and] (740) authority (Imarat) was such that it was as if the kings of resolute determination (Ulu al-Azm) had not ultimately fulfilled this greatest rank – as is its due – until they had transitioned from the army (Sepah) to authority (Imarat), from authority to ministry (Vizarat), and from ministry to sovereignty (Sultanat), like Timur and Nader Shah, and the likes of them; thus, their upbringing in this manner explicitly indicates that a major leadership (Reyasat) was intended in their regard, under the consideration of the grace (Karamat) of the Prophet's effect (Nabi) (741), peace be upon him and his holy progeny (peace be upon them).

footnote.p: (739) The addition is from the source.
(740) The addition is from the source.
(741) In [A] - despite a subsequent salutation - there was mistakenly a salutation (S) here as well.

para.p: And in this same manner (742), that noble one (Sallallahu ʿalayh [wa alih] wa Sallam) would be in regard to these two, both of them maintained their armies and commanders in such a way that a better arrangement than this is unimaginable, neither would their commanders entertain thoughts of rebellion (and independence, nor would the soldiers show signs of laziness, neglect, or idle behavior in plunder and killing and looting, and there could be no form of injustice or oppression, nor disdain or indication over the commanders and their armies, and the subjects would rest in a cradle of safety and security, spending their time at ease, and conquests would be continuous, with spoils (743) and profits accruing to them day by day, and this matter is clearer than the sun and more evident than yesterday to those well-versed in the field.

footnote.p: (742) In the source [training]
(743) In the source (complete)

para.p: In actual occurrences, Shi'ism does not advance, and what is the might and exaggeration of Shi'ism in matters is delusional; if it were like that, it would be good, and if it were (744) such, it would be better. (745)

footnote.p: (744) In the source: (such).
(745) Tuhfah Ithna Ashariyyah: 268-269.

para.p: The response from the respected author
I say:

As for what he said: if a Shia believes in the worthiness of leadership for Amr ibn al-As and Osama ibn Zayd, and holds them to be superior, then in this matter, the Ahle Tasannun would need to respond – is not unfounded.

Then the response is that if a Shia were to maintain that Abu Bakr and Umar were of a lesser rank than Osama and Amr ibn al-As, this belief does not necessitate an acknowledgment of the worthiness of Amr ibn al-As and Osama for the Greater Imamate; rather, the utmost that can be concluded from this is that Osama and Amr ibn al-As were superior to Abu Bakr, Umar, and their likes, and this does not imply the worthiness of the Greater Imamate; because, in the Greater Imamate, superiority over all subjects, as well as infallibility and Divine Appointment, is also a condition.

It is remarkable that this seemingly educated person who is an ardent enemy of the Ahlul Bait (peace be upon them) (Nasibi) for the sake of deceiving the masses, despite claiming knowledge and virtue, utters such futile superstitions, overlooking the explanations of recognized scholars, and bases his answers on his own delusions and fantasies. The intent of the People of Truth from this criticism was that: superiority (afzal) is a condition in leadership (Imamat). is, especially in matters of politics, where they hold that superiority in this area is also a condition for others who deny the stipulation of superiority. This narrative clearly indicates that Osama and Amr ibn al-As were superior to the two Shaykhs [i.e., Abu Bakr and Umar]. Thus, if superiority in matters of politics, which is a primary condition of caliphate, is not established in the two Shaykhs, they would not be worthy of the caliphate.

The Addressee averts from this explanation and resorts to this superstition, claiming that according to this, it must be that the Shia believe in the caliphate and imamate for Amr ibn al-As [and] Osama. One must be fair and ask, what relevance does this statement have with the explanation of the people of truth?!
As for what he said: second, that in a specific matter, appointing an inferior over a superior is not inherently shameful.

The reply to this is that anyone who maintains the reprehensibility of prioritizing an inferior over a superior will do so in any context; and anyone who does not believe it to be reprehensible will not hold this in any context. Claiming that there is no shame in appointing an inferior over a superior in a specific matter is a breach of a compounded consensus.
As for what he said: and this specific appointment does not indicate superiority.
This is false because Jalal al-Din al-Suyuti narrated in "Jami' al-Jawa'mi'" that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) said:
« أیّما رجل استعمل رجلا علی عشرة أنفس ، علم أن فی العشرة أفضل ممّن استعمل ، فقد غشّ الله وغشّ رسوله وغشّ جماعة المسلمین » . ع (746) . عن حذیفة (747) .

"Whoever appoints a man over ten people, knowing that among the ten there is someone better than the one he appointed, has indeed betrayed Allah, betrayed the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy family), and betrayed the Muslim community.”" (746) Narrated from Hudhayfah. (747)

footnote.p: (746) [A and B] ie. Narrated by Abu Ya'la.
(747) [A] Compared to the original collection of "Jami' al-Jawa'mi'" in the letter Alif. (12). [Jami' al-Ahadith (Jami' al-Jawa'mi') 3 / 398, Kanz al-'Umal 6 / 19].

para.p: That is: Any man who appoints another man over ten people should know that among those ten people, there is one (748) who is better than the one he has appointed. Thus, verily, that appointer has betrayed God and His Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and the congregation of Muslims.

footnote.p: (748) Apparently, "(a person)" is correct.

para.p: Shah Waliyullah al-Dehalwi has narrated in "Ila'at al-Khafa" from al-Hakim that Abdullah ibn Abbas narrated from the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) that he said:
"Whoever appoints a man from a group, and within that group, there is someone more pleasing to God than him, has indeed betrayed God, betrayed His Messenger, and betrayed the believers." (749)

footnote.p: (749) Izalat al-Khafa 1 / 16.

para.p: And it is mentioned in "Fath al-Bari":

روی إسحاق بن راهویه والحاکم من حدیث بریدة : ان عمرو بن العاص أمرهم فی تلک الغزوة أن لا یوقدوا ناراً ، فأنکر ذلک عمر ، فقال له أبو بکر : دعه ، فإن رسول الله صلی الله علیه[ وآله ] وسلّم لم یبعثه علینا إلاّ لعلمه بالحرب ، فسکت عنه .

Ishaq ibn Rahuya and al-Hakim narrated from the hadith of Buraydah that Amr ibn al-As commanded them in that expedition not to light a fire, and Umar disapproved of this. Abu Bakr said to him, "Leave him, for the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)… [And his Family] and Peace be upon him was not sent against us except for his knowledge of warfare, so he remained silent about it.
فهذا السبب أصحّ إسناداً من الذی ذکره ابن إسحاق ، لکن لا یمتنع الجمع .
This reason has a more authentic chain of transmission than what Ibn Ishaq mentioned, but combining them is not precluded.

و روی ابن حبان – من طریق قیس بن حازم – ، عن عمرو بن العاص : إن رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم بعثه فی ذات السلاسل ، فسأله أصحابه أن یوقدوا ناراً ، فمنعهم ، فکلّموا أبا بکر ، فکلّمه فی ذلک فقال : لا یوقد أحد منکم ناراً إلاّ قذفته فیها .

Ibn Hibban narrated – through Qays ibn Hazim – from Amr ibn al-As: Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy Family) sent him in the Expedition of Dhatu al-Salasil, and his companions asked him to light a fire, but he prevented them. So, they spoke to Abu Bakr, and he interceded for them in this matter, saying: "No one of you shall light a fire, except that I will cast him into it."

قال : فلقوا العدو فهزموهم ، فأرادوا أن یتبعوهم ، فمنعهم ، فلمّا انصرفوا ذکروا ذلک للنبیّ ، فسأله ، فقال : کرهت أن آذن لهم أن یوقدوا ناراً ، فیری عدوهم قلّتهم ، وکرهت أن یتبعوهم فیکون لهم مدد ; فحمد أمره . (750) انتهی به قدر الحاجة .

He said: Then they encountered the enemy and defeated them, but they wanted to pursue them, and he prevented them. When they returned, they mentioned this to the Prophet, and he asked him about it. He said: "I disliked to permit them to light a fire, as it would show their enemy their small numbers, and I disliked them pursuing them, as it would mean reinforcements for them"; so he praised his decision. (750) This concludes him to the extent necessary.

footnote.p: (750) [A] Kitab al-Ghazawat, Expedition of Dhatu al-Salasil (12). [B] Fath al-Bari 8/54 (Cairo edition 1325). [Fath al-Bari 8/59].

para.p: And it is mentioned in "Rawdat al-Ahbab" during the narration of the Expedition of Dhatu al-Salasil that:
Amr ibn al-As said: "Let no one light a fire, or I will throw him into the fire."

And one narration is that Umar al-Faruq denied this to Amr and spoke harshly. Amr said: "O Umar! Were you not commanded to listen to my words and obey?!" He replied, "Yes." Amr said: "Then embody that command," and Abu Bakr said to Umar: "Leave him to his own state, for indeed, the dignified Messenger of God, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, did not appoint him as an Amir over us except because he understands the necessities of war well. (751) Thus ends the quote.

footnote.p: (751) Rawdat al-Aḥbaab, p. 119-120.

para.p: And from the appointment of Amr ibn al-As over the two Sheikhs during the battle of Dhat al-Salasil, along with the statements in "Fath al-Bari" and "Rawdat al-Ahbab," it also became clear that Amr ibn al-As was more knowledgeable than Abu Bakr and Umar regarding the necessities of war.

And certainly, Imam Amir al-Momineen Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him) was more knowledgeable than Amr ibn al-As about the necessities of war, as had previously manifested during this very battle, so Imam Amir al-Momineen (peace be upon him) was more knowledgeable than Abu Bakr and Umar regarding the necessities of war; and the evidences of his superiority over all the Companions in every matter concerning Imamate have been discussed and elaborated upon in full. (752)

footnote.p: (752) This refers to the book "Burhaan al-Sa'aadah" by the author; please refer to the introduction of the investigation.

para.p: As for what he said: because it is mentioned in the specific introduction to granting authority... to the end.

Then it is flawed by the fact that if the jihad against the disbelievers and the combat against the wicked opposers – which are among the greatest pillars of the caliphate and the pinnacle of Islam – were being carried out well by Amr ibn al-As in the sight of the audience, and nothing was being accomplished by the two Sheikhs, this is a clear admission of the superiority of Amr ibn al-As over the two Sheikhs in the matter of governance; and if the two Sheikhs were also inferior to others in matters of governance, how could they be deserving of the caliphate?!
As for what he said: like what occurred in the leadership of Amr ibn al-As, who was a shrewd man and possessed of cunning and trickery.

Then, it is a complete wonder (753) that the Addressee shows contempt and denigration of Amr ibn al-As and belittles him, while he is considered one of the prominent companions among the Ahle Tasannun. And aside from the explicit statements of the Ahle Tasannun regarding the obligation to honor and exalt all companions, and the prohibition of belittling and insulting them, they especially narrate hadiths of virtue concerning Amr ibn al-As as well, unless – seemingly – the hadiths of his virtue were also considered fabricated by the Addressee!

footnote.p: (753) [A] f [Faydah:] Denigration of Amr ibn al-As, a companion (Sahaabī).

para.p: And also, the complete piety and alertness and understanding and insight of the Addressee regarding the people of reason and religion became evident [that] the so-called scholar, the Addressee, refers to the one appointed by the Prophet of the the two worlds, and the Commander of the Two Shaykhs as a shrewd man and one possessed of cunning and trickery.

It is also evident that the esteemed gentlemen, the two Shaykhs, must have learned all these attributes from their teacher and commander well, as they were specifically appointed for this, by the acknowledgment of the one addressed.
As for what he said: in a specific leadership offering condolences and comforting the heart of one who is grief-stricken, mourning, and wronged is intended.

So in the case of submission, what necessity is there for someone superior to him to also be made his commander? And if that were the case, it should have been that the Commander of the Faithful, Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him), would also be made his commander. (754)

footnote.p: (754) [A] Yes, if the two Shaykhs had killed Osama's father, it would have been possible that his consolation in obtaining authority over them was limited to that! (12).

para.p: And this is the answer to what has been said:

Third: That the intention of the Holy Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was that he inform Abu Bakr and Umar about the matters that the appointed ones would face with the Leader… until the end.

Because if that Noble One (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) had intended this, he would occasionally have made the Commander of the Faithful, Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him), a commander of someone else, and since this matter has not occasionally occurred, we understand that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) considered the precedence of the lesser over the greater (afzal) to be incorrect (qabih) and blameworthy, and this is the objective.

Unless the superior argues that – seeking refuge in Allah from that – the Noble One of the Message (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not want the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) to attain the caliphate, and therefore did not make that Noble One subordinate to anyone, nor taught or trained him.

And the occurrence of conquests and spoils cannot be taken as evidence of truth, for if it were, then Genghis Khan and other disbelievers and reprobates (fajir) upon whom consecutive conquests occurred in their dominion must have been on the truth!

chapter.title: Seventh Criticism: The Appointment of Umar ibn Khattab as Caliph Despite Belief in the Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) Non-Designation

para.p: Dehalvi’s claim
He said: Seventh Objection:

That Abu Bakr al-Siddiq opposed that esteemed one (the Prophet) [(peace be upon him and his holy progeny)] in his appointment of a successor, is undoubtedly clear, and it is well-known that the nobility of the Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, understood well the advantages and disadvantages, and he had complete compassion and kindness towards his community. He did not appoint anyone as a caliph over his community, while Abu Bakr appointed Umar as a caliph.
Responses to this objection have been given in several ways:

First: The claim that he (the Prophet) (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not appoint a successor for his community is a blatant lie and slander; because all the Shia believe that the noble Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, appointed Amir (Ali) (peace be upon him) as his successor. And if Abu Bakr also followed the tradition of the Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, and appointed a successor for the community, then from where would an opposition arise?

And if they speak according to the belief of the Ahle Tasannun, then indeed, the scholars among the Ahle Tasannun also assert the appointment of a successor in prayer (salat) and in pilgrimage (hajj); and the companions who were the secret interpreters of the Prophet, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, and could grasp the subtleties and understand the signs of that most pure one, (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), would find this sufficient.

And Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, considering that many people from both Arabs and non-Arabs had recently entered Islam, [and] would not understand these subtleties without explicit statement, designation, and a covenant, wrote, recited, and presented them.

Second: That the Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) not appointing a successor was because he knew with certainty, through Divine Revelation and heavenly inspiration, that after him (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), Abu Bakr would be the successor, and the virtuous companions would reach a consensus on him, not including anyone else, as indicated by the narrations: (فأبی علي إلاّ تقدیم أبي بکر) "He refused me except to advance Abu Bakr," and (یأبی الله والمؤمنون إلاّ أبا بکر) "Allah and the believers refuse except for Abu Bakr," and (إنه الخليفة من بعدي) "He is the successor after me," which are explicitly present in the "Sahih" of the Ahle Tasannun; since he had this certainty, the need for appointing a successor and writing a covenant was eliminated.
As mentioned in "Sahih Muslim," it is stated that:

In the illness of his passing, he had summoned Abu Bakr and his son to write a covenant of succession, but then said: "The Exalted Truth and the Muslims will not, of themselves, appoint anyone as a successor other than Abu Bakr. There is no need to write," he had deemed it [sufficiently resolved].

In contrast to Abu Bakr, he was not receiving revelation to attain certain knowledge, nor had he inferred from the situation of the people through signs that after me, without a doubt, Umar ibn al-Khattab would be appointed as successor, and he believed, in his own reasoning, that appointing Umar was the most suitable for the religion and the community. Thus, it became necessary for him to act on what he found to be in the best interest of the community, and, thank God, his intellect functioned, and the might of the religion and the order of the affairs of the nation and the multitude of killings (755) of unbelievers that occurred at the hands of Umar are not recorded in any history as having been authorized by the caliph of any prophet.

footnote.p: (755) In the source (overthrow)
