para.p: Third: Not making a testamentary appointment (istikhlaf) is one thing, and forbidding it is another; opposition would only occur if he were to forbid making a testamentary appointment (istikhlaf), while Abu Bakr was making one, not that the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not make a testamentary appointment (istikhlaf) and Abu Bakr did; otherwise, it would imply that the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) was opposing the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) in the testamentary appointment (istikhlaf) of Imam Hasan (peace be upon him). Far from Allah be that (756).

footnote.p: (756) Tuhfat al-Ithnaa ʿAshariyya: 269.

para.p: The response from the respected author
I say:
Know that <107> ʻAbd al-Razzaq Lahiji has said in his book "Gohar Murad":

Sixth: That he appointed Umar as caliph himself, while the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), in their belief, had not made a testamentary appointment (istikhlaf), so if making a testamentary appointment (istikhlaf) was good, why did the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) not do it, and if it was bad, why did Abu Bakr do it? And Umar, at the time of his death, said:
إن لم أستخلف فإن رسول الله ( صلی الله علیه وآله ) لم یستخلف ، وإن أستخلف فإن أبا بکر استخلف.

"If I do not make a testamentary appointment (istikhlaf), it is because the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not make a testamentary appointment (istikhlaf), and if I do make one, it is because Abu Bakr made a testamentary appointment (istikhlaf)."
وهذا تصریح منه بعدم استخلاف النبیّ [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله و سلم ) ] (757) .
And this is a clear statement from him regarding the lack of testamentary appointment (istikhlaf) by the Prophet [(peace be upon him and his holy progeny)] (757).

footnote.p: (757) Gohar Murad: 409.

para.p: And Qazi al-Qozat (Ibn Khallikan) in the book "Mughni" stated in his explanation of this criticism:
إن أبا بکر نصّ علی عمر و ترک التأسی بالرسول ; لأنه لم یستخلف (758) .
Indeed, Abu Bakr explicitly appointed Umar and left off emulating the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny); because he did not appoint a successor (758).
And the prominent scholar Khwaja Nasir al-Din Tusi, in his explanation of this criticism, said:
وخالف الرسول فی الاستخلاف [ عندهم ] . (759) انتهی .
And he opposed the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) in the appointment of a successor [in their view]. (759) End.

footnote.p: (759) [al-Sharh] Tajrid al-I'tiqad 295. [Tajrid al-I'tiqad: 400 (Zanjani's edition), and page: 508 (Ameli's edition), and page: 203 (Subhani's edition)], and the addition is from the source.

para.p: And this criticism is taken from the words of Umar mentioned in "Sahih Bukhari" and "Sahih Muslim," as Ibn Hajar stated in "Sawa'iq Muhriqah" in the fourth chapter of the first section while explaining the evidences supporting the assertion of the absence of explicit appointment by the Messenger (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) of one individual:
و ما أخرجه الشیخان عن عمر أنه قال – حین طُعن : إن أستخلف فقد استخلف من هو خیر منی – یعنی أبا بکر – وإن أترککم فقد ترککم من هو خیر منی – یعنی رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم (760) .

And what both Shaykhan narrated from Umar that he said – when he was criticized: "If he appointed a successor, then he appointed one better than me" – meaning Abu Bakr; "and if he leaves you, then he leaves one better than me" – meaning the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny). (760)

footnote.p: (760) [Sahih Muslim 3 / 1454 (Cairo edition, 1976), and Sahih Bukhari 8 / 126 (Cairo edition, 1936). [Sawa'iq Muhriqah 1 / 69, Sahih Muslim 6 / 4, Sahih Bukhari 8 / 126].

para.p: That is: It indicates the lack of an explicit appointment from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) regarding the leadership (Khilafah) of one individual, what both Shaykhan have narrated – meaning Muslim and Bukhari – from Umar, indeed spoke truthfully when he said – at the time when the dagger was struck -: "If I appoint a caliph, then surely someone better than me has appointed a caliph" – meaning Abu Bakr – "and if I [were to] leave you, then indeed someone better than me has left you" – meaning the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny).
And Waliyullah in his treatise "Tafdeel al-Shaykhayn" (Excellence of the Two Shaykhs) after narrating this statement of Umar, said:
So the people understood that the noble Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not appoint anyone as a caliph, and Umar was not suspicious of Abu Bakr. (761) End.

footnote.p: (761) Qurrat al-Aynayn: 196.

para.p: Meaning: Thus, the people recognized that the Noble Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not appoint anyone as a caliph, and Umar is not suspected of enmity towards Abu Bakr; that is, no one can accuse Umar of this meaning, that he said this out of enmity towards Abu Bakr.

And what indicates that Umar considered it praiseworthy not to appoint a caliph is that afterwards he himself did not designate a specific caliph, but rather placed it in the hands of a council of six people. Thus, Umar’s statement and action indicate that Abu Bakr, in Umar’s belief, acted contrary to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) in the appointment of a successor. (762)

footnote.p: (762) 2- [A and B] I say: There is no doubt that appointing a successor entails many significant interests and numerous benefits; from saving the creation from conflict and strife that leads to destruction and ruin, to uniting the word of the Muslims, which leads to the prosperity of both this world and the Hereafter. Therefore, Ibn Umar said to his father: "They claim that you are not appointing a successor, and that if you had a shepherd of sheep or a herdsman of camels, then if he came to you and left them, you would see that he has wasted them; the care of people is even more important!" Thus, his article concludes as found in their authentic texts. [See: Sahih Muslim 6/5, Sunan al-Kubra li al-Bayhaqi 8/149, Fath al-Bari 13/177, and others]. From here, the parent of the one who opposes inclined towards the necessity of explicit designation, and he even stated this in "Izalat al-Khifaa [1/6] and Qurrat al-Aynayn [: 115]; whoever wishes can refer to them. There is also no doubt that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) was more compassionate towards his ummah than to leave them as a herd, wandering in every valley, not knowing the path of guidance. And how could it be, when he clarified specific interests and established rulings even on minor matters, to the extent of informing them about manners in the bathroom, eating and drinking, interacting with women, and raising children? So, if it is assumed that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not appoint a successor - as it is claimed by those of the Sunni perspective - there is no doubt that it would be for significant harms and great misdeeds that could be envisioned in appointing a successor, such that those interests would oppose and overwhelm them, necessitating his decision to refrain from it. Thus, appointing a successor in this case would be a clear sin and a great crime, meaning that Abu Bakr, in the appointment of Umar, would be committing an act of prohibitive nature and a source of immense wrongdoings. This establishes an argument that refutes all their flimsy interpretations and invalidates the majority of their absurd justifications, and it is clear, with it, praise be to Allah, and from Him is success.

para.p: As for what is said: that the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not make that Immaculate One a caliph over the ummah, is a clear lie and slander; because all the Shia believe that the noble Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) appointed Amir al-Momineen (peace be upon him) as a caliph.

Thus, it is pure folly; because the intention of the scholars of the Shia in this statement is that, according to the belief of Ahle Tasannun, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) had a designated caliph over his ummah. he had not appointed him, so Abu Bakr's opposition to the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny)’s appointment of Umar in succession – in the belief of Ahle Tasannun – might also have occurred, just as it is explicitly mentioned in the words of the esteemed Abd al-Razzaq that:
The Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not, in their belief, meaning in the belief of Ahle Tasannun, appoint a successor. (763)

footnote.p: (763) Gohar Murad: 409

para.p: As for what he has said: and if Abu Bakr also followed the Sunnah of his prophet, may peace be upon him and his holy progeny, and appointed a successor over the ummah, from where would the opposition arise?

Then it is a source of utmost astonishment that he himself acknowledges that, in the eyes of the Shia, the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) appointed Ali, the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him), as his successor, and yet Abu Bakr's further appointment of Umar – which is a direct opposition to the Messenger of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) and an antagonism to him – is termed an agreement (764).

footnote.p: (764) That is, if he responds on this assumption that the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) appointed the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) as his successor; then in this case, there is no reason for anyone else to have the right to choose a successor (خلیفه), rather, in this case, choosing a successor would be a clear opposition to the successor appointed by that holy person.

para.p: As for, what he has said: if they are speaking according to the doctrine of Ahle Tasannun, then the scholars of Ahle Tasannun also believe in succession, in prayer and in Hajj.
Therefore, the matter is not devoid of two possibilities:

Or that the succession (istikhlaf) in prayer and in Hajj is the same as the succession (istikhlaf) being discussed, or necessitates it; thus, it is contradictory and in opposition to what was said in Chapter Seven regarding the fourth belief:
Then, the most appropriate for the legal incumbents (mukallafin) is that they leave the appointment of a leader to their reason. (765)

footnote.p: (765) Tuhfat al-Ithnaa ʿAshariyyah: 179.

para.p: Because, in this case, it would follow that something contrary to what was most appropriate for the legal incumbents (mukallafin) had been done by the Holy Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny).

And this idea is also contradictory and in opposition to the statement of the majority of Ahle Tasannun; because the belief of the majority of Ahle Tasannun is that the Prophet of God (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not appoint anyone as a successor, as Ibn Hajar said in "Sawa'iq Muhriqah":
قال جمهور أهل السنة والمعتزلة والخوارج : لم ینصّ علی أحد (766) .
The majority of the Ahle Tasannun, the Mu'tazilah, and the Khawarij said: He did not specify anyone. (766)

footnote.p: (766) [B] al-Sawaa'iq: 25. [Sawaa'iq Muhriqah 1/69 (Maktabat al-Nahda al-ʿIlmiyyah, Beirut)

para.p: And Nawawi, in "Sharh Sahih Muslim," said in the commentary on the hadith: ( سُئلت عائشة : من کان رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم مستخلِفاً لو استخلَف ؟ قالت : أبو بکر . . إلی آخره ) (ʿA'ishah was asked, "Who would the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny and may His blessings be upon them) appoint as a successor (ikhilaf) if he were to appoint one?" She replied, "Abu Bakr...") stated:

This indicates to Ahle Tasannun that the caliphate of Abu Bakr... was not by a text (naṣṣ) from the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny and may His blessings be upon them) explicitly on his caliphate (khilafah), rather, it was a consensus.

الصحابة علی عقد الخلافة له ، وتقدیمه لفضله ، ولو کان هناک نصّ علیه أو علی غیره لم تقع المنازعة من الأنصار وغیرهم أولا ; ولذکر حافظ النصّ ما معه ولرجعوا إلیه ، لکن تنازعوا أولا و لم یکن هناک نصّ ، ثم اتفقوا علی أبی بکر (767) .

The companions were united on the matter of his caliphate and his precedence due to his virtues, and if there had been a text appointing him or anyone else, there would not have been initial dispute among the Ansar (Ansar) and others; and the one who remembered the text would have mentioned what he had, and they would have returned to it. However, they initially disputed, and there was no text there, then they agreed on Abu Bakr. (767)

footnote.p: (767) [A] Al-Kitab al-Fada'il, Fada'il Abu Bakr. [Sharh Muslim li-Nawawi 15 / 154].

para.p: Or that the appointment (istikhlaf) in prayer and in Hajj is neither the same as the appointment being discussed nor does it entail it, so mentioning it might be mere redundancy and pure fluff, and Abu Bakr's opposition in the appointment of Umar with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) remains established in its own right, for in this case, the appointment that Abu Bakr made was not something that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) had specified.

As for what he said: the companions who were interpreters of the Prophet's (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) symbols and knowledgeable in subtleties, understood the indications of that most pure being, was that this much was sufficient.

Then, the answer is that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) had, on several other occasions, also commanded the companions to lead in prayer and perform Hajj, and if this had been sufficient, it would imply that they too should be considered caliphs.

As for what he said: the second reason the Prophet (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) did not appoint a caliph was that he, through Divine Revelation (wahy) and heavenly inspiration (ilham), knew with certainty that after him, Abu Bakr would be the caliph, and the chosen companions would reach a consensus over him.

Then, of course, the noble Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny) knew that Abu Bakr would usurp and wrongfully claim the caliphate after him, and that the wicked companions would come to a consensus against him.

And a consensus of the good companions on him was never established; rather, the best and last of the companions, who was the revered Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him), did not swear allegiance to Abu Bakr for up to six months, nor did the other members of Banu Hashim, who were among the good companions, swear allegiance in obedience to him. Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him), Ammar (may Allah be pleased with him), Salman (may Allah be pleased with him), Miqdad (may Allah be pleased with him), and others also refrained from his allegiance, and Sa'ad ibn Ubadah – who is considered among the good companions by the Ahle Tasannun – did not pledge allegiance to him, nor did he do so to Umar until he died.

For this reason, Fakhr al-Razi has stated in “Nihayat al-Uqul” that a consensus (<109>) on the allegiance to Abu Bakr was not achieved except after the death of Sa'ad ibn Ubadah! (768) Similarly, the Ansar disputed in the caliphate of Abu Bakr.

footnote.p: (768) Nihayat al-Uqul, page: 272, text: 549.

para.p: As for what he said: just as the hadith… until the end.

So, if the majority of the Ahle Tasannun do not hold beliefs in the content of this hadith, its subject, and similar ones; then to use it as evidence against the Shiites is the utmost ignorance and will lead to complete folly and regret.
Rather, the so-called scholarly Nasibi himself stated in the fifth belief of the chapter on Imamate that:
The three caliphs are neither infallible nor explicitly appointed according to the Sunnis. (769) It ends with these words.

footnote.p: (769) Tuhfah Ithna Ashariyah: 180.

para.p: And here – as it follows that a liar would have no memory – he neglects this statement of his and claims explicit texts on the caliphate of Abu Bakr.

And in spite of this, (770) from the hadith: ( یأبی الله والمؤمنون إلاّ أبا بکر ) [God and the believers refuse anything but Abu Bakr], it must follow that – God forbid – the noble Amir (peace be upon him), who refused to pledge allegiance to Abu Bakr, would be outside of the believers, as well as other Banu Hashim and other companions who did not pledge allegiance to him, and also the Ansar, who at first wanted to make someone other than Abu Bakr the caliph, and Sa'd ibn Ubada – who sometimes did not pledge allegiance to Abu Bakr – would also be outside of the believers.

footnote.p: (770) [A] or [Fa] [Faydah:] The fabrications of the hadith: (Yahbi Allah wal-Mu'minun illa Abi Bakr). (12).

para.p: And the hadith: ( أبی علی [ ( علیه السلام ) ] إلاّ تقدیم أبی بکر ) [Ali (peace be upon him) would not approve anything but the precedence of Abu Bakr] has been described by the major hadith scholars of the Sunnis as fabricated and worthless, as mentioned in "Kanz al-'Ummaal":
عن علی [ ( علیه السلام ) ] قال : قال لی رسول الله [ ( صلی الله علیه وآله ) ] : سألت الله أن یقدّمک ثلاثاً ، فأبی إلاّ تقدیم أبی بکر .

Ali [peace be upon him] said: The Messenger of Allah [peace be upon him and his holy progeny] said to me: "I asked Allah to grant you precedence for three days, but He refused except to grant the precedence of Abu Bakr."
أبو طالب العشاری فی فضائل الصدیق .
Abu Talib al-Ishari in "Fada'il al-Siddiq".
خط (771) . وابن الجوزی فی الواهیات . کر .
Kht (771). And Ibn al-Jawzi in al-Wahiyat. Kar.
وقال فی المیزان : إنه باطل (772) .
And he said in al-Mizan: It is false. (772)

footnote.p: (772) [A] The virtues of Abu Bakr in the category of actions, before the chapter on his worship. (12). [B] Kanzul Ummal 6 / 319. [Kanzul Ummal 12 / 515 (printed by Mu'assasat al-Risalah, Beirut)].

para.p: And the original statement of Ibn al-Jawzi in "Elal Mutanahiya" is as follows:

( أنا ) القزاز ، قال : ( أنا ) أبو بکر الخطیب ، قال : أخبرنی الجوهری ، قال : ( أنا ) علی بن عمر الحافظ ، قال : ( أنا ) محمد بن مخلد ، قال : ( نا ) عمر بن محمد بن الحکم النسائی ، قال : ( نا ) علی بن الحسن الکلبی ، قال : ( نا ) یحیی بن ضریس ، قال : ( نا ) مالک بن مغول ، عن عون بن أبی جحیفة ، عن أبی جحیفة ، عن علی [ ( علیه السلام ) ] قال : ( قال لی رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم : ( سألت الله أن یقدّمک ثلاثاً ، فأبی عَلَیَّ إلاّ تقدیم أبی بکر ) .

(Narrated to us) al-Qazzaz, he said: (narrated to us) Abu Bakr al-Khatib said: Al-Jahwari told me, saying: (narrated to us) Ali ibn Umar al-Hafiz said: (narrated to us) Muhammad ibn Makhlad said: (narrated to us) Umar ibn Muhammad ibn al-Hakam al-Nasai said: (narrated to us) Ali ibn al-Hasan al-Kalbi said: (narrated to us) Yahya ibn Dharis said: (narrated to us) Malik ibn Maghul said, from Aun ibn Abi Juhayfa, from Abi Juhayfa, from Ali (peace be upon him) who said: (The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, said to me: "I asked Allah to advance you by three, but He refused to me except the advancement of Abu Bakr.")
قال المصنف : هذا لا یصحّ عن رسول الله صلی الله علیه [ وآله ] وسلّم ، وعلی ویحیی مجهولان (773) .
The author said: This is not authentic from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, and Ali and Yahya are unknown. (773)

footnote.p: (773) [A and B] Chapter on the superiority of Abu Bakr al-Siddiq from the Book of Virtues and Merits. (12). [A] And a copy of "Alil Mutanahiya" in Arabic script is, by the grace of God, available with me. [Alil Mutanahiya 1 / 182].

para.p: And al-Zahabi's statement in "Mizan" is as follows:

علی بن الحسن الکلبی ، عن یحیی بن الضریس – بخبر باطل لعلّ هو آفته – عن مالک بن مغول ، عن عون بن أبی جحیفة ، عن أبیه مرفوعاً : یا علی ! سألت الله – فیک – أن یقدّمک فأبی عَلَیَّ إلاّ أبا بکر . (774) انتهی .

Ali ibn al-Hasan al-Kalbi, from Yahya ibn Dharis – with a false report, Perhaps he is its defect – from Malik ibn Maghul, from Aun ibn Abi Jahifah, from his father, narrated as a an attributed statement (marfu) : O Ali! I asked Allah – concerning you – to put you forward, but He insisted to me only Abu Bakr. (774) End.

footnote.p: (774) [A] in the chapter on the letter 'ayn. [Mizan al-I'tidal 3 / 122].

para.p: And if he can extract the hadith from the "authentic" (sahih) collections, his truthfulness and the foolishness of the companions of the "authentic" (sahih) collections will become evident, as such falsehoods, which the elders of Ahle Tasannun explicitly declare to be lies, were included in the "authentic" (sahih) collections. Otherwise, it apparently seems that this is an accusation that has arisen against the companions of the "authentic" (sahih) collections.

And if by "authentic" (sahih) he does not mean the books of "authentic" (sahih), but rather means authentic narrations, then it is still rejected on the basis that (775): if this hadith had been mentioned in the authentic narrations of the Ahle Tasannun, why would their elders consider Abu Bakr to be non-explicitly appointed (ghayr mansus)?!

footnote.p: (775) Apart from the acknowledgment of the elders of the general public (Ahle Tasannun) of its weakness, which has been mentioned recently.

para.p: In any case; there are definitive pieces of evidence and certain proofs that indicate the non-explicit appointment (ghayr mansus) of Abu Bakr, and in consideration of that, the falsehood of this hadith and similar ones becomes clear, rather, it becomes evident even by the acknowledgment of the addressee himself, and all praise is due to Allah for that.

But regarding what he said: he believed with his own reasoning that the best for the religion and the community (ummah) was the caliphate of Umar, so it became necessary for him to act upon what he found to be in the best interest of the ummah... until the end.
Thus, it is contradictory and incompatible with what was previously quoted from the fourth belief in Chapter Seven of this book.

And whenever, according to the conveyed statement from the mentioned belief, it is more suitable for the accountable ones (mukallafin) that the appointment of a leader be entrusted to their reason, then the appointment of Abu Bakr and Umar may not be more appropriate for the accountable ones, and that is the objective.

As for, regarding what he said: "And so much the might of religion and the organization of the affairs of the nation, and the multitude of the slaughter (776) of unbelievers that occurred at the hands of Umar, is not recorded in any history as having come from the caliph of any prophet,"

footnote.p: (776) In the source (overthrow)

para.p: the response is that it has been mentioned in the hadith of "Bukhari":
« إن الله یؤیّد هذا الدین بالرجل الفاجر » (777) .
"Indeed, Allah supports this religion with a sinful man". (777)

footnote.p: (777) [A] Ghazwat Khaybar from the Book of Maghazī. (12). [B] Sahih Bukhari 5 / 133, Cairo 1313. [Sahih Bukhari 4 / 34 and see also Kanz al-‘Ummaal 10 / 182, 183, Musnad Ahmad 5 / 45, Majma‘ al-Zawa'id 5 / 302-303].

para.p: Therefore, if the support of the religion through Umar has taken place, it cannot be a proof of his virtue and merit. Here, it is necessary to establish his faith and suitability for the caliphate of the Noble Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and his holy progeny), not to prove that within his authority, the might of religion was established.
As for what he said: not appointing a successor (istikhlaf) is one thing, and forbidding from it is another.
So the answer is that: since he himself mentioned in the fourth belief of the chapter on Imamate that:
It is most appropriate regarding the obligations of the accountable beings that the appointment of a leader be entrusted to their reason (aql). (778)

footnote.p: (778) Tuhfah Ithna 'Ashariyah: 179.

para.p: This discussion does not benefit him.
And he also stated in the chapter on Imamate:

If we reflect carefully, we can ascertain that the appointment of an Imam by God is fraught with numerous corruptions (mafasid); because the opinions of the world’s scholars are diverse and their desires are varied. Thus, determining a single individual or even several individuals for all of humanity in all times of the world's existence would lead to the stirring up of conflicts (fitnah) and an increase in chaos, resulting in the neglect of the matter of Imamate, the dominance of the overpowering, and the subjugation and cautiousness (taqiyyah) of those individuals, and even placing them in the danger of annihilation, and their constant state of fear and concealment. (779) End.

footnote.p: (779) Tuhfah Ithna 'Ashariyah: 174.

para.p: And it is evident that the obedience to Abu Bakr was also necessary and obligatory due to his being one of the rightful leaders, like the obedience to God. And the Authority of God (Waliyullah) explicitly stated the obligation of obeying the caliph he has done so, so all the corruptions that he has deemed necessary regarding the appointment of a caliph from God must also be deemed necessary concerning the appointment of Abu Bakr and Umar.
However, what he said: otherwise, it would imply that the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) acted contrary to the Prophet in appointing Imam Hasan (peace be upon him) as his successor.

The answer to this is that this implication arises only if the Shiites believed that the Prophet of God, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, did not appoint a caliph, whereas you know that he himself addressed his response to this very insinuation by saying:
All the Shiites assert that the noble Prophet of God, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, appointed the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) as his caliph.

It is also established and realized among them that just as the Messenger of God, peace be upon him and his holy progeny, appointed the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) as his caliph, he had likewise commanded the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) to appoint Imam Hasan (peace be upon him) as his caliph after him.
